story:
Well hello there!

As many of you know, I'm producing this play.  Theater has a very special place in my heart, and I was lucky enough to see and do plenty of it while I lived in New York.  I have always found exhilaration in going to see theater; it's in your face, visceral, and anything can happen. 

Stephen Adly Guirgis writes the kind of plays I love.  

I read them or see them on stage, and I walk away inspired to seek a greater understanding of not only myself, but the people in the world around me. Guirgis says, "These are specific characters, with specific wants and desires."  He hopes the audience will not only come see a story about these specific people, but also see themselves within these people. In this play we are producing, the love runs deep, the emotions are high, and the struggles are unending.


A play of this nature, and a playwright of this caliber, deserve a good show.  We have raised $10K, and we need to raise a bare minimum $5K more.  This number allows us to secure the rights to the play, lock down the theater we want to use, and begin paying the key players (Production manager, set designer, light designer, etc.) who will help us create the vision our talented director has.  

Here come the exciting perks.  One of my hobbies is carpentry, and in exchange for a more sizable donation, I'm offering my services and craftsmanship to you.  Here's how it works:  

You donate $100, and you get a beautiful, engraved (5"X18") serving tray.

 

You donate $250 and you get a pair of benches.  

You donate $350, and you get a coffee table.  


You donate $3000, and you get a dining/kitchen table.  

You donate $3000, and you get this Adonis

You donate $4000, and you get an armoire.  

For $5000, you get this faccia bella...

At the end of the show, I will build your piece, or pieces, and everyone wins.  You pick the stain, and the design is something we can figure out together!  

The entertainment industry is not unlike many other industries; the more work you put in, the more opportunity you have to get something out.  Often times you have to create your own opportunities, and that is exactly what we are doing here! An opportunity of a lifetime.  These are the moments we all hope for, the cherished moments that make it all worth fighting for.

I have assembled an incredible group of passionate people, and we are working hard to put the pieces together.  Consider yourselves the facilitators of dreams.  Donate some money, maybe get a piece of wood, and then definitely, a hundred percent, come see the show!!  You're the ones.  Let's do this.

story:
Short Summary

Working together we are striving to create exciting Theatre, and create a feeling of family in our own work and in our community. Our members are a group of talented like minded individuals who pull strengths from all walks of life and bring their own unique views and talents to the work. We are looking to raise the 3000 to cover the cost of the rights to our shows, the rental for the theaters, props, set, guest artists, musicians, rehearsal spaces, advertising and anything under the sun that may arise in the beginning months of our company. We plan to put up atleast 2 to 3 shows this year including plays, musicals, improv shows, and concerts. Then from there the sky is the limit for us with support and help from the community.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise a total of $3000 

We will be using it to cover the rights to both our shows, rental fees for our performance venues, props, costumes, advertising, and anything else that may come up along the way. 

Rewards!

Any and all donations are greatly appreciated and all will be mentioned in our program and on our website!

$10-Knockout Collaborative magnent/sticker

$50-1 ticket voucher to a performance of your choice of either Middletown or The Last Five Years

$100-2 ticket vouchers to a performance of your choice of either Middletown or The Last Five Years

$200-4 ticket vouchers to a performance of your choice of either Middletown or The Last Five Years


    Risks & Challenges

    As a new theater company we face the reality that all those in the business face which is that people may not like your work. But that is a risk worth taking for our work, because I'm confident in the group of people I am working with to follow through and put together great work. Hiring people to help us when we are new may also be a challenge as well versed professionals in our community usually don't work for free, this may give us the option of giving new artists a chance as well. 

    Funding is always a constant concern for all theaters, so we will depend on our own initiative in raising funds, and the community to help us grow and thrive.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We will always be accepting the help of the community!

    • Spread the word about us and our shows
    • We will need ushers to help
    • Working the box office
    • Volunteers will always be appreciated and needed

story:
Sauter Dance Collective and Montpelier Movement Collective are creating an innovative and collaborative dance project portraying the emotions and experiences in the ebb and flow of family and its complex relationships. Sauter Dance Collective's portion captures the pulse of life, death, love, and anger in the realm of every family. Inspired by written submissions from a variety of friends, family, and even strangers, we will be combining the words, music, movement, and visual art of an extensive community of both students and professionals. Montpelier Movement Collective's portion of the performance offers a glimpse into the lonely experience of birth trauma and postpartum depression. It explores the essential role of family in what can be a polarizing and solitary experience for women. Both pieces examine the raw emotions tied to all families and the way we heal ourselves and one another.

Who We Are:

Kiera Sauter
Choreographer and Co-Director

Kiera Sauter grew up in Peacham, Vermont and has performed and taught in a wide range of performances in Vermont, New Hampshire, Maryland, and North Carolina. She found her love for dance at Contemporary Dance and Fitness Studio (CD&FS) in Montpelier where she received her early training. After high school Kiera went on to Goddard College and earned a BA in Choreography and Dance Pedagogy. Throughout her dance career, Kiera has trained in a wide range of styles from ballet and modern to hip-hop and stepping and has dabbled in other forms of movement, such as capoeira, salsa, and zouk. Kiera currently choreographs and performs around Vermont and is the founder and director of the Sauter Dance Collective, a small dance company based in Vermont. Subluxation: A Partial Dislocation, and Braving the Cold; Creating Some Heat are the two most recent shows which Kiera choreographed and produced for the Sauter Dance Collective. Kiera was recently selected as a choreographer for the Charlotte New Music Festival setting works on Pilobolus, Sean Currin, and Sterling Dance Company dancers. Additionally, she runs a youth choreography mentoring program for middle and high school students, as well as works as administrative assistant and teacher at CD&FS. Outside of dance, Kiera spends her time working on a wide variety of collaborations with other art forms, as well as cross training and learning about injury prevention and rehabilitation. 

Isadora Snapp
Choreographer and Co-Director

Isadora Snapp is a born and bred Vermonter, hailing from the Mad River Valley. She began dancing at four years old, but the pink tights and leotards turned her off of the idea entirely. It wasn’t until the fifth grade that she found her way back to dancing at Contemporary Dance and Fitness Studio in Montpelier, VT where she met and danced with Kiera Sauter. Summers were spent studying at the Bates Dance Festival, Alvin Ailey Summer School and Dance New Amsterdam, training equally in ballet and modern dance. Following high school Isadora attend New York University, Tish School of the Arts, Dance and has since returned to Vermont to teach, perform and choreograph. In 2010 she founded Montpelier Movement Collective (MMC) with Amy LePage, Avi Waring and Willow Wonder. MMC was established with the commitment to enriching Vermont’s exposure to the arts through performing, teaching and creating dances. Currently, along with choreographing for MMC, Isadora teaches in three different central Vermont studios and performs with SDC and Hanna Satterlee. In her limited spare time she loves enjoying a good book, gardening and caring for her two little ones. 

What We Need: 

By contributing to our campaign, you will be supporting a grassroots and collaborative effort between:

·  Budding writers

·  Students of dance and theater

·  Burgeoning composers

·  And, of course, the directors/choreographers bringing this all together

All money raised will first fund marketing and production of the show. If we exceed our $5,000 baseline goal, we will have the opportunity to offer compensation to our dancers. Our main goal, however, is to launch the project production this fall and to fund the use of three performance spaces for use in spring 2015.

We can’t do this without your help!

Please consider making a contribution to help us secure our performance space and lay the foundation of our project.

Impact:

All money raised through the Indiegogo campaign will support:

  • Rental of performance spaces
  • Sets
  • Costumes
  • Lighting and Sound Technicians
  • Other general production needs

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you would like to help in other ways, please consider donating goods or services, such as:

  • printing of programs
  • printing performance posters/advertisements
  • costume design/production
  • advertising performances
  • ushering 
  • filming
  • photography
  • tell your friends!
  • share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media

story:
Jessica meets Will and they are immediately attracted to each other. Summer passes by and the new school year starts--which means the start of infatuation, secrets, jealousy and a roller coaster of a relationship. "Be With Me" explores the dynamics of young love--all-consuming and ultimately devastating. We are the uncomfortable witnesses as we watch Jessica and Will spiral downward into self-destructive darkness.

We are premiering "Be With Me" at the 2014 Vancouver Fringe Festival.  It will be running from September 5th-14th at the Cultch on Venables Street and will feature the recorded music of Vancouver's  rising musical stars, The Belle Game!

Who We Are

Liz Maillard: Writer, Producer, and Actor (Jessica)

Liz Maillard is at the early stage of her career as a playwright, producer, director, and choreographer.

She grew up on the North Shore and attended Vanleena Dance Academy where she studied ballet, tap, jazz, hip-hop, and lyrical dance. She is a graduate of Capilano University’s Musical Theatre Program and has appeared recently as Baby Bear in Shrek, the Musical (Align Entertainment). She was the assistant choreographer for Cabaret (Pipedream) and was the choreographer for Scotch and Chocolate (Fringe, 2013). She has also choreographed student musicals (Alice in Wonderland, Aladdin, The Little Mermaid, Guys and Dolls) for the Lindberg Academy where she teaches musical theatre and is the coordinator of the EPIC Program.

Liz’s ultimate goal is to establish a small company that will bring edgy alternative theatre and dance to the Vancouver stage.  

The Belle Game: Music.

The Belle Game take intricate guitar and keyboard lines, anchored by dark pop rhythms, and weave them into gorgeous, graceful melodies. The Canadian indie authority Exclaim! describes their music as “indie-rock at its best: texturally layered, with echoing guitars, infectious rhythms and horns, and lavished in hooks.”

Cory Haas: Director.

Cory is an actor, director, and a little bit of everything else in between. He is a recent graduate of Capilano University from where he holds an ASAS diploma and a Bachelor of Performing Arts degree. Directing credits: Legally Blonde (TUTS/assistant, 2013014), The Boyfriend and Hello Dolly! (Exit 22/assistant). Cory co-created and performed in Naked Love (Fringe 2013). He has conceived pieces for FUZE and the Push Festival. He is thrilled to be part of this production.

Ranae Miller: Assistant to the Director.

Ranae is a graduate from the Capilano Musical Theatre program. Her credits include: Princess Fiona in Shrek the Musical (Align Entertainment), Tzeitel in Fiddler on the Roof (Ovation Award Nominee for Outstanding Supporting Female) and Liesl von Trapp in The Sound of Music (Gateway Theatre); Erica Snodge in Riverview High: The Musical (Entrance Theatre); Young “Little” Edie in Grey Gardens (FCP); Cinderella in Cinderella (Exit 22). She was honoured at the 2011 Ovation Awards with the Most Outstanding Newcomer Award.

Linzi Voth: Stage Manager.

Linzi is a multifaceted performing arts addict and takes turns being a stage manager, dancer, singer, actor, theatre instructor, and choreographer. She has a Bachelor of Performing Arts Degree and Musical Theatre Diploma from Capilano University and has appeared in VanDeca Choir–Alto (Evolution of Music Concert June 7th); Carrie (Fighting Chance, Fringe); Spring Awakening (Fighting Chance, Fringe); Cabaret (Pipedream); Magic to Do (ITP/WRS Productions); Mrs. Claus’ Kitchen (Famous Artists); Cocktails at Pam’s (Staircase XI); Made of Stone (Prohibition Theatre); Model Wanted (Friendly Haters); The Last Piece, Vic & Jack (Little Basket); We Are Three Sisters (United Players); Assassins (Pipedream); Qualia (Push). Linzi has also performed with Gateway, Royal City, TUTS and Metro. She works with children who have autism. 

Stefano Casadei: Actor (Will).

Stefano is a local actor, writer, and director. Though having worked mostly in film and television, he has always had a passion for the stage. With the production of Be With Me, he now will be able to make his theatre debut as Will Anderson, one of the play’s two primary characters.

The Impact

This is first show that Liz has written and produced. She is hoping that it will be the first of many and will inspire others to bring their work to not only the Fringe but to all Vancouver stages.  She wants to help encourage up-and-coming artists.  

What We Need  

•  We are looking to raise some money for our upcoming Fringe show!

•  This show is going to have a large multi-media aspect!

•  We will be using the funds we raise here to help make the show the best it can be, putting the funds we raise towards costumes, multi-media equipment, and  any additional costs that come up along the way.

What You Get

•  A plethora of Perks varying from thanks, to tickets to the show, to fun videos and signed posters.

•  You will have contributed to an original show and the World Premier of "Be With Me." You will have helped us to make that happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

Social media is a big thing these days. Feel free to share our IndieGogo page and attend our Facebook event here.

story:
YOU CAN STILL SUPPORT OUR JOURNEY!


Adia Tamar Whitaker, dancer, choreographer, singer, songwriter, playwright, educator, nation builder and visionary, moved to New York in 2000 to connect with different kinds of people from the African Diaspora and train to be one of the best dancer/choreographers in the country. 
Now, Adia wants to be one of the most prolific movement innovators in dance history.

After 14 years & 7 generations, Ase Dance Theatre Collective is going to TRINIDAD & TOBAGO to manifest that and so much more, but we need our nation IN BROOKLYN AND BEYOND to help us get there!

From Ghana to Haiti to Jamaica, the Ibo people left footprints across the Diaspora. They created legacies of resistance that reach from North America to the Caribbean to Nigeria. No matter where they landed, they were proud warriors that fought and died for their freedom.

The Ibos let no one define who & what they were.

As people of African descent living in the US, cultural pride and self-definition can be daily struggles. We're headed to Trinidad and Tobago to study the Ibo legacy of resistance as an entry point into retelling African stories of forced migration during the transatlantic slave trade. We’re interested in the ways American slavery continues to impact the contemporary experiences of African people in the Diaspora. 

A lot of our work is centered on the conversations contemporary folklore continues to have with traditional culture in the Diaspora. African spiritual tradition, vernacular movement, life cycle music and dance; the relationship between women and drums will be the focus of our work. We want to let the environment tell us what to do and how to do it. 

While in Trinidad and Tobago we plan to:

  • develop a dance for video project informed by the natural, urban and cultural landscapes of Trinidad and Tobago. 
  • experiment with and expand already existing repertory.
  • offer four intergenerational community master workshops in Afro-Haitian and Contemporary dance, Urban Movement, and Neo-Folklore of the African Diaspora.

We will also be traveling with the phenomenal filmmaker ORION GORDON who will document our journey.

And what are you helping to pay for? 

The Makeda Thomas Institute costs $1000 for the choreographer and $500 for each additional dancer. This fee covers HOUSING, LOCAL TRANSPORTATION, and THE VAST ARRAY OF CULTURAL EXCHANGE WORK AND RELATIONSHIPS we will build. We also have to cover TRAVEL COSTS and MEALS for each artist. 

This journey is an irreplaceable opportunity for Ase Dance Theatre Collective to rest, research AND reflect not only on the Ibo legacy, but on the legacy of our own work and what the next 13, 15, 20 years might bring.

In the spirit of our African ancestors,
Trinidad and Tobago has called
PLEASE HELP US RESPOND.
story_txt:
YOU CAN STILL SUPPORT OUR JOURNEY!



Adia Tamar Whitaker, dancer, choreographer, singer, songwriter, playwright, educator, nation builder and visionary, moved to New York in 2000 to connect with different kinds of people from the African Diaspora and train to be one of the best dancer/choreographers in the country. Now, Adia wants to be one of the most prolific movement innovators in dance history.After 14 years & 7 generations, Ase Dance Theatre Collective is going to TRINIDAD & TOBAGO to manifest that and so much more, but we need our nation IN BROOKLYN AND BEYOND to help us get there!From Ghana to Haiti to Jamaica, the Ibo people left footprints across the Diaspora. They created legacies of resistance that reach from North America to the Caribbean to Nigeria. No matter where they landed, they were proud warriors that fought and died for their freedom.The Ibos let no one define who & what they were.As people of African descent living in the US, cultural pride and self-definition can be daily struggles. We're headed to Trinidad and Tobago to study the Ibo legacy of resistance as an entry point into retelling African stories of forced migration during the transatlantic slave trade. We’re interested in the ways American slavery continues to impact the contemporary experiences of African people in the Diaspora. A lot of our work is centered on the conversations contemporary folklore continues to have with traditional culture in the Diaspora. African spiritual tradition, vernacular movement, life cycle music and dance; the relationship between women and drums will be the focus of our work. We want to let the environment tell us what to do and how to do it. While in Trinidad and Tobago we plan to:

develop a dance for video project informed by the natural, urban and cultural landscapes of Trinidad and Tobago. 

experiment with and expand already existing repertory.

offer four intergenerational community master workshops in Afro-Haitian and Contemporary dance, Urban Movement, and Neo-Folklore of the African Diaspora.
We will also be traveling with the phenomenal filmmaker ORION GORDON who will document our journey.And what are you helping to pay for? The Makeda Thomas Institute costs $1000 for the choreographer and $500 for each additional dancer. This fee covers HOUSING, LOCAL TRANSPORTATION, and THE VAST ARRAY OF CULTURAL EXCHANGE WORK AND RELATIONSHIPS we will build. We also have to cover TRAVEL COSTS and MEALS for each artist. This journey is an irreplaceable opportunity for Ase Dance Theatre Collective to rest, research AND reflect not only on the Ibo legacy, but on the legacy of our own work and what the next 13, 15, 20 years might bring.In the spirit of our African ancestors, Trinidad and Tobago has called PLEASE HELP US RESPOND.

story:
What Is This All About

'MURDER'

Written By: Hanoch Levin
Translated By: Barbara Harshav
Directed By: Yadin Goldman
September 19, 8:00pm
September 20, 8:00pm
September 21, 8:00pm
American Theatre of Actors
314 W 54th St, New York, NY 10019
*All the proceeds from the show will be donated to the international peace organization "One Voice".

'Murder', a tragedy in three acts and an epilogue, was written in 1995 by the late Israeli playwright Hanoch Levin. It portrays the Israeli-Palestinian endless cycle of violence and revenge. This play is not about sides, it is about people everywhere and the monstrous brutality they are capable of. More So, it is about how people do not change. When the current war in Israel and Gaza dies down, what then? Will we stick to violence and hate or will we finally give peace a chance? This timeless and universal play is a cry for change.

Levin was an extraordinary playwright. He had a way of creating the ugliest situations and characters through the funniest, most poetic language. We are proud to introduce his work to more people and have this outstanding play be our company's first production.  

Who We Are...

Exodus Theatre Company was created by Yadin Goldman (Artistic Director, from Israel), Jara Green (Production Manager, from Iceland) and Aubrey Taylor (Executive Producer, from the U.S.); all graduates of Circle in the Square Theatre School in New York. We made it our mission to tell riveting stories from around the world and to create theatre that battles ignorance, indifference and fear.

Visit exodustheatre.com to read more about the company!

What We Need & What You Get

We did the math and we need $4,500 to produce 'MURDER'. We made it a principle to make affordable theatre so we need your help to raise the money for:
1. The Theatre Space: 'MURDER' will be performed in a unique and intimate space at the American Theatre of Actors on 54th street. We chose this venue mostly because of its curious energy and the way it fits the play, but also because of how affordable it is considering the location.
2. Author's Rights: We are in touch with The Cameri Theatre in Israel which owns the rights to Levin's works.
3. Insurance: Safety first!
4. Rehearsal Space: Our cast is relatively large and therefore we have to rent studio spaces for our rehearsals. Obviously we are looking for the best deals out there.
5. Costumes & Props: Great costumes are essential when you bring Levin's work to life since one of the elements that make his theatre so unique are his extrovert and colorful characters.
6. Compensation: Too often, artists put their hearts and souls into a show without getting paid. We want to be able to pay the ensemble and creative team even just a small stipend to show our appreciation for all their hard work. 
On the right side of this page, you'll see the perks you get by contributing to our project!

The Impact

    All the proceeds from the show will be donated to "One Voice",                          an international peace movement dedicated to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. 

    We minimized the production budget as much as possible and every dollar we don't use for the show will go to "One Voice". So by donating, you are supporting two causes: our production of Levin's powerful play and the urgent effort to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The more money we raise, the more we can donate.

    Our Challenge

      This is ETC's first production and since we made a really bold choice of material, it's obvious that we have a long journey ahead of us and a lot to learn along the way. We feel  that we're up for the challenge and together with our fantastic cast, creative team and your help, we are confident that we will succeed in creating riveting, meaningful theatre. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      There are other ways you can support Exodus Theatre Company! Share this campaign with your friends using the Indiegogo share tools, visit our website and follow us on Facebook. Help us get the word out!

      Tickets to 'MURDER' can be purchased HERE ! 

      We thank you for all your support and look forward to making phenomenal theatre together!

The more money we raise, the more we can donate.


Our Challenge

This is ETC's first production and since we made a really bold choice of material, it's obvious that we have a long journey ahead of us and a lot to learn along the way. We feel  that we're up for the challenge and together with our fantastic cast, creative team and your help, we are confident that we will succeed in creating riveting, meaningful theatre. 


Other Ways You Can Help There are other ways you can support Exodus Theatre Company! Share this campaign with your friends using the Indiegogo share tools, visit our website and follow us on Facebook. Help us get the word out!
Tickets to 'MURDER' can be purchased HERE ! 
 We thank you for all your support and look forward to making phenomenal theatre together!

story:
Bridging The Houses of Stone is a performance of the heroic story of Zimbabwe’s great spiritual leaders, told through music, dance, and song. The beauty, spirit, and power of Zimbabwean culture will transport the audience back in time and across thousands of miles to a land whose rhythms and style of dance are rarely witnessed today in America. 

Bridges will feature artists from The Zimbabwean Artists Collective (ZAC), a group of Zimbabwean artists with a passion for celebrating and preserving their cultural heritage. Together, they act as Heritage Ambassadors, cultivating opportunities to bridge their traditional culture with their contemporary American lives in a unique and impactful way.

Their main objective is to act as a collective to further unify, organize and preserve their cultural history. One of the goals that ZAC has been focusing on creating collaborative performances addressing various themes that show case Zimbabwean cultural and spiritual traditions ZAC

The project is being partially funded by a grant given to artistic director Rujeko Dumbutshena from Brookyln Arts Council and is being supported by Cumbe Dance in Brooklyn, NY.  In order for this to be a successful project we are looking for contributors to match the funds given to ZAC to go towards artist pay, transportation and food while in New York preparing for the show. 

Perks for Donating: Donating will get you perks such as hand printed greeting cards, art work, and private mbira and dance lessons! 

Why this is Important to Us: As Zimbabwean artists one of our goals is to act as a vehicle to further expand the demographic of students and audiences of Zimbabwean arts and culture. This gives us am opportunity to highlight our culture rather than only our economic and political situations which are what most people are familiar with.

Previous Performances: ZAC artists, with support from Camp Mabina, AMP Concerts and North 4th Art have performed in a number of venues in Albuquerque New Mexico. These venues include the Cooperage, North 4th and the Albuquerque Balloon Museum. ZAC launched it’s first NY event by hosting a house concert for Mr. Cosmos Magaya October 2011.

Other ways to Help:

We are aware that some people are not able to contribute monetarily, but you can still help out in several ways! Here are some options: 

If you live in New York we need people to help host artists Tendai Muparutsa and Ronnie Daliyo who are coming in from out of town.

We need people to help set up if you live in NY.

Share this campaign with others

Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

 

….And that’s all there is to it.

story:
What are The Minty Awards?

The Minty Awards was founded in 2010 as a way to recognize the students of the Performing Arts Programs of the Catholic High Schools on Staten Island. 

  • We look to uphold the tradition to honor the talents of the performers while promoting their schools, their dramatic arts programs, faith and all who support them.
  • We believe that these students and schools provide excellent examples of self- discipline, teamwork, and talent that their families, friends, and community should celebrate.
  • We also value a good Catholic education, believing that it instills morals and principles these students carry with them after they have left high school.

The 2013 Minty Awards will be on Saturday, June 8 at 7pm at the historic St. George Theatre!

In the past two years, we have donated close to $10,000 to the Catholic High Schools. Last year, over 800 people attended The Minty Awards at the majestic and historic St. George Theatre.

What We Need & What You Get

As in the past, half of our income from ticket sales will go to the school which receives the St. Gensius Award for Outstanding Musical. However, this year we are trying to cover all our costs through sponsorships and ads, so that every penny we make from ticket sales will go to EACH participating school! By contributing to The Minty Awards, you are helping us come closer to that goal of giving back to every Catholic high school on Staten Island!

We're also offering great deals and prizes based on your contribution level!

The Impact

The Minty Awards is a unique event for the Staten Island community:

  • It is the only event of its kind on Staten Island.
  • It has been attended by dignataries from all members of the New York community: Archdiocean officials, Elected officials, Tony Award winning actors, civic leaders
  • Last year, over 800 family and friends gathered at the St. George Theatre, with the excitement building up for this year's event, we are looking to surpass 1000 attendees!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to help contribute through Indiegogo, we ask that you please help spread the word about The Mintys! Share this page on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, blog or any other site that will get people excited for this year's ceremony!

story:
Dear friends, family, and dance-making supporters alike!

     We are eight choreographers at The New School (NYC) graduating this semester, and we’re trying to raise funds for our senior thesis dance performance. We would seriously appreciate any support you can give - even $5 makes a huge difference!

     Each of us has been working to develop a unique dance work, which includes many different elements of production and preparation: spatial design, costume, lighting design, rehearsal space, sound scores and the like. Your generous donations will go directly toward paying our amazing running crew, building physical production elements, and adorning our incredible New School dancers in costumes that will complete our choreographic visions.

     We are so excited to premiere our original works at Abrons Art Center’s Experimental Theater space on April 12th and 13th, and we hope you come and experience it with us. Check out our donation perks below, which include mention in the program, free tickets, and a whole bunch of homemade cookies.

     Stay tuned for updates on our project, including choreographer profiles and videos! Spread the word, bring your friends, and thank you for the support!!


With so much love and so many thanks,

the Choreographers

*****

Ernest Baker
Stormy Budwig
Claire Johannes
Susanne Krall
Jean McLocklin
Ella Misko
Laura Scatena Romero
Leah Woodward

story:
SUMMARY

Greetings!  Welcome to the FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” indiegogo.com fund-raising campaign!  This is a non-profit full-length stage play featuring an all-Drama Student cast!  The play is targeted to premiere in the early fall (October) of 2013, on the campus of a Bronx, NY university.  A short run of five (5) performances of this theatrical event will be presented for the benefit of the surrounding community, and BATMAN / comic book industry fans near and far!  Log on to  www.fathersofthedarkknight.com for an in-depth look at the production!

 

THE PLAY

In March of 1939, an ambitious, young comic strip artist by the name of Robert Kahn was presented with an exciting and life-changing opportunity.  Vince Sullivan, the Editor and Publisher of National Periodicals Publications (known today as DC Comics), was trying to come up with another super-hero sensation to match the success of the recently debuted SUPERMAN.  Sullivan called Kahn into his office and presented him with the challenge of creating just such a character. Motivated by the lure of a lucrative weekly paycheck and steady employment, Robert (working under the pseudonym of  “BOB KANE”) spent the following year collaborating with his writing partner BILL FINGER and artist JERRY ROBINSON to create the Caped Crusader of Gotham City… THE BATMAN!


From his very first appearance in the May issue of Detective Comics (issue #27), the character was an instant success!  Having shrewdly negotiated a deal retaining half ownership of what would ultimately become a world-wide, multi-media sensation, Bob Kane went on to become a very wealthy celebrity artist over the following decades.

But behind the scenes, The Batman’s comic strip success was bitter-sweet.  While Kane enjoyed the sweetness of fame and notoriety, The Dark Knight mythology co-creators Bill Finger and Jerry Robinson saw mostly the bitterness.

How could this happen? How was it that Finger was never given the proper credit nor financial reward for his substantial role in the creation of the iconic Batman mythology?  Why did Kane refuse to give Robinson his deserved credit for his conceptualization of The Joker or for his design contributions for Robin The Boy Wonder?  In the stage production of “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT”,you will learn the answers to these burning questions, and so much more!

Set in Bob Kane’s studio apartment in The Bronx, circa 1939 and beyond, this ambitious theatrical drama is designed to play out on one half of the performance stage.  Here, you will witness the dramatic, humorous, and informative real-life creative process undergone by this intrepid trio as they flesh-out characters and build the fictional world of The Batman’s Gotham City!

But equally compelling will be the action playing out on the second half of the stage, where each fantasy character and environment developed by Kane, Finger, and Robinson excitingly comes to life before your very eyes!  You will be delighted by a live, gothic spectacle of sights and sounds, as classic comic book heroes battle the most terrible villains for the very soul of Gotham City!

As biographical drama meets fantasy adventure, you too will agree that “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” is a stunning theatrical achievement!

PLAYWRIGHT, PRODUCER, AND DIRECTOR

Overseeing this entire production as Playwright, Producer and Director is NYC Department of Education-registered Teaching Artist Roberto Williams.  With over 25 years of professional experience as a stage performer in New York City, Mr. Williams has enjoyed several careers in the arts, and now brings his passion for entertainment to his many performing arts student.

Having already written, produced, and directed numerous school presentations, Mr. Williams now embarks upon his most ambitious showcase of student talent to date:  The dramatic stage production of  “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT”!

Initially conceived of as a small high school production in October of 2011, Mr. Williams has steadily transformed the scope and scale of “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” into something that will become the new standard of excellence in student-produced theater.  For the sake of maintaining full creative control, and total faithfulness to the classic comic book source material, this production has been moved out of the (often confining) parameters of the school system, and is being produced independently.

Each student will be instilled with an invaluable sense of artistic pride and ownership from their involvement in this enterprise.  And this sprawling real-life tale of three poor boys from the Bronx who create an iconic, American mythology will serve as powerful inspiration to the production’s youthful cast, crew, and audience.

With The Batman mythology at the center of this production, a life-long dream  to create this gothic world on stage will be realized by playwright / director Williams and his excited students!

On a personal note, Mr. Williams feels that it is absolutely vital for disadvantaged inner city students to have ambitious artistic opportunities like “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” provided to them as often as possible. This need is particularly urgent now in the wake of yearly public school budget cuts to Arts-in-Education programs nationwide. With the generous help and support of the PARENTS of the student performers, Mr. Williams has developed “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” into a sprawling, ambitious production that boldly defies that unfortunate statistic!

With the launch of this inaugural production, Mr. Williams plans to quickly realize his dream of an elite All-Student Theater Company of talented performers as his pupils!

 

FUNDS ALLOCATION

We are working to raise $20,000 of production capital.  We are aware that this is a significant amount of money.  However, we can assure everyone that the money is being put to very good use. We need professional resources to make our student stage play as polished as it deserves to be.  

Mr. Williams has already invested over $10,000 of his own money to develop “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” as a showcase for his students.  He has personally hand-fabricated many of the props and costumes that have been created thus far, and designed the stage sets that will feature prominently in the play.  Please feel free to log onto the official website for an in-depth look with TONS of images and up-to-the minute production info! www.fathersofthedarkknight.com. 

This money will cover the expenses for:

 

Theater Space Fees

Stage Set Construction Materials

Set Furniture Pieces,

Construction / Carpentry

Practical Stage Effects (smoke / fog/mist machines, pyrotechnic squibs)

Video Projectors and Projection Screens Rentals

Lighting Purchases and Rentals

Sound Purchases and  Rentals

Additional Costumes

Props Purchase and Fabrication

Transportation

Rehearsals

Publicity / Promotion, 

Documentary Videography

Permits

Meals

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP


If you cannot help by contributing money to our production, you are still in a position to get the word out about this page!   We humbly ask that you PLEASE share this link on Facebook, Twitter, or any other social networking website.  In addition, PLEASE share our official website:  www.fathersofthedarkknight.com

We still need production stagehands, and key production positions still need to be filled.  If you would like to JOIN the “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” production team by donating your services, please contact us through the official website and tell us all about yourself!

Thank you SO much! We are SO excited to bring this production to life, and we hope to see you all on opening night!

 


NOTE: REGARDING THE LEGALITY OF THE PROJECT

This is a 100% NON-PROFIT student-made stage play.  We are making no revenue from the project. Any donations we receive on Indiegogo will directly fund the play.  They will never go into anyone's pocket.

Regarding our rights to make the series, Warner Bros. (owner of DC Comics/Entertainment) issued this statement regarding fan films/creations in 2004 that has been their policy ever since, a statement we strictly adhere to:  

"Warner Bros. definitely appreciates the enthusiasm and respect of its fans. We will continue to monitor the use of Warner Bros. properties as used in fan films / creations. However, we will only consider taking action against such films/creations that are either commercial in nature, are commercially exploited or otherwise engage in or depict inappropriate activity."

Motivated by the lure of a lucrative weekly paycheck and steady employment, Robert (working under the pseudonym of  “BOB KANE”) spent the following year collaborating with his writing partner BILL FINGER and artist JERRY ROBINSON to create the Caped Crusader of Gotham City… THE BATMAN!

From his very first appearance in the May issue of Detective Comics (issue #27), the character was an instant success!  Having shrewdly negotiated a deal retaining half ownership of what would ultimately become a world-wide, multi-media sensation, Bob Kane went on to become a very wealthy celebrity artist over the following decades. But behind the scenes, The Batman’s comic strip success was bitter-sweet.  While Kane enjoyed the sweetness of fame and notoriety, The Dark Knight mythology co-creators Bill Finger and Jerry Robinson saw mostly the bitterness.

How could this happen? How was it that Finger was never given the proper credit nor financial reward for his substantial role in the creation of the iconic Batman mythology?  Why did Kane refuse to give Robinson his deserved credit for his conceptualization of The Joker or for his design contributions for Robin The Boy Wonder?  In the stage production of “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT”,you will learn the answers to these burning questions, and so much more!  Set in Bob Kane’s studio apartment in The Bronx, circa 1939 and beyond, this ambitious theatrical drama is designed to play out on one half of the performance stage.  Here, you will witness the dramatic, humorous, and informative real-life creative process undergone by this intrepid trio as they flesh-out characters and build the fictional world of The Batman’s Gotham City!
But equally compelling will be the action playing out on the second half of the stage, where each fantasy character and environment developed by Kane, Finger, and Robinson excitingly comes to life before your very eyes!  You will be delighted by a live, gothic spectacle of sights and sounds, as classic comic book heroes battle the most terrible villains for the very soul of Gotham City!
As biographical drama meets fantasy adventure, you too will agree that “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” is a stunning theatrical achievement!
PLAYWRIGHT, PRODUCER, AND DIRECTOR
Overseeing this entire production as Playwright, Producer and Director is NYC Department of Education-registered Teaching Artist Roberto Williams.  With over 25 years of professional experience as a stage performer in New York City, Mr. Williams has enjoyed several careers in the arts, and now brings his passion for entertainment to his many performing arts student.
Having already written, produced, and directed numerous school presentations, Mr. Williams now embarks upon his most ambitious showcase of student talent to date:  The dramatic stage production of  “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT”!
Initially conceived of as a small high school production in October of 2011, Mr. Williams has steadily transformed the scope and scale of “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” into something that will become the new standard of excellence in student-produced theater.  For the sake of maintaining full creative control, and total faithfulness to the classic comic book source material, this production has been moved out of the (often confining) parameters of the school system, and is being produced independently. 
Each student will be instilled with an invaluable sense of artistic pride and ownership from their involvement in this enterprise.  And this sprawling real-life tale of three poor boys from the Bronx who create an iconic, American mythology will serve as powerful inspiration to the production’s youthful cast, crew, and audience.
With The Batman mythology at the center of this production, a life-long dream  to create this gothic world on stage will be realized by playwright / director Williams and his excited students!
On a personal note, Mr. Williams feels that it is absolutely vital for disadvantaged inner city students to have ambitious artistic opportunities like “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” provided to them as often as possible. This need is particularly urgent now in the wake of yearly public school budget cuts to Arts-in-Education programs nationwide. With the generous help and support of the PARENTS of the student performers, Mr. Williams has developed “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” into a sprawling, ambitious production that boldly defies that unfortunate statistic!
With the launch of this inaugural production, Mr. Williams plans to quickly realize his dream of an elite All-Student Theater Company of talented performers as his pupils!
 
FUNDS ALLOCATION
We are working to raise $20,000 of production capital.  We are aware that this is a significant amount of money.  However, we can assure everyone that the money is being put to very good use. We need professional resources to make our student stage play as polished as it deserves to be.   Mr. Williams has already invested over $10,000 of his own money to develop “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” as a showcase for his students.  He has personally hand-fabricated many of the props and costumes that have been created thus far, and designed the stage sets that will feature prominently in the play.  Please feel free to log onto the official website for an in-depth look with TONS of images and up-to-the minute production info! www.fathersofthedarkknight.com.   This money will cover the expenses for:
 
Theater Space Fees
Stage Set Construction Materials 
Set Furniture Pieces, 
Construction / Carpentry
Practical Stage Effects (smoke / fog/mist machines, pyrotechnic squibs) 
Video Projectors and Projection Screens Rentals
Lighting Purchases and Rentals Sound Purchases and  Rentals
Additional Costumes 
Props Purchase and Fabrication 
Transportation 
Rehearsals 
Publicity / Promotion,  
Documentary Videography
Permits
Meals
 
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
  If you cannot help by contributing money to our production, you are still in a position to get the word out about this page!   We humbly ask that you PLEASE share this link on Facebook, Twitter, or any other social networking website.  In addition, PLEASE share our official website:  www.fathersofthedarkknight.com  We still need production stagehands, and key production positions still need to be filled.  If you would like to JOIN the “FATHERS OF THE DARK KNIGHT” production team by donating your services, please contact us through the official website and tell us all about yourself! 
Thank you SO much! We are SO excited to bring this production to life, and we hope to see you all on opening night! 
 
NOTE: REGARDING THE LEGALITY OF THE PROJECT
This is a 100% NON-PROFIT student-made stage play.  We are making no revenue from the project. Any donations we receive on Indiegogo will directly fund the play.  They will never go into anyone's pocket.  Regarding our rights to make the series, Warner Bros. (owner of DC Comics/Entertainment) issued this statement regarding fan films/creations in 2004 that has been their policy ever since, a statement we strictly adhere to:  
"Warner Bros. definitely appreciates the enthusiasm and respect of its fans. We will continue to monitor the use of Warner Bros. properties as used in fan films / creations. However, we will only consider taking action against such films/creations that are either commercial in nature, are commercially exploited or otherwise engage in or depict inappropriate activity."

story:
Help support our 2013 Carnaval contingent!

In partnership with Rhythm & Motion and ODC, Latin Dance Grooves is preparing our 5th annual award-winning San Francisco Carnaval parade contingent. Our 2013 contingent theme is "Un Mosaico de Movimiento: Many Cultures, One People". We have over 100 dancers participating in our contingent, and we need your help in generating the funds to support their amazing work and dancing!

What is Latin Dance Grooves?

Latin Dance Grooves, created in 2008 by Elizabeth Soberanes, is a vibrant dance class and community that explores the sensual art of Latin dance! Taught by Elizabeth Soberanes and Bianca Coleman, our Latin Dance Grooves classes have developed a huge multi-generational community of dancers. With respect and integrity, Elizabeth and Bianca incorporate traditional dances such as Afro-Cuban, Rumba, and Afro-Brazilian, as a way of demonstrating the connection between traditional and popular dance. The goal is to help students develop an understanding and awareness of the cultural context of the diverse, sophisticated and complex rhythms of Latin dance. Additional guest artists helping with our parade contingent this year are Javier Gordillo Robles (guest choreographer from Peru), Regina “Califa” Calloway (guest artist instructor), Eyla Moore (rehearsal asst.), Shawn Peltier (make-up/hair design), Van Nguyen-Stone (videographer/film-maker), and Wendy Louise Miller (costumer).

What is SF Carnaval?

San Francisco’s Carnaval festival blossomed from its inception in Precita Park in the Mission District 35 years ago. Its growth and development is attributable to the passion of its founding members who longed for the traditional Carnaval celebrations of their native homelands. Those founding members were composed of people from many cultures, and walks of life ranging from musicians, dancers, artists and a host of local residents that saw the joy and happiness that came when they gathered in this multicultural celebration. Every year, the festival and parade draw hundreds of thousands of people for two days of dancing Salsa, Samba, Reggae, Tango, Hip- Hop, Merengue, Calypso, Cha Cha Cha, Cumbia, and Mambo into the evening. In addition to the parade, the Carnaval festival has vendors, arts & crafts, music, and activities for adults and children. The 2013 parade will take place on Sunday, May 26.

How will your contribution help?

While the dancers pay for their parade rehearsals and costumes, there are still many costs to putting our contingent together. We have a lot of ground to cover to get everything together for parade day. We would love to support our dancers with a gorgeous float, high quality sound system, food/supplies for a celebratory after-parade event and airfare to fly our special guest artist, Javier Gordillo, back from Peru to participate in the parade with us!

What do you get for contributing?

We want to bring you as close as we can to our community and parade experience. From free classes to a fully produced contingent DVD, our perks are designed to share our love and joy in Latin Dance Grooves and SF Carnaval. Our colorful list of perks can be found to the right on this page. As ODC is the fiscal sponsor for our contingent and a 501(c)3 non-profit organization, all donations (after value of perks received) are tax-deductible!

Other ways you can help …

Of course, we'd love for you to give to the campaign, but understand that not everyone is able to. If you can't, here are some other ways you can help:

  • Forward our campaign to your family and friends
  • Volunteer to help us on parade day
  • Come see the parade and cheer us on!

story:
Who We Are

My name is Claude Alick. I write under the name of C.C. Alick. I am a writer of novels, short stories and plays. My published works include Wet Storage and Other Stories, and Dancing with the Yumawalli. Originally from the Caribbean island of Grenada, I now make my life and my art in Missoula, Montana. In addition to other key people on this project, the most important professionals I will be working with are my children.

My daughter, Claudia Alick went to Hellgate High School, and holds her B A degree in theater from The George Washington University and a master's degree in performance studies from NYU. She is an associate producer at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in Ashland, Oregon.

My son, Jesse Alick also went to Hellgate High School, and the American Musical and Dramatic Academy in New York City. He works as an Artistic Associate at the Public Theater in New York City.

My other daughter, Maia Mills-Low went to Hellgate High School, and is an actor and sometimes student at the University of Montana.

The play has been an honor to write because Haiti and its continuous revolution remain central to the children of Africa in the diaspora. And sharing the production of this play with you and my children are the biggest honors for which I could hope.

 

 

The Project


This play is called Cowardice of Eyes. This theatrical piece seeks to bring congruency between how the world views Haitians and how the people of Haiti see themselves. The play deals with three elements of Haitian life: history, politics, and religion, presented through informative and penetrating dialogue, imbued with magical realism, music and dance. We will bring the richness of Haitian life to you. Their struggle, triumphs, all brought to the surface for those who are willing to witness it.

Why Do This
This play was written in response to the earthquake of January 12, 2010 that shook southern Haiti and my complete disgust at a television preacher who said God is punishing Haiti because of the Voudo religion. Having grown up in the region my heart broke at the ignorance and ill will this supposed man of God was spreading.


The magnitude of this disaster will last decades. The quake registered 7.0 on the Richter scale; the most powerful to hit Haiti in 200 years. The epicenter of the quake, just ten miles from Haiti's capital, Port -Au-Prince, suffered the full brunt of the devastation leaving the government unable to control the situation or mobilize their resources. Countries quickly sent aid, the initial response was great. The media ran many stories of stunning rescues of adults and children pulled from the rubble, some with crushed limbs, broken bones, and amputations in the days, weeks, and months that followed. After the initial well-spring of dramatic rescues, and aid from abroad, the media coverage receded and Haiti went out of sight and it seemed out of mind. Occasionally there would be some stories about some form of abuse by Peace Keepers, an outbreak of cholera, and aid workers feasting on American cuisine in restaurants just a stone's throw from camps full of homeless and starving Haitians.

 

With Cowardice of Eyes, we will keep the plight of Haiti in the minds and hearts of people of the world. While aid has helped the region, I believe understanding the culture of our neighbors to the south will help to change the misinformed and misguided understanding of this complex culture.

 

Your Investment

 

Your investment will be used to rent the theater space, hire a director, stage manager, designers: set, lights, sound, and other tech support, also house manager or ushers and cameras for filming the show and camera operators. In the even that my goal is not reached the play will be further financed from my own funds. The production will be staged in my home town of Missoula, Montana. Missoula is the most culturally diverse city in Montana. Missoula offers locals and tourists, the opportunity to see our locally operated attractions including symphony, ballet, many museums, and theaters to name just a few. The University of Montana is located in Missoula, and we are known for being an artistic haven in the Pacific North West.

As mentioned above, in addition to staging the play, we will be using the funds to produce a digital film to be distributed to schools and libraries. Portions of the funds will go to the Aristide Foundation for Democracy in Haiti, as well as the formation of an outreach organization to assist theaters in various parts of the US and abroad, to stage the play. Our primary goal with this project is to promote the educational and enlightening aspects we can bring to people everywhere about the Haitian people.


We hope you would like to be part of our journey by investing what you can, and assisting us to share all we can.

 

 

 

 



 

 

 


.

We hope you would like to be part of our journey by investing what you can, and assisting us to share all we can.

story:
OUR STORY

This summer, Studio 42 is thrilled to present WASPS by Ken Urban (The Awake, The Happy Sad), running July 24-28 at the Connelly Theater in Manhattan's Lower East Side. We are grateful to have received generous and important institutional support for this production, but we still have a fundraising gap of $3,500, and we need your help. Ken Urban's irreverent satirization of American politics in WASPS is exactly the kind of new work that Studio 42 champions, but only your support can make it a success!

ABOUT WASPS

Welcome to a dystopic trailer park fantasia where no dog, mail-order boy toy, or sex doll is safe.  

Bedazzler just wants a little refinement, but it's hard when your dad is a war vet addicted to beer, trailer park women, and jury duty. With the help of her libidinous gal pals, Bedazzler devises a plan to put her old man on the straight and narrow, but, as with most Greek comedies, Fate won't make it easy. 

Presenting Ken Urban's (morally) loose adaptation of Aristophanes' The Wasps, featuring lascivious lesbians, a New England power bottom, a militant community college feminist, and, of course, the family dog. In this foretelling of the not-too-distant Disunited States of America, Studio 42 asks the question: are those that pass judgement truly just? Also, why is that guy in a bee costume?

HOW YOU CAN HELP

As with all Studio 42 productions, WASPS challenges each artist involved to redefine what is possible in the theater. Below are only a few examples of the important impact your contribution will have.

  • $100 pays for a monthly metro card for one actor
  • $75 pays for costumes for one actor
  • $50 pays for printing of scripts for the cast of nine actors

Especially in this challenging economic environment, Studio 42 relies on the essential support of individuals like you to continue to sustain quality "unproducible" programming, and we're offering a few tokens of appreciation to thank you for your generosity. In addition, Studio 42 is a registered 501(c)3 organization and all contributions are tax deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law. 

SPREAD THE WORD!

Please help us spread the word about WASPS by sharing our campaign on Twitter and Facebook!

Better yet, join us July 24-28 at the CONNELLY THEATER for WASPS to experience firsthand the results of your generosity! Please click here for more information.

Thank you for your support, and see you at the show!

__________________________________________________________________________________

ABOUT STUDIO 42

Founded in 2001, Studio 42 is a not-for-profit theater company that produces “unproducible” plays that are spectacular, outrageous, and surpass the boundaries of convention. Armed with inventive and highly experienced designers, directors, and actors, Studio 42 sets out to prove that any project can be realized, and that audiences are hungry for access to more surprising productions. For more information about our commitment to “unproducible” theater visit www.Stu42.com.

story:
You People Are Amazing!

After just one month into our campaign to keep the Pageant Theatre  open and functioning by raising enough funds to purchase and install the industry required digital projection system, we have reached our minimum goal. The generous outpouring of support---not only financially--but verbally and emotionally---has been overwhelming. Our campaign continues through the end of December, which means that beyond the minimum we've reached, with future pledges of funds we will be able to upgrade the sound system---and perhaps most importantly to your comfort---the seating in the theatre.
In the upcoming weeks, we will be in touch with you about our perks promised, to get shirt sizes and other information related to your donations.

Our campaign continues through the end of December, which means that beyond the minimum we've reached, with future pledges of funds we will be able to upgrade the sound system---and perhaps most importantly to your comfort---the seating in the theatre.In the upcoming weeks, we will be in touch with you about our perks promised, to get shirt sizes and other information related to your donations.

story:
What is Valjean Friday Night Film Festival?

Valjean Friday Night Film Festival (VFNFF), is a festival for artists to display their vision the way they intended.  The 6500 sq. ft. location with spacious parking houses a 18ft x 23ft white cyc wall and quality surround sound. VFNFF serves as a Mixer to encourage like-minded individuals as well as a Screening for short films, skits, commercials, music videos, documentaries, and much more. Being one of the Creators it feels good to inhabit a space to unleash endless possibilities of creative imagery.

I am requesting donations from family, friends, fellow artists, movie fanatics, indie lovers, givers - that means YOU.  I want everyone to have a memorable, pleasant experience at the FINALE | VFNFF of 2012-2013.  This event will re-screen ALL winners of VFNFF Viewer's Choice.  Second screening exposes film to new viewers, in turn, they vote for The People's Choice.  Recipient of achievement is awarded.  Cash Prize given to the Winner of the festival selected by judges.

Let's continue to support the arts and encourage creativity.

 

Who We Are?

The VFNFF functions inside of Smooth Sound Multimedia - An all-in-one studio serving all your needs at once.  Smooth Sound Multimedia is owned and operated by Jerry Jackson.  Jerry Jackson has worked in the Entertainment Industry as a Director and Director of Photography (DP) for over several years. My involvement with Smooth Sound Multimedia has increased skill sets in Production, Event Planning, and Marketing. Another associate includes Anabella Ricardo with knowledge of Production and a specialty in the Art Department.  We are the collective synergy that holds the festival together.

Respective IMDb links:

  1. Jerry Jackson 
  2. Shanequa Reed
  3. Anabella Ricardo

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Funding will go towards Promotional Materials, Decorations, Staff, and Catering.
  • No Entrance Fee to the FINALE | VFNFF By Donating $10 or more.
  • $15 OFF Headshots (3 Look minimum and 2 Retouched Photos for $150)
  • 10% OFF Studio Rental, Short/Demo Reel Package, Taped Audition, Actor's Slate.

 All funds will be disbursed to categories listed above.

 

The Impact

By supporting the Valjean Friday Night Film Festival you help inspire more filmmakers to submit to festivals.  Festivals are a great approach to get your content out to the public. It takes more than just an ideal; you have to take action and must have determination to finish. VFNFF prepares first time filmmakers with a few guidelines enabling a smooth submission process.  The filmmaker gains positive feedback from the audience during Q & A.  Talking in front of the audience is essential, think of it as practice for your speech, especially when ready to pitch your project.  What better place than the VFNFF to screen your talent amongst others in an encouraging environment? 

Thinking of another way to help?

If you don’t have funds to help, please spread the word by sharing, using various Internet tools.  We all know how much every little bit helps.  And I look forward to supporting you in the future.
story_txt:
What is Valjean Friday Night Film Festival?
Valjean Friday Night Film Festival (VFNFF), is a festival for artists to display their vision the way they intended.  The 6500 sq. ft. location with spacious parking houses a 18ft x 23ft white cyc wall and quality surround sound. VFNFF serves as a Mixer to encourage like-minded individuals as well as a Screening for short films, skits, commercials, music videos, documentaries, and much more. Being one of the Creators it feels good to inhabit a space to unleash endless possibilities of creative imagery.
I am requesting donations from family, friends, fellow artists, movie fanatics, indie lovers, givers - that means YOU.  I want everyone to have a memorable, pleasant experience at the FINALE | VFNFF of 2012-2013.  This event will re-screen ALL winners of VFNFF Viewer's Choice.  Second screening exposes film to new viewers, in turn, they vote for The People's Choice.  Recipient of achievement is awarded.  Cash Prize given to the Winner of the festival selected by judges.
Let's continue to support the arts and encourage creativity.
 
Who We Are?
The VFNFF functions inside of Smooth Sound Multimedia - An all-in-one studio serving all your needs at once.  Smooth Sound Multimedia is owned and operated by Jerry Jackson.  Jerry Jackson has worked in the Entertainment Industry as a Director and Director of Photography (DP) for over several years. My involvement with Smooth Sound Multimedia has increased skill sets in Production, Event Planning, and Marketing. Another associate includes Anabella Ricardo with knowledge of Production and a specialty in the Art Department.  We are the collective synergy that holds the festival together.
Respective IMDb links:



Jerry Jackson 
Shanequa Reed
Anabella Ricardo

 
What We Need & What You Get

Funding will go towards Promotional Materials, Decorations, Staff, and Catering.
No Entrance Fee to the FINALE | VFNFF By Donating $10 or more.
$15 OFF Headshots (3 Look minimum and 2 Retouched Photos for $150)
10% OFF Studio Rental, Short/Demo Reel Package, Taped Audition, Actor's Slate.

 All funds will be disbursed to categories listed above.
 
The Impact
By supporting the Valjean Friday Night Film Festival you help inspire more filmmakers to submit to festivals.  Festivals are a great approach to get your content out to the public. It takes more than just an ideal; you have to take action and must have determination to finish. VFNFF prepares first time filmmakers with a few guidelines enabling a smooth submission process.  The filmmaker gains positive feedback from the audience during Q & A.  Talking in front of the audience is essential, think of it as practice for your speech, especially when ready to pitch your project.  What better place than the VFNFF to screen your talent amongst others in an encouraging environment? 
Thinking of another way to help?
If you don’t have funds to help, please spread the word by sharing, using various Internet tools.  We all know how much every little bit helps.  And I look forward to supporting you in the future.

story:
FRESH PRODUCE'd provides a place where new theatrical work can ripen. Dedicated to exploring new work, FRESH PRODUCE'd unites playwrights, actors, and directors to bring the page to the stage through risk, growth, and play. 

 

Founded in May of 2012 by a group of 10 theatre artists, FRESH PRODUCE’d performs 3 new short plays on the 3rd Thursday of every month at the Arthur Seelen Theater in The Drama Book Shop. FP has grown a lot in its first year, producing 33 fresh-picked plays and collaborating with more than 100 artists. Now we need your help to expand our monthly workshop series into our vision for our second year: professional rehearsal space and free participation for our expanding network of writers, actors, and directors.

At FP, our writers are the focus of our process. We welcome works in all phases of development, and we work closely with the writers to tailor the Thursday performances to the needs of their plays, from staged readings, to modestly-staged productions. This year we’ve helped to promote the work of dozens of playwrights from New York City and beyond, including Boston, San Francisco, Houston, and Canada. In addition to their work with FP, our writer-collaborators have had readings and work presented at Ars Nova, the Public Theater, and MCC Theater at the Lucille Lortel Theater, to name a few. Additionally, we produced three readings of playwright Brett Dalton’s FOOTPRINTS IN THE SNOW for Broadway League producers and we were selected by a Huffington Post contributor as one of her top theater companies in New York City in 2012, alongside the Public Theater, Playwrights Horizons and The Wooster Group.

And now we’re bi-coastal! Founding Producer Riva Di Paola forged westward, beginning the Los Angeles branch now in residence at the The Other Space Theater at The Actors Company. We’re excited to bring a whole new crop of Freshies into the bunch, and do some cross-coastal pollination.

But every pineapple plant needs water to grow. And it’s springtime at The Drama Book Shop. Every month, our core cast and guest playwrights chip in to rent the wonderful Arthur Seelen Theater for the evening. It is our goal to offer free participation for all! We need your support in order to make this possible.

Also, thus far, we’ve been using our apartments as stand-in rehearsal rooms. Our artists have been kind enough to commute from Washington Heights to the Village to Astoria in order to rehearse in cast members’ apartments. Our hosts’ kindnesses will never be forgotten, and our Freshies have had the opportunity to explore all of the corners of the city. However not every play benefits from an overly-friendly kitty bouncing in during the intense climax. We’d love the opportunity to offer professional rehearsal studios to our artists. We’ve really bloomed over the last year, and free participation and proper rehearsal space will provide us with the opportunity to flourish!

FRESH PRODUCE’d has thrived in Year 1, and we’re hungry to see what Year 2 brings to the table!  Help us to continue to freshly produce exciting, unique plays, and to make this year even better than the last. Thank you for your continued support, and we’ll see you on the next third Thursday! Upcoming shows: May 16th, June 20th, July 18th

 

This campaign is generously sponsored by terraNOVA Collective, a non-profit theatre company dedicated to new play development.

story:
Our Story

TBTB, Theater Breaking Through Barriers, is the only Off-Broadway theater, and one of the few theaters in the country, dedicated to advancing actors and writers with disabilities and changing the image of people with disabilities from dependence to independence.


We have a fantastic $50,000 grant from Bloomberg Philanthropies and must match 20% of it, or $10,000. If we succeed we become eligible for an additional $25,000. So your contribution can lead to a lot more money. We expect 5,000 from snail mail, and we need your help to reach 5,000 via indiegogo by January 15. 


Right now we are in competition with letter writing. The very old Artistic Director says he can raise more money by snail mail than electronics. Help prove the younger set right by donating today!


The Impact

Your support will help us to do a two play season at the Clurman Theatre on Theatre Row.  April 14-May 13, 2012 we will present The Merchant Of Venice  and June 20 - July 1, 2012 we will produce More Of Our Parts our 2nd annual 10-Minute Play Festival of commissioned plays about disability. 


The time for our strongest growth and influence is now.  It’s 21 years since the Americans With Disabilities Act was passed.  54,000,000 of us, nearly 20%, are dealing with a disability.  But nothing like this is visible in the media.  Only 2% of characters on TV exhibit a disability and only 0.5% are allowed to speak.  Hollywood is required to track casting based on age, gender and race, but they categorically refuse to track disability. This must change, and the use of disabled actors in disabled and able-bodied roles become as accepted as the use of artists of color.


What It Costs

$4,000 pays one actor's entire salary and benefits for a 7 week run of Merchant

$1,000 rents a light package.

$500 purchases a 10-minute play from a writer for the 10-Minute Play Festival. The first 7 people to donate $500 or more will be listed as "commissioners" of a specific play in the 10-Minute Play Festival. Four writers from last year have already signed on to write new plays - Bekah Brunstetter, Samuel D. Hunter, Neil LaBute and Kate Moira Ryan.

$250 pays for a small ad in the New York Times.

$100 pays for a poster outside the theatre.

$50 buys production scripts.


These are not glamourous expenses but they are the real expenses of putting on a play. The glamour is the illusion we create onstage and the participation of contributors and audience.


What You Get

$10 - A thank you in the program.

$25 - A mug with the TBTB logo, and a thank you in the program.

$50 - 1 ticket to either production, a mug with the TBTB logo, and a thank you in the program.

$100 - 2 tickets to either production, a mug with the TBTB logo, and a thank you in the program.

$200 - 2 tickets to both productions, a mug with the TBTB logo, and a thank you in the program.

$500 - The first 7 people to donate $500 or more will be listed as "commissioners" of a specific play in the 10-Minute Play Festival. 2 tickets to both productions, a mug with the TBTB logo, and a thank you in the program.

$1,000 - One performance of either production dedicated specifically to you on the day of your choice, with 6 free tickets to that performance. A poster signed by the company, and a mug with the TBTB logo. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends about our campaign, and our plays. Check out our website at tbtb.org
