story:
Cecily and Gwendolyn's Fantastical... is an ongoing, ever-evolving, audience-generated and driven, improvisational theater/social science experiment.

Theater artists and veteran improvisers, Kelly A. Jennings and Karen Getz, are Cecily Marlborough and Gwendolyn Hamm: Time-Traveling Victorian Social Anthropologists completing their study on the history of human culture. Gathering missing data on 21st Century cultures, they run a series of Fantasticals... subject-driven, anthropological field studies framed as "audience-interactive theater.”  In these, willingly gathered test-subject audiences engage in an empirical look at American life through a decidedly Victorian Lens; unearthing the absurd, incredible, often gobsmackingly wondrous elements of our unexamined, everyday lives.

Hoping to observe how this democratic society works, The Fantastical… will spend 2012 traversing the USA, diving under the waves of vitriol spewing from its mass media to meet actual Americans.  The Fantastical American Anthropological Inquisitorial Probe (and world domination tour)  will land at The Phoenix, Cincinnati, St. Louis, D.C., Minneapolis, Boulder, Philadelphia and, possibly, New Orleans, Fringe Festivals.  Within the instant, joyful communities formed at each Fantastical…Cec and Gwen hope to uncover the mechanisms of a functioning (?) 21st Century, Democratic Society “ through it's unique and fascinating citizens. In December, Cec and Gwen will share their findings in series Fantastical Symposiums…at their Earth base camp in Philadelphia.



                 The Fantastical….Indiegogo Funding          

                                      Campaign -Phase #1

Target-$3200

 

Cecily and Gwendolyn's Fantastical...is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Cecily and Gwenolyn's Fantastical ... must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law 


For easier digestion, our funding campaign is broken down into three,  bite size, phases.

                                Phase 1-COSTS

Travel/Lodging, Festival Fees, Production and Administrative Costs, first 3 Festivals: Phoenix, Cincinnati and St. Louis

Phases 2 and 3 will cover costs for The Capitol, Minnesota, Boulder, Philadelphia and New Orleans Festivals plus Final run/symposium in Philadelphia.

And now, $3200 in costs, broken down:

Phoenix: March 8th – March 11th

  • Application Fee:$35
  • Participation Fee: (after grant from Festival) $150
  • Round trip airfare for 2- PHL-PHX:$900
  • Southwest Airlines (Lovely People!!)
  • Lodgings:$90
  • Metcalf House Hostel (Coolest Hostel in the West)
  • Cabs to/from Airport:$40
  • Promotional Material/Programs/Postage: $25
  • TOTAL PHOENIX COSTS: $1240

 Cincinnati: May 29- June 9

  • Application Fee:$50
  • Round trip airfare for 2- PHL-CVG:$650
  • Lodgings: (Provided by Festival)$0
  • Car Rental: $200
  • Promotional Material/Programs/Postage:$25
  • TOTAL CINCINNATI COSTS:$925

St. Louis: June 20- June 26

  • Application Fee:$25
  • Participation Fee:$150
  • Round trip airfare for 2-PHL-STL:$635
  • Car Rental:$200
  • Promotional Material/Programs/Postage:$25
  • TOTAL ST. LOUIS COSTS:$1035

TOTAL COSTS FOR PHASE #1 -  $3200

 

Have no cash?  Want to help?

Have frequent flier miles you want to donate?  Have a friend at Southwest Airlines who can get us a sponsorship?  Want to help feed us?  Have friends in the food business in Cincinnati, St. Louis, D.C., Boulder, Minneapolis, Philadelphia or New Orleans?

We need footage and editing finesse.  Know folks who can shoot our shows across the  States?  Have some editing time you want to donate? 

                               

 WHO WE ARE AND WHY WE DO WHAT WE DO

Karen Getz and Kelly Jennings are professional theater artists who work within the conventional and devised theater communities of Philadelphia. They are both actors, makers, directors, producers, teaching artists and passionate, long-form improvisers.

 

They began working together in 1994 as company members of Comedysportz Philadelphia, ran Tapestry Theater (work for and by women who dare!) from From 1997-2005, produced The Annual Female Funnyfest from 1999-2002 and were 2/5's of the revered and beloved Philly Long-form ensemble, Lunchlady Dorisˆ, from 1997 until it folded in 2009.

 

Inspired by the ensemble-based, character-driven work they were doing in Doris and anxious to take the work further, they set their sites on a fearless, fourth-wall-free, completely improvised, audience generated and integrated, two-person show. The first of these was Killer Pussy, a Super-Hero, Audience-Interactive, Action-Adventure, played throughout the house. Premiering at The 2006 Philly Fringe Festival, Jennings and Getz continued to explore the format the Philly's SPARK, Improv and Fringe festivals.

 

The characters of Cecily and Gwendolyn made their first appearance during a Killer Pussy show and kept creeping into the work, demanding to be heard. Karen and Kelly finally acquiesced to the these slightly mad Victorian women in early 2008 and Cecily and Gwendolyn’s Fantastical.... was born. Debuting at the 2008 Philly Fringe, The Fantastical...garnered critical acclaim and a devout fan base with runs at The Philadelphia Improv Festival, Two Philadelphia SPARK Festivals, The 2009 Philadelphia Fringe Festival, The 2010 Philadelphia Second City show at PTC , two Philadelphia Joke Initiative Produced runs (2009 and 2010),  The 2011 Capital Fringe Festival and The 2012 Phoenix Fringe Festival, this past March.

 

In addition to their work as actors, directors and makers and their blind and proudly geeky obsession with all things Victorian, British, Science, Science-fiction and Socio/Anthropological, Kelly is a teaching artist for The Philadelphia Shakespeare Festival and a revered improv ensemble coach. Karen is 3x Barrymore award-winning choreographer and the creator of 3 original, comic-actors’ ballets (Suburban Love Songs, Disco Descending and The A.I. Project.) At the very moment of this writing, Kelly is directing The Music Man just outside of Philly and Karen is choreographing Dessa Rose in Richmond, Va.

story:
Hello!

My name is Rosanna Karabetsos, but everyone calls me Rosie! I am a junior in high school, I attend the Greater Hartford Academy of the Arts. (http://www.crec.org/magnetschools/schools/artsacademy/) I have been dancing ever since I could walk, I really don't know where i'd be without it! I have been accepted into the American Dance Festival, six week school, in North Carolina this summer.(http://www.americandancefestival.org/) . It'll be a time of self research, and growth in my art of dance. I can't express my excitement as I prepare for this amazing experience! Starting on June 14, I'll be spending my days taking classes with amazing artists from around the country, and the world. This will be the experience of a lifetime and I need your help to get there!

Help!

What I need is quite simple, help raising funds for my tuition for ADF. My goal is to raise around $4,000...and I don't have much time! My tuition will pay for my boarding costs, my food and everything else I need for my six weeks in North Carolina. Every cent will get me one step closer to the American Dance Festival!

 

Spending six weeks in a new city doing the thing I love most will be a dream come true. I have never had the chance at an opportunity like this ever before! To help me just a little bit more, you can post or share this link to anyone you think could help!

thank you!


**Up at the top is the video I sent into ADF in hopes of receiving a scholarship. It shows a short solo, and a few minutes of technique. I will be posting more photos, and videos as well as updating the page with any other information I find out!**

Spending six weeks in a new city doing the thing I love most will be a dream come true. I have never had the chance at an opportunity like this ever before! To help me just a little bit more, you can post or share this link to anyone you think could help! 
thank you!

**Up at the top is the video I sent into ADF in hopes of receiving a scholarship. It shows a short solo, and a few minutes of technique. I will be posting more photos, and videos as well as updating the page with any other information I find out!**

story:
We are bringing our show to New York and we need your help to put it up!

DUELING HARPS is an elegant night of music and antics created by performers Ann Magnuson , Adam Dugas, harpists Alexander Rannie and Mia Theodoratus, and the puppeteer Robin Walsh. Our show runs October 14, 15 and 16, 2010 at the Abrons Arts Center located in New York City’s Lower East Side.

This is a fun and unique show of music and performance and these kinds of things only happen with independent backing. Here's how we pitch it: A darkly elegant evening of gorgeous melodies with a theatrical flourish. Ann Magnuson and Adam Dugas face off on vocals as Alexander Rannie and Mia Theodoratus strum their harps in this twisted match of musical one-upmanship. The quartet thrusts and parries with an arsenal of tunes ranging from the ridiculous to the sublime: psychedelic calls to prayer, Henry Purcell’s Baroque art songs, Kraftwerk, Buffy St. Marie, Lee Hazlewood and Pink Floyd, as well as original songs by Magnuson and Dugas. 

Dugas and Magnuson meet upon the stage to resolve a grudge; a duel ensues to settle their dispute that is fought using only music. Each singer brings a second to accompany them on the harp, the only other weapon allowed in the duel. Dugas and Theodoratus represent the East Coast, Magnuson and Rannie the West, as a battle rages - with much trickery and tomfoolery. Robin Walsh adds a dash of the surreal with her puppetry, and a special Halloween encore rounds out the night. There will be blood! 

Why do we need your help? We are producing this all ourselves and need to fly and house three fantastic artists from Los Angeles in pricy New York City. We are trying to keep the door price low ($20) so that as many people as possible can attend and therefore we could use a bump in our financing to help cover production costs like props and puppet construction, and to pay all the artists involved a respectable fee: lighting designer, sound man, costumers, etc

If you can't give today, please help us spread the word!

story:
Our Story  

Edna Miroslava Barrón and Karen Anne Light are artists living in San Francisco. They joined forces in 2009 at Flying Actor Studio in SF, while participating as students of its nine month physical theatre conservatory under Master Teachers James Donlon and Leonard Pitt. Edna and Karen found inspiration in each other, and their equally strange and absurd sense of humor, as well as their mutual obsession with Alice in Wonderland. Thus, a roller-coaster of theatrical adventure and strangeness ensued....


Alice: Down the Rwong Wrabbit Whole is an original comedic play, in development since autumn 2009. The script has been created from an extensive period of improvisations by Edna Barrón and Karen Anne Light, with guidance and mentorship from John Gilkey.

Aside from Alice in Wonderland the San Francisco artists have been influenced by the physical theatre techniques they studied together--mime, mask, clown, ensemble theatre--at Flying Actor Studio of San Francisco (website below). John Gilkey, a principal comedic performer in Cirque du Soleil and SF comedy troupe "We Are Nudes" (see websites below), was a guest teacher at FAS. He graciously agreed to continue working with Edna and Karen after their year at the Conservatory ended.

A short, incomplete preview of Alice (featuring guest performer, Laura Ferrari) was presented in January of 2011 to select audiences at Studio Gracia in SF, and now it's time to produce the show in its entirety.

In this play, the audience witnesses Karen and Edna attempt to adapt the animated movie, Alice in Wonderland, into a "full-length theatrical production in which two women play each of the 359 characters." In reality, the play is an account of the psychological unravelling of the actresses, strangely braided with the story of Alice. The humor lies in the stream-of-consciousness detours that the actresses take as their character flaws relentlessly impede their own progress. Thirty seconds in, the play's title is readily earned.

WHO WE ARE

EDNA (ED' GNAW-)


(websites below: sparklycuntjob.com , hookup-productions.com)

Edna studied Performing Arts & Social Justice at the University of San Francisco where she adapted, produced and directed the full-length novella, 'The Face', by David St. John, a professor/poet from USC. She also trained with Dijana Milosevic from Dah Teater in Belgrade, Serbia and assistant directed her show, 'Necromancers,' a story about the ethnic cleansing war of the early 90’s in then-Yugoslavia. Her USF thesis consisted of co-writing, performing in and creating sound design for a show called 'The Understory,' highlighting underprivileged SF communities, Bayview Hunter's Point and Tenderloin, with consultation from filmmaker, Kevin Epps. In early 2009, she completed her first community year-long residency at Climate Theater. 
Edna works on comedy sketches with performers in the Bay Area and abroad. On the side, she works as a motion capture performer at Mixamo Inc and was most recently featured in the Telltale Games' Jurassic Park. She dabbles in sound design and video editing as well. Her first short film, 'Passersby' was shown in two film festivals in 2009. She is also Dj Nobody at San Francisco's KUSF, the recently exiled online radio station of USF.

KAREN (NEER-ACK) (aka "Kare Bear")
(website below- karenannelight.weebly.com...under construction)

Karen Anne Light began acting in ensemble theatre productions as a young girl in Chico, California, and realized early in life that she had found her calling. She majored in Theatre Arts at San Francisco State University, where she focused on Suzuki Method, Meisner Technique, and Ensemble Theatre. In Oxford, Karen studied Shakespearean theatre and contemporary theatre at the British American Drama Academy. She also studied briefly in Paris with Theatre du Soleil. 
Karen's experience in professional and student performances in SF range from an all-female Shakespeare company, to Butoh and Bedouin dance, to the SF Opera. Her work in video and film art has led her to collaborate with the likes of George Kuchar and Michael Rudnick. Karen also has ten years' experience in various styles of Middle Eastern dance. She has studied and performed as a core member of Life Dance Theatre of San Francisco. 
Recently, Karen apprenticed with celebrated playwright, director, and actor, John O'Keefe. This experience jetstarted her into producing her own work. She presented her first solo show, a movement-based storytelling sequence called "Portals", in October 2010. She is currently in the process of writing a new script, "Red House".

    REVIEWS

    Here is some feedback from audience members at the preview performance:

    "Karen and Edna have paired up as a diva and doofus. A kind of art scene Abbott and Costello. And it works! It is about a story that never was, namely Alice in Wonderland. Oh yes, they have a very wet Mad Hatter's tea party which is hilarious (thank God it was in a plastic pool), and then the rabbit hole (a hula hoop that seems to keep moving) the mushroom, the shrinking and growing Alice..But halfway through, a series of wonderful and funny catastrophes set in and the piece gets even funnier."               -John O'Keefe, award-winning playwright, actor, and director

    "I sometimes dwell in sober acceptance that real life is not as good as it is in cartoons. But to my surprise, the wascally wrong wabbit hole adventure of two lively looney toons, Karen and Edna, batting their big round eyelashes and spinning around and about in a psychedelic, super-spirited frenzy, is an impressively metamorphic bit of theatre to behold! "     -Chris White, performer

    "Clowning with stand up and sketch comedy...Edna and Karen are right on the cutting edge. Edna's simple playfulness is the perfect foil for Karen's stern faux intellectualism spinning Alice down all sorts of wrong rabbit holes."  Michael Sommers, playwright and director

    ''The performers, Karen Anne Light and Edna Miroslava Barron--brilliant, subtle gorgeous movers. They have a wonderful control of their bodies. Funny? Fucking hilarious...in this incisive way that captures the nuance of all the messy stuff of being human...Their relationship to each other intertwines with the story of Alice in Wonderland as they play all the characters and the tree, and switch who gets to play alice, and pour water over their hands from teacups, and sing through the holes of tutus..." -Karen Penley, playwright and performer

    WHAT IF...

    We already tried a campaign on kickstarter and it failed because we asked for too much and couldn't circulate it to enough people. On kickstarter, you don't get any of your funding unless you reach your goal. If we don't make  any money, we can't pay all the people who help us get the show up. It's very difficult to find venues that don't ask for rental fees upfront, but luckily, we've found a new gallery space in SF called the Emerald Tablet, which will split the door with us each night. We're very happy about this because now we can spend the money we get to pay people and get all the right things for our set! And that is why we've moved our fundraiser here to indiegogo, where we can keep the funds raised regardless of reaching our goal or not. YAY indiegogo!


    What We Need 

    THE SET- Edna and Karen have already assembled and procured a majority of the set and costumes from local thrift stores, under a less-than-a-shoestring budget. Kind friends and fellow artists have lent their aid in construction of a giant toadstool mushroom, and a hula hoop-and-paper rendition of a giant vagina (!).

    THE SOUND- The mindbending, melting cartoon-style soundscore has been wittilly crafted by Ms. Barron.

    THE LIGHTS- Lighting cues are simple and can be easily modified for any performance venue.

    THE TOUR- The artists are in communication with fellow artists in SF, LA, NYC, and Portland to secure performance venues for their tour.

    GUEST PERFORMERS- Part of the show involves collaboration with a guest performer. The preview featured Laura Ferrari (LA-based clown, comedian, actress; website below). Future presentations may include Miss Ferrari, as well as Eduardo Vildasol (international costume designer, comedic actor, physical performer, visual artist; last website below), and Jane Osborn (LA-based aerial performer, clown, actress, musician; website below).

                *                 *                  *                 *                  *                *                  

    WHERE YOUR MONEY WILL GO

    -Payment for artists, guest performers, designing artists

    -Material costs for new set pieces, lights

    -Venue fees in NY and LA



    **WE ARE ASKING FOR MUCH LESS THAN WE ACTUALLY NEED FOR THE FULL TOUR. 

    WE ARE GRATEFUL FOR WHATEVER YOU PLEDGE....FEEL FREE TO PASS THIS ON TO FRIENDS (and enemies), AS WE WOULD LOVE TO RECEIVE BEYOND OUR REQUESTED AMOUNT!!**

        THANK YOU ! THANK YOU! THANK YOU! THANK YOU! THANK YOU!!

    ** Promo photos by Adrienne Fodor (www.takingpictures.org)

    ***Special thanks to Bernard Vash for Voice Coaching

    ****Thanks to Karla Claudio Betancourt for recording the Preview performance and Skype rehearsal with John Gilkey. http://www.detacto.blogspot.com

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Tell your friends to donate a dollar!

    Here is our website: www.RwongWrabbitWhole.webs.com


    Here are other websites you may be interested in viewing:


    2. hookup-productions.com
    3. johngilkey.com
    4. flyingactorstudio.com
    5. lauraslittletop.com
    6. wearenudescomedy.com
    7. janeosborn.com
    8. web.me.com
    9. johnokeefe.org
      1. sparklycuntjob.com
      2. karenannelight.weebly.com

story:
Short Summary

Hello all! My name is Suse Doepken, a recent graduate from Western Oregon University. In 2020 I completed my senior thesis project, which is a full-length play that delves into David Bowie's music, relationships, addictions, and significant events that shaped his life and work. I have always loved his work, and I spent the last two years researching and finalizing this script with the plan of a performance before my college graduation. Unfortunately, it had to put it on pause due to COVID-19.

Thankfully, the wonderful Majestic Theater in Corvallis, OR has been able to reserve space for me in their theater so that I can not only perform the play I spent years writing, but also film it for those who cannot travel to see it due to restrictions. However, it's very expensive for a recent college grad, so I'm reaching out in hopes others can help donate to decrease the upfront cost I'm facing for not just the venue, but also the minimal costumes, props, and lighting the play requires.

What We Need & What You Get

I am aiming to raise $1500, which not only covers most of the cost of reserving the space, but also allows me a small budget for costumes, props, makeup, etc. Rental space for 4 or 5 days will be around $1000, and costumes, etc will be around $500.  Any extra money will only help make this stage production the best it can be, such as extending our reservation to allow more practice and performance days. I'm very grateful to all of your support in this endeavor <3

PERKS!

-For donations of $1, you will receive a link to watch the play once it has been filmed and edited!

-For donations $5, you will receive a link to watch the play once it has been filmed and edited!

-For donations $10, you will receive a link to watch the play, as well as a playbill that will be mailed to you!

-For donations $20, you will receive a link to watch the play, a playbill, a thank you card from cast and crew, and our eternal love <3

If the goal of $1500 is not met, all proceeds will still go to funding this production, the rental space, costumes, props, etc. Any donation helps, and we're grateful for your support!!!

The Impact

The reason I wrote this play at all was because I wanted to share my love and interest of David Bowie with others. He and his music have had a profound impact on me. I think examining his life in order to understand his music is fascinating, and I want others to see his work through the same lens I do.

This play has been like a literal child to me, and not being able to perform it last year was truly devastating. Although it's obvious why it couldn't happen, I'm extremely glad that an opportunity came along for me to continue this project. I'm determined to do everything I can to make this production possible, hence this indiegogo project!

Other Ways You Can Help

I totally understand if you are not able to contribute, and I'm so thankful you even clicked this indiegogo to check it out! If you can't contribute, I hope you consider sharing or telling your friends about it to continue getting the word out <3

story:
Panoply Collective 

Panoply Collective is a Toronto-based actor's initiative. We aim to challenge audience preconceptions of classical theatre, and we seek to re-tell narratives with a feminist, inclusive, and accessible perspective.

Panoply had originally planned to stage our adaptation of Peter Pan this summer in an outdoor theatre. Given the circumstances with COVID-19 preventing in-person shows, we were able to adapt this production into an audio play to bring this magical and uplifting story to your homes during this time of isolation! Peter Pan is hosted online via YouTube and SoundCloud. 

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign replaces the Pay-What-You-Can funds we would have collected from our live shows this summer. The total amount of $1600 is based on an average of our income from previous shows, and our projections of what profit shares would have been for our performances this summer. 

  • 70% of the proceeds will be split in equal parts among the actors & creative team of Peter Pan, who have volunteered their time to participate in the production. 
  • The remaining 30% will be donated to a Toronto organization called Black Womxn In Motion.

Black Womxn In Motion

While we hope this audio drama will provide a sense of joy, connection, and community during this period of isolation, we must also acknowledge that our production was able to exist due to many compounding privileges. This injustices upheld by white supremacy and the ongoing systemic racism which BIPOC still face today, in the theatre community and beyond, must be fought against.

We would like to encourage everyone to continue focusing their energy on anti-racist actions. Specifically, we'd like to direct your attention to Black Womxn In Motion. BWIM is a Toronto-based, youth-led organization that empowers and supports the advancement of Black womxn and survivors of sexual violence. 30% of our proceeds will be going towards BWIM. We at Panoply are proud to support their cause, and encourage you to do the same. For more information visit their website: https://blackwomeninmotion.org/

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help us reach our goal by sharing this campaign!
  • Follow us on Instagram & Facebook 
  • Have any questions? Send us an email at admin@panoplycollective.com

Thank you for your support! We are so looking forward to sharing this magical production with you.
story_txt:
Panoply Collective 
Panoply Collective is a Toronto-based actor's initiative. We aim to challenge audience preconceptions of classical theatre, and we seek to re-tell narratives with a feminist, inclusive, and accessible perspective.
Panoply had originally planned to stage our adaptation of Peter Pan this summer in an outdoor theatre. Given the circumstances with COVID-19 preventing in-person shows, we were able to adapt this production into an audio play to bring this magical and uplifting story to your homes during this time of isolation! Peter Pan is hosted online via YouTube and SoundCloud. 

What We Need & What You Get
This campaign replaces the Pay-What-You-Can funds we would have collected from our live shows this summer. The total amount of $1600 is based on an average of our income from previous shows, and our projections of what profit shares would have been for our performances this summer. 

70% of the proceeds will be split in equal parts among the actors & creative team of Peter Pan, who have volunteered their time to participate in the production. 
The remaining 30% will be donated to a Toronto organization called Black Womxn In Motion.


Black Womxn In Motion
While we hope this audio drama will provide a sense of joy, connection, and community during this period of isolation, we must also acknowledge that our production was able to exist due to many compounding privileges. This injustices upheld by white supremacy and the ongoing systemic racism which BIPOC still face today, in the theatre community and beyond, must be fought against. 
We would like to encourage everyone to continue focusing their energy on anti-racist actions. Specifically, we'd like to direct your attention to Black Womxn In Motion. BWIM is a Toronto-based, youth-led organization that empowers and supports the advancement of Black womxn and survivors of sexual violence. 30% of our proceeds will be going towards BWIM. We at Panoply are proud to support their cause, and encourage you to do the same. For more information visit their website: https://blackwomeninmotion.org/

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us reach our goal by sharing this campaign!
Follow us on Instagram & Facebook 
Have any questions? Send us an email at admin@panoplycollective.com

Thank you for your support! We are so looking forward to sharing this magical production with you.

story:
Short Summary

  • To put on our show, we are looking for 300$
  • As young creators of independent theatre, we are passionate about bringing this show to it's fully realized potential.
  • Through donations, our show will be able to have the design elements and production value needed to tell our story.

What We Need

  • We are asking for 300$ in order to afford all the structural and design elements that go into creating a professional show for the festival.
  • after a conservative planning for budget, we have determined this is enough to cover the costs of what we plan to do.
  • This money will be used for: constructing costumes, paint, materials for the set, props, puppetry, and special effects .

The Impact

By helping to reach our funding goals, you will be not only helping young theatre artists develop a new show, but as a whole will be supporting the development of new Canadian theatre. Staging "Equinox" is the first step for us towards impacting our culture and community in a positive way by making them think, feel, and question the world around them.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  •  get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • share our indiegogo campaign on social media!
  • encourage your friends to consider donating/coming to watch!

story:
Let's Keep Live Theatre Alive!

Hello, dear friends!

My name is Dan Kostelec, and I’m the guy who plays your friendly, neighbourhood Shakespeare at Renaissance Faires, schools and more all over the country in my one-man, audience-interactive, improvisational Shakespeare show, “Shakespeare Approves!” I take some of the Bard’s plays and turn them into half-hour, live-action, interactive cartoons where the audience members are the actors, props, and scenery.

The COVID-19 crisis has shut down everything, renaissance faires and theaters included - and some of the most vulnerable people in our increasingly-gig-based economy are your favorite performers in theatre and renaissance festivals.

Piggy-backing on the success of the first two shows ("12th Night & the 3 Bears!", "Romeo & Juliet: The Flying Implement of Doom Edition!") performed by our new online theatre company, The Social Distancing Players , we're back for round #3 of online, irreverent, quasi-improvisational, audience-interactive family fun with "Julius Caesar: Beware the Ides of March of the Penguins!"

Actors from theatre companies and some of your favorite Ren Faire acts will be performing a live reading adapted from my stage show that is normally produced at festivals as an audience-interactive, improvisational show.

I'm looking to raise at least $900.00 for this first performance, so that I can guarantee each actor a minimum of $100 (and hopefully more!( for their time in bringing us joy and laughter. And that's where you come in. We need your help to make it happen!

 What We Need & What You Get

We need $900.00. Okay - that part was pretty straight-forward

What do you get?

A part in the show! And also much more!

If you're familiar with my live, in-person ren faire show, you know that I use the audience members as my cast, the set, even as some of the props. So keeping with that tradition, if you are able to donate to this cause, the first 4 people to donate $50 or more will get to be in the show (all roles are first-come, first served). Yeah, it sounds like pay-to-play, because it is. But if you can afford it, I guarantee that you'll have a marvelous time!

Roles Available

  • Calphernia
  • Casca
  • Cinna
  • Julius Caesar

But wait — there’s more!

Let’s say you have some cash but can’t afford to go up to $50. Well, for $30 you can get a copy of the performance script signed by the author (that’s me!).

And if you’re feeling particularly generous and want to donate $100 - well, you get some goodies! You get the signed performance script, a part in the show (if you desire, and if they haven’t been snatched up yet — all roles are first-come, first served), AND a personalized sonnet commissioned JUST FOR YOU (a $20 value).

The Impact

You will directly be helping professional entertainers keep "professional" as part of their job title, by helping us to pay our bills, buy our groceries (when we dare to venture outside during this social distancing period), and not sink deeper into poverty or credit card debt.

You're helping to extend hope and build morale for our fellow members of humanity by giving them a much-needed distraction during this crisis, a sense that a return-to-normal is not just possible but inevitable.

You're keeping live theatre alive.
 

Other Ways You Can Help


Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
Share this campaign with your friends, family, even enemies!

And that's all there is to it.

Thank you. I love you - you love me - there is mutual, glorious affection!

story:
About shut.eye

          ​a dance theater performance symposium on sleep, dreams, and consciousness

Inspired by sleep, dreams, and the subconscious, de novo dance’s shut.eye creates an immersive, multi-media “dreamscape” through movement, music, and interactive technologies.  Accompanied by live and electroacoustic music, the performance features de novo’s extended roster of dancers, musicians, and sleep experts.  Combining experimental belly dance, butoh, performance art, and musical robots, shut.eye creates surreal interpretations of sleep experiences.

Performances:
Friday, April 1  7:30PM
Saturday, April 2  7:30PM
Sunday, April 3 2:30PM matinee
Duration 90 mins. (roughly the time of a complete sleep cycle)

Tickets: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2484771

Venue:  The Secret Theatre
44-02 23rd Street
Long Island City, NY 11101-5000
(718) 392-0722
Directions:  http://www.secrettheatre.com/VisitorInfo1.html

With your Support, We Will: 

·  Rent The Secret Theatre venue for rehearsal and performances

·  Print postcards and programs

·  Purchase costumes, props, and equipment for the performances

·  Arrange for transportation for participating artists from the HANAC Harmony Innovative Senior Center 

About de novo dance

de novo dance was founded in 2012 by Ian Wen (performance artist), Irina Kom (choreographer/dancer), Aurie Hsu (composer/dancer), and Steven Kemper (composer/technologist).  de novo dance creates genre-defiant performances that blur the boundaries between performer and spectator.  shut.eye follows de novo dance’s inaugural project Houseguest, which was performed to sold-out audiences over three performances at the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance in June 2013.  shut.eye is made possible in part by the Queens Council on the Arts with public funds fromthe New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council.  www.denovodance.com

With: Felipe Bastos, Jens Boutrup, Debbie Despina Cartsos, Baptiste Denient, Erin Holmes, Aurie Hsu, Lauren Jeanette, Vincent Katz, Steven Kemper, Bob Lyness, Lauren Marie Robbiani, Darius Stone, Eugenia Tzirtzilaki, Estefania Vaz Ferreira, Ian Wen, Irina Wen, and Jayoung Yoon.  And seniors from the HANAC Harmony Innovative Senior Center in Astoria, Queens.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute financially, you can still help!!  Please:
· Tell your friends about shut.eye
· Share shut.eye announcements via social media
· Join us for shut.eye performances
· Volunteer your time to help on the day of the performance (tickets, seating, etc.)

Is this Donation Tax-Deductible?

Please note that donations made through this platform are not tax-deductible.  However, we are also sponsored by The Field*, who will acknowledge your donation.  If you wish to make a tax-deductible donation, you may do so here: https://www.thefield.org/Profile.aspx?SAID=2916

*The Field is a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions made to The Field and earmarked for (Artist/Company name) are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906, New York NY 10038, www.thefield.org. A copy of The Field’s latest annual report may be obtained, upon request, from The Field or from the Office of the Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
We (Marianne Trenka and Tessa J. Brown) are two Montreal-based performers and producers--we are bringing our latest two-woman show to the Montreal Fringe Festival. We’ll be presenting comedy, circus, dance, burlesque, poetry, and more! We’re both professional artists, and so we’re doing our best to recoup the costs of our Fringe registration fees and the other costs incurred by producing a show. By funding our campaign, you’re helping two starving artists starve a little less!

For your contribution, we’ll be offering a variety of perks—if you donate $25, you get a free ticket to our Fringe show, and if you donate $40, you get two! Additionally, for donations of $10, Tessa (a published poet) will write you a poem on a subject of your choosing. 

We would love to reach our goal of $500, but if we don’t, the funds we do raise will go towards the costs of producing this show. Any amount is incredibly helpful, and we’re so grateful to anybody who’s willing to contribute even a little bit. Producing these shows is a real passion project for both of us—all of our shows are aimed at showcasing the talents of women and gender non-conforming people, and our two-woman show is no different. Great Scott Media called it “a whimsical, funny, incisive romp through the absurdities of socially imposed femininity.”

Even if you can’t contribute, please consider sharing our campaign with your friends, and don’t forget to come out to the show—we can’t wait to see you, and thank you for all of your help!

story:
Medicine the Musical

This production has a budget of $65,000 and is part of the SubletSeries@HERE: a curated rental program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical support. The show will will run for 14 shows Nov. 3-18, 2018. Tickets are on sale at: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/993113

Set to a dynamic rock score, Medicine the Musical follows a group of first year medical students as they struggle with their lives, loves, and the rigors of their education. It is a unique platform with which to share with the public something about the world of medicine, including the pressures and frustrations felt by doctors and medical students.

What started as the seed of an idea while I was in medical school has now matured into a full-fledged musical production. Following on a successful staged concert reading in April 2017 (see the video), we are now determined to bring this show to a New York off-Broadway production.  

This is your chance to support the arts in a meaningful way and bring this exciting project to the stage. See the show, meet the cast, attend the opening night party, and receive lots of cool theater swag.

The full video from the staged reading is above, and here are links to individual songs.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

Risks & Challenges

Producing a first-class show is like starting a small business. We need to do everything--book a theater, audition cast, create scenery, choreography, marketing, and more. Sure, we can stumble somewhere along the way, but we will get the show up. The nature of the final production will depend on the amount of funding raised.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help get the word out.

  • Post on your social media
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

See you all on Opening Night

story:
Short Summary

Artistic Director, Erika ‘RED’ Stowall recently began a journey to create work in Michigan. As she began presented her works, she decided she wanted to have a sole group of dancers and started building a repertoire. Later, Big Red Wall Dance Company was founded.  Big Red Wall Dance Company (BRW) is having amazing success in the Michigan. 

Now, the company has been accepted into the Ruby Slippers Fringe festival. We are ecstatic to be traveling to North Carolina. This year has rewarded us with the ability to travel outside of the state; however we are still a growing organization.  The company is reaching out to you to assist with traveling and lodging expense.

BRW will be taking an excerpt from their 1 length performance ‘Why It Gotta Be Black.’ WIGBB premiered in September 2014. The work depicts the stereotypes of African American Women as seen in the media.  Work expresses the frustration of labeling and misrepresentation of African American. BRW mission is to create movement that speaks to the needs of the area. Building community through collaboration with local artists and changing the stigma of the City.   

Your contribution will help with us completing our first traveling performance. There are many factors into making a production of this size successful as well as continual support of artists in the city.  We have been blessed to have certain services offered to us as generous donations; however we still need your support with: 


What We Need & What You Get

BRW is traveling to North Carolina for the Ruby Slippers Fringe Festival and needs your help. We need assistance with travel, lodging and performance fees.  

Traveling expenses: $500

Lodging: $150

Dancer fees: $400

Meals: $150


The Impact

BRW is a growing dance company located in the city of Detroit. The recent work that we are taking to NC, speak on the media presentation of African American and their bias. This company main mission is keeping Detroit artist working. BRW hopes to create works that empowers the city of Detroit.  

Using crowdfunding campaign's, BRW has had many successfully productions in Detroit. Now, the company would like to travel  and show the world how talent the city is. It is a great honor for the company to be invited to North Carolina and with your help, we will be able to achieve this. 

With your continual support, Big Red Wall is happy to have many years of success in Michigan. Working with amazing local artist, the company would like to take their work and show the many layers of Detroit. Traveling out and displaying the talent of the city is the most important thing to Big Red Wall. 

Risks & Challenges

Big Red Wall has had many successful productions and performance in the last year. However, traveling out of the state with performers and props can become quite costly. As well as running a small company with limited resources. The company needs your support to accomplishment this task without exhausting funds. Artistic Director, Erika Stowall, would like to make this trip as effortless as possible for her dancers. The dancers are brilliant amazing artist, that sacrifice their bodies for the arts. With limited funding and paid gigs, the dancers many rehearse or perform with little to no payment.  With your support, the company will be able to reward these performers for their hard work and effort. 


Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to help with this project.  We also have started a survey on Loops Survey http://m.loopsurvey.com/RyKQ7vwfYV . Please take the time to answer the questions or share with others.  The information we receive will go into the creative process.  

Even if you are unable to donate please spread the word about the Indiegogo campaign.

Big Red Wall Dance Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Big Red Wall Dance Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Traveling out and displaying the talent of the city is the most important thing to Big Red Wall. 
Risks & Challenges
Big Red Wall has had many successful productions and performance in the last year. However, traveling out of the state with performers and props can become quite costly. As well as running a small company with limited resources. The company needs your support to accomplishment this task without exhausting funds. Artistic Director, Erika Stowall, would like to make this trip as effortless as possible for her dancers. The dancers are brilliant amazing artist, that sacrifice their bodies for the arts. With limited funding and paid gigs, the dancers many rehearse or perform with little to no payment.  With your support, the company will be able to reward these performers for their hard work and effort. 


    Other Ways You Can Help 
There are many ways to help with this
project.  We also have started a survey
on Loops Survey http://m.loopsurvey.com/RyKQ7vwfYV
. Please take the time to answer the questions or share with others.  The information we receive will go into the
creative process.  
Even if you are unable to donate please spread the word about the
Indiegogo campaign.

Big Red Wall Dance Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Big Red Wall Dance Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
We have exciting news!

"Cenicienta: A Bilingual Cinderella Story" has been invited to New York City's Association of Performing Arts Professionals Conference (APAP) in January 2020. This event is an opportunity to perform the show for the gatekeepers of the country's biggest performing arts centers.  Since it's debut, "Cenicienta" has toured schools across Central Texas reaching more than 10,000 young people! Our little show is ready for a national tour  which is why we're asking you to be the fairy godmother in Cenicienta's story. Your donation will help build a platform that inspires youth to “Be the person you’ve waited for all your life, and never give up.” -reflections from a young audience member after a performance at Sin Fronteras Festival.

The Creators

"Cenicienta: A Bilingual Cinderella Story" is a Theatre-For-All play created in 2015 in collaboration with Teatro Vivo, Glass Half Full Theatre, and Zach Theater.  Commissioned by Nat Miller, co-written by Caroline Reck and Rupert Reyes, composed by Ammon Taylor, the character of Belinda is performed by Gricelda Silva. The original show won awards for Outstanding Puppetry, Best Actress, Original Score (B. Iden Payne Awards 2015) and Best New Play (Austin Critics Table 2015). It has been touring Central Texas since 2017 and added a second touring show in 2019 starring Madison Palomo as Belinda.

 

A Cinderella Story of a Cinderella Story...

Cenicienta features Belinda, a 10-year-old who has been sent to the basement to prepare the party that her stepmother and stepsisters host for (real life) writer Gary Soto. A budding poet herself, Belinda wants desperately to attend the party and share her own writings with Soto.  It’s a story within a story; Belinda lives out her version while also reenacting the classic tale, using whatever objects are at her disposal: napkins, teapots, and doilies, to name just a few. Through a love of poetry passed down by her father, she learns to stand up for herself and take charge of her life and dreams.

Just like the story of Cinderella, we need help getting to the big event.

Here are the costs we are up against:

Plane Tickets for 5 people:  $1245

Conference Booth: $975

Airbnb for 5 nights, NYC: $850

Baggage/Shipping: $250

Conference & Event Fees:  $1300

Showcase Fees: $1500

Promotional Materials: $450

Why is my donation important?

We believe in the universal experience of imaginary friends, of hopes and dreams, in the magic of risking everything to achieve a better future. With such high financial barriers to attend this conference, it's no wonder why many major PAC offerings lack representation from independent voices. We are committed to expanding this opportunity for Latinx youth to see and hear actors who look and sound like them on stage. If we can reach our goal, your generosity will resonate across the country like the roar of laughter from an auditorium full of kids feeling empathy for a folded napkin.

How else can I support?

Have you had a chance to see the show in person? Tell your friends about the experience!
If you haven't, check out the links below to find out more about the show's impact.
Sharing this campaign amplifies our mission, and gets us closer to the goal! 


SHARE with friends who think critically!
“If you've ever had the fleeting wish that Disney's Cinderella wasn't so dated and unreal, here's your remedy.“ 
-CTX Live Theatre

SHARE with parents of kids who love to read!

It teaches lessons in the importance of reading and writing...
-The Austin American Statesman

SHARE with your bilingual community! 

"...Belinda... speaks both English and Spanish throughout the play, intertwining both languages together in a way that is easy to understand..."
-Do512 Family

SHARE with anyone who needs a good dose of imagination!

"...Their eyes get brighter. Their focus is intense, different from the glazed look children get when they are watching digital content. They are watching and listening, piecing together the story."
-Alt Ed Austin

story:
What we are doing

When you hear Flint Michigan, what do you think? Lately, it has been poverty, violence, and bad water, but there is so much more to The Vehicle City. The people of Flint have a long history of fighting, surviving and winning. Flint is overcoming its current challenges just as Flint folk of an earlier generation overcame the world’s largest corporation to acquire safe working conditions, a better standard of living for their families and financial security to generations of American workers. 

We are a company of students and faculty from Alma College in Alma, Michigan and we are creating our devised theatre piece to share one of the great stories of our state with the international arts community at the world’s largest arts festival in the Summer of 2019.  The Edinburgh Fringe provides us a great opportunity, but not for free.

What We Need & What You Get

While we have raised some funds through local events and donations, and committed a fair amount of our own money, we are a long way from our goal. We need your help to get over the finish line.  Your support will be used for registration fees, space rental accommodations, as well as production and travel costs.  For Example

Airfare to Edinburgh $6400

Lodging and Venue Rental – $18,000

Meals – $8000

Incidentals – $2000

Production Cost - $4000

We want you to know that we appreciate your help, so we have developed a set of perks that we want to share with you if you donate at various levels.  You could receive a social media shout out, a digital thank you note, a show poster signed by the company, or a 44 Days T-Shirt.

Other Ways You Can Help

The 44 Days Company understands that not all of our supporters can make a financial contribution, but we would appreciate any help you can give.  Maybe you could

  • Share this page with your friends and family!
  • Come and see the show during a preview performance in Alma and bring everyone you know!
  • If you happen to be at the Fringe while we are there, come and see the show

Cast

WILLIAM "JOE" HARRISON

I am from Belding Michigan, I am a senior at Alma College pursuing a degree in New Media Studies and a second major in Theatre. I have been part of Alma College Theatre since my freshman year both as an actor (Our Town, The Laramie Project, The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee, Northanger Abbey)  as a technician (Rumors, Dracula, Soldier’s Heart). Outside of Alma College, I have worked with Unto These Hills Outdoor Drama (Cherokee, NC), and Blessed Unrest (New York, NY). Outside of theatre, I have worked as a production assistant on the short film Base Camp, and as an assistant editor for The Show About The Show, and Mutable Films. 

 

CASSIDY SANFORD

I’m from Caledonia Michigan and I am a senior at Alma College. Though I am primarily a technician, I am intrigued by the idea of stepping out of my comfort zone into the world of acting for this production. Some of my past productions include being Master Electrician and/or Sound Engineer on Eurydice, Much Ado About Nothing, Northanger Abbey, Soldier's Heart, and Dracula. I am grateful for the opportunity to share the story of the Flint Sit Down Strike and to gain more experience and knowledge about devised theatre and is happy to be able to share the fruits of mine and my fellow performers hard work.  

 

DANIEL CHALICE

I am a junior at Alma with double majors in theatre and marketing. I grew up in the small town of Saugatuck, Michigan and discovered he had a gift for the stage in my sophomore year of high school.  At Alma, I have been involved in several shows with my favorite role being Benedick in Much Ado About Nothing. I stay physically active during the day with exercise and slow down in the evenings playing video games with his friends. Upon graduation, I plan to Chicago, New York, or Los Angeles to pursue a career in the arts. 

 

ELIZABETH PECHOTA

I am a Psychology and Theatre major at Alma College. I am a native Michigander, born and raised in the small town of Cadillac Michigan. I have participated in theatre for seven years being involved with over 20 productions. The history of my home state has always fascinated her.  

 

GRACIE LLOYD

I am from Alma, Michigan and I’m a 19-year-old freshman at Alma College. I plan to double major in Theatre and New Media Studies. Theatre wise my main focus is acting. My interest in acting began when I was just nine years old with the Gratiot County Players, a community theatre company in downtown Alma. I have done six productions so far with GCP. I also participated in three shows with Alma High School and so far in my Alma College career I have two shows under my belt. I also love to sing and have been in multiple musicals. Being on stage is my passion and I hope to someday pursue acting as my career.

story:
The Project

Hi There!

We are producers, directors, actors, designers, technicians and artists from the Ryerson School of Performance. We are students, on the cusp of graduation, using or final months before “real life” to collaborate on a fully realized theatrical production. We are joining forces to bring to life one of the most beautiful plays of our time.

Eurydice, written by Sarah Ruhl, is a modern theatrical adaptation of the ancient Greek tragedy of Orpheus and Eurydice. Unlike the Greek version, which follows Orpheus’ story, this play highlights the character of Eurydice and explores her journey through life and the Underworld. Eurydice analyzes all the forms love and loss can take in a witty, absurd and poignant manner.

Where: The Ryerson Theatre, Toronto ON.

When: April 10th, 2017, 8pm

Where Will the Money Go?

Our campaign goal is $1000. This amount will go specifically to:

  • Props for the Show
  • Paint for the Set
  • Equipment Rentals & Repairs

If we are unable to reach our goal, we will divide the donations we receive between the props and paints departments. If, better yet, we go above our goal, all additional funds will be put into construction materials for the set and costumes.

Perks

As a small incentive to donate, we have some fun perks to offer!  Some of these include, a high-five from the director, a poster signed by the cast, a personalized thank-you letter from a character from the show and more!

The Impact

There is a stigma surrounding student theatre that it is not at the same caliber as professional work. We believe, given the resources, we can create something beautiful that will uphold the same standard as a professional theatre company. Please help us set the record straight.

With your help, we will be putting this story on its feet. By contributing, you are allowing the designers and director to realize their vision to its fullest potential. You will be helping us create a platform with which to launch ourselves into the industry. You will be helping us conclude our education with a piece of work we can be proud of.

A huge challenge of independently producing theatre as students is finding ways to raise finances for our work. We not only want to get our project up and running, but we want to help future students as well. That is why, any additional profit we make from ticket sales will go into a pot that will be given to the next group of students from our school, who wish to independently produce a show.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to donate. However, you can still contribute by:

  • Sharing our campaign on Social Media
  • Talking about our show to your Friends and Family
  • Following our journey on Facebook and Instagram (Social Media will launch early March, #findingeurydice)
  • Buying Tickets and coming to see our show!

story:
Footlights aims to give its entire cast and crew as professional an experience as possible while providing an accessible and affordable performance for the student body as well as the Edinburgh community at large. Each academic year, the society sets out to produce a musical of only the highest quality. In recent years, the society has continued to achieve striking levels of professionalism throughout all levels of these productions, reflected in hugely successful productions of hit musicals including 'Anything Goes', 'Fame', 'A Chorus Line', 'West Side Story', 'In The Heights', 'Rent', and most recently our 2016 show, 'Guys and Dolls'.

EU Footlights is proud to announce its 2017 show, Urinetown. Urinetown is a satirical comedy musical that premiered in 2001, with music by Mark Hollmann and lyrics by Hollmann and Greg Kotis. It satirizes the legal system, capitalism, social irresponsibility, populism, bureaucracy, corporate mismanagement, and municipal politics all through song and dance, and gives huge amounts of comedy along the way!

 

Why are we crowdfunding?

Every year the cast, crew and committee put in a huge amount of effort fundraising, hosting events, doing bakesales and singing Christmas Carols all over Edinburgh. Putting on a large scale production means paying for a venue, costumes, set and making sure everyone is heard and lit up! The money we raise here will be going directly towards the cost of the production and making sure that we continue to wow audiences across the city.

We hugely appreciate the help that friends, family and theatre lovers offer and whether you can donate or not we look forwards to seeing you in February at the show!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're interested in supporting us as a business we also have a wide range of sponsorship options available and would love to chat to you. You can get in touch with us at sponsorship@edfootlights.com

story:
Katrina Grogan-Kalnuk, Zoë Kenneally, Rachel Markun, and Sarah McLennan are all graduating dance artists in Toronto. For the past seven months these four dancers have been deep in the creative process, collaborating with fellow artists and production students in order to make full length creations.

With your help, these artists will be able to reach the scope of their creative vision, including design and production elements, such as set and costume. Any contribution increases the potential for fulfilling their creative dreams.

The money raised will go directly to the design and purchase of different set elements; from galactic make up, hundreds of news papers, to a life size box on stage. 

Another way to support these artists is to attend a fundraising event at Eden Hall on March 2, 2017. Please follow link below if interested:

https://www.facebook.com/events/772632459555114/

story:
Greetings friends, supporters, comrades, co-conspirators, strangers and curious alike. Here's a friendly plea from within the art-making trenches dug from a desolate fund raising landscape. 

Please help David Neumann/Advanced Beginner Group make it to their New York premiere! 

Please support our process and help our extraordinary collaborative team realize this important work. 

What's the project and who's involved?

I Understand Everything Better is a multi-disciplinary performance piece conceived and directed by David Neumann with a stellar team of collaborators fast approaching two premieres!

Collaborators include:
Tei Blow: Sound design, Music Direction
Sibyl Kempson: Text
Chloe Brown: Lights
Mimi Lien: Set
Christine Shallenberg: Projections
Erica Sweany: Costumes

and performers Tei Blow, John Gasper, Karen Kandel, Jennifer Kidwell, David Neumann

with additional important help from: Eben Hoffer, Merrick Williams, Meredith Boggia, and Amanda Brandes

I Understand Everything Better came out of a life-changing experience most people eventually must go through. David's parents died on either side of Hurricane Sandy. His mother, suddenly in the summer. His father had a longer journey and died a few weeks after the storm made landfall. Neumann started this work nearly a year later. I Understand Everything Better is both fiction and truth, riding the fine line between the purely presentational and the deeply personal (to quote our collaborator, Sibyl Kempson).

The work is an attempt to articulate the many layers of that experience and maybe even the consciousness of dying itself (and with that, those taking care of the dying).  Using structural elements of the Japanese Noh Theater as a container for these ideas, I Understand Everything Better shares some formal elements with the Nohgaku and above all a belief that there's great value in engaging the imagination when exploring the more mysterious  parts of our experience.

“Mr. Neumann proves once again to be an astute, sensitive observer of the human condition in all its funny and desperate and, finally, beautiful frailty.” – The New York Times

I Understand Everything Better is commissioned by American Dance Institute (World Premiere March 27–28) and the Chocolate Factory Theater and Abrons Arts Center (New York Premiere at Abrons Arts Center April 15–25). 

What we need & what you get!

After nearly two years in development at residencies all over the U.S. and abroad, I Understand Everything Better is in the homestretch. We need to raise just $6,000 to make it to our April New York City premiere! Funds will go toward materials for the production, as well as payment of our amazing team. 

We can do it, but we need your help!

Your gift of any size earns you our immense gratitude for your support of the arts!

  • For a donation of $25 or more, we will give you a shout out on Facebook and on our website www.advancedbeginnergroup.org
  • For a donation of $50 or more, you get the perks above, plus a production photo signed by the cast and creative team.
  • For a donation of $100 or more, you get the perks above, plus a limited edition album containing music from the show.
  • For a donation of $250 or more, you get the perks above, plus two tickets to a performance of I Understand Everything Better at Abrons Arts Center.
  • For a donation of $500 or more, you get the perks above, plus drinks with the cast post show.

Other ways you can help.

In addition to making a gift, please help us spread the word about this campaign and about our performances at Abrons Arts Center using Indiegogo's share tools, the online tool of your choice, or, you know, a megaphone!

Don't forget to like our Facebook page for more updates!

THANK YOU in advance for your support!

photo credit: Maria Baranova

*****

About David Neumann / Advanced Beginner Group

Advanced Beginner Group is a collection of artists across many disciplines and approaches that, under the direction of David Neumann, come together for specific projects. We make work that is at its core an irrational response to our perceived place in the universe. We make our pieces from scratch, bringing to word, action and proximity a delighted embrace of our contradictory lives. Words and actions can only point to experience. We actively attempt to create experiences that are difficult to describe. 

David Neumann is the artistic director of Advanced Beginner Group. His work has been presented in New York City at P.S. 122, New York Live Arts, The Whitney, MAD, Danspace, and The Kitchen,  among others. Neumann performed in the works of Susan Marshall, Jane Comfort, Sally Silvers, Doug Varone, Annie­-B Parson & Paul Lazar’s Big Dance Theatre, and club legend Willi Ninja. He was also an original member of the Doug Elkins Dance Company. He has worked with directors Hal Hartley, Jonathan Demme,  Laurie Anderson, Robert Woodruff, Lee Breuer, JoAnne Akalaitis, and Sarah Benson in a range of works for the stage; more recently he choreographed An Octoroon at Soho Rep, and directed The Object Lesson at BAM this fall. Neumann is on faculty at Sarah Lawrence College and is an independent director and choreographer based in NY.
story_txt:
Greetings friends, supporters, comrades, co-conspirators, strangers and curious alike. Here's a friendly plea from within the art-making trenches dug from a desolate fund raising landscape. 
Please help David Neumann/Advanced Beginner Group make it to their New York premiere! 
Please support our process and help our extraordinary collaborative team realize this important work. 
What's the project and who's involved?
 

I Understand Everything Better is a multi-disciplinary performance piece conceived and directed by David Neumann with a stellar team of collaborators fast approaching two premieres!

Collaborators include:Tei Blow: Sound design, Music DirectionSibyl Kempson: TextChloe Brown: LightsMimi Lien: SetChristine Shallenberg: ProjectionsErica Sweany: Costumes
and performers Tei Blow, John Gasper, Karen Kandel, Jennifer Kidwell, David Neumann
with additional important help from: Eben Hoffer, Merrick Williams, Meredith Boggia, and Amanda Brandes

I Understand Everything Better came out of a life-changing experience most people eventually must go through. David's parents died on either side of Hurricane Sandy. His mother, suddenly in the summer. His father had a longer journey and died a few weeks after the storm made landfall. Neumann started this work nearly a year later. I Understand Everything Better is both fiction and truth, riding the fine line between the purely presentational and the deeply personal (to quote our collaborator, Sibyl Kempson).
The work is an attempt to articulate the many layers of that experience and maybe even the consciousness of dying itself (and with that, those taking care of the dying).  Using structural elements of the Japanese Noh Theater as a container for these ideas, I Understand Everything Better shares some formal elements with the Nohgaku and above all a belief that there's great value in engaging the imagination when exploring the more mysterious  parts of our experience.

“Mr. Neumann proves once again to be an astute, sensitive observer of the human condition in all its funny and desperate and, finally, beautiful frailty.” – The New York Times
I Understand Everything Better is commissioned by American Dance Institute (World Premiere March 27–28) and the Chocolate Factory Theater and Abrons Arts Center (New York Premiere at Abrons Arts Center April 15–25). 

What we need & what you get!

 After nearly two years in development at residencies all over the U.S. and abroad, I Understand Everything Better is in the homestretch. We need to raise just $6,000 to make it to our April New York City premiere! Funds will go toward materials for the production, as well as payment of our amazing team. 
We can do it, but we need your help!
Your gift of any size earns you our immense gratitude for your support of the arts! 
For a donation of $25 or more, we will give you a shout out on Facebook and on our website www.advancedbeginnergroup.org
 For a donation of $50 or more, you get the perks above, plus a production photo signed by the cast and creative team. For a donation of $100 or more, you get the perks above, plus a limited edition album containing music from the show. For a donation of $250 or more, you get the perks above, plus two tickets to a performance of I Understand Everything Better at Abrons Arts Center.
For a donation of $500 or more, you get the perks above, plus drinks with the cast post show.
   
Other ways you can help.

 In addition to making a gift, please help us spread the word about this campaign and about our performances at Abrons Arts Center using Indiegogo's share tools, the online tool of your choice, or, you know, a megaphone!
Don't forget to like our Facebook page for more updates!
THANK YOU in advance for your support!
photo credit: Maria Baranova
*****

story:
Who We Are

SFBATCO - Executive Producer///We are SF natives who grew up studying and performing theatre with groups such as SFArtsEd, Ruth Asawa School of the Arts, and Rec and Park's YPTMTC. We want to perform and work professionally in theater in the Bay Area and we are taking action to create those opportunities for ourselves and for other Bay Area performers. See more @ sfbatco.org!

 4th Walrus - Co-Producer///We are a collective of theater artists from Stanford bringing new musical theater to millennials and larger Bay Area audiences. We are dedicated to providing high quality, professional musical performance and production opportunities to college students and recent graduates interested in a career in theater and the arts. See more @ 4thwalrus.com!

Our Project 

We are raising funds to put on a re-imagined minimalist production of Sweeney Todd at the Exit Theater July 16-25th, 2015. We will be creating one of Sondheim's most celebrated masterpieces in an intimate theater space.  Your donation will help us realize this vision! 


Sweeney Todd is presented through special arrangement with Music Theatre International (MTI) and SF Opera.

Buy your tickets at sfbatco.brownpapertickets.com today!

Why We Need YOU!

Creating theatre in SF is expensive. You think renting an apartment is hella expensive here? Try renting a theater. On top of that we need money for rights, costumes, sets, fake blood, rehearsal spaces, and paying our artists.

To thank you for your generous donations, we have fun perks such as Singing Sweeney Telegrams, Signed Posters and Exclusive Behind-the-Scenes Videos of the creative process. 

Here is an estimate of how we will distribute our budget:



The Impact

You can trust us to take your dollars and turn them into magical theatrical experiences. The 4th Walrus team has been involved in directing, producing, and performing in numerous successful Stanford shows including The Last Five Years, Hairspray, My Fair Lady at Bing Concert Hall, and Sunday in the Park with George. SFBATCO as a company has already produced 4 shows: It's Not Easy Being Green, Fake Your Way to the Top, The Distance We've Come: A Tribute to Danny Duncan, and Home for "all of" the Holidays. We know how to stretch each dollar into a high quality performance, so give us your money or we'll have to kill people to use as sets*. "Times is hard." - Mrs. Lovett

*This is a reference to the plot of Sweeney Todd, not our actual fall-back plan. 

Risks & Challenges

It's hard to produce theatre. Well established theatre companies are struggling to secure funding every year. Yet in the face of all this, we want to earn your donation by showing you the great theatre we can make. We believe in our mission to create professional theatre in the Bay Area, where many of us were born and raised and taught to love theatre. We believe that if we fight to stay and create theatre here, we can make the Bay Area a thriving capitol for theatre professionals and theatre lovers alike. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Post to facebook or twitter, tell your friends, tell your parents, tell your barber! If you weren't convinced to donate by this indiegogo (which, c'mon you really should be), come to our show July 16-25th at the Exit Theater and be convinced to donate to our company so we can put on our next show!!!


THE TEAM:

Executive Director/Co-Founder of SFBATCO/Production Manager- Marcelo Pereira///Marcelo has helped produce two off-Broadway shows, The Black Book by Phil Blechman and Rogerandtom by Julien Schwab. Recent acting credits include Skippyjon Jones (TheaterworksUSA), Rent(Syracuse Stage), A New Brain (SU Drama), and A Midsummer Night’s Dream (Bathwater Productions). Directing credits include Celebrate 12th Night Joyfully with Kathryn Crosby (NYPL at Lincoln Center) The Complete History of America [Abridged] (Black Box Players) and Too Many Tamales (Marsh Youth Theater). 

Artistic Director/Co-Founder of SFBATCO-Rodney Earl Jackson Jr.///

Rodney is a proud San Francisco native having grown up in the Lower Haight/Hayes Valley community. He began his performing career at a young age as a San Francisco Arts Education Player. Upon his acceptance to the Ruth Asawa School of the Arts with an emphasis in Theatre, he joined Park and Rec.’s Young People’s Musical theatre Company. He has been apart of numerous art organizations in the Bay Area including The New Conservatory Theatre, Broadway by the Bay, Woodminster Theater, The African-American Shakespeare Company, and Bathwater Productions; as well as an incredible youth organization, Broadway Dreams which connects broadway artists with local youth around the country passionate about their craft. He made his Broadway debut in The Book of Mormon directly after graduating from Carnegie Mellon's School of Drama. He is now singing "My Girl" and occasionally portraying the iconic Marvin Gaye in the first National Tour of Motown: The Musical. Rodney is so grateful to the community that helped shape him into the artist he is today, his personal mission is to make theatre accessible to everyone in the SF Bay Area.

Artistic Director/Co-Founder of 4th Walrus Productions/Director - Ken Savage///Ken Savage is a Bay Area theater director and graduate of Stanford University (B.A. Drama ‘14 and M.A. Communication ‘15) and San Francisco University High School '10. Directing credits include: Sunday in the Park with George, Company, The Fantasticks, The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee, The Last Five Years, and an Asian re-imagination of the classic Broadway musical My Fair Lady which was the inaugural musical in Stanford’s Bing Concert Hall. Recently, this spring Ken directed the blockbuster hit Hairspray in Stanford's 1600-seat Memorial Auditorium breaking box office records selling over 6,000 tickets over 5 performances. Professionally he has worked at Arena Stage, The Public Theater, Theatreworks Silicon Valley, and American Conservatory Theater (A.C.T.). He is currently directing a production of My Fair Lady at Broadway By the Bay which opens in June at the Fox Theater in Redwood City.

Music Director/Co-Founder of 4th Walrus Productions/Musical & Vocal Director - Joel Chapman///Joel Chapman is a conductor and bass-baritone in the Bay Area. He has sung with and conducted Convivium, a new chamber choir, the Stanford Chamber Chorale, and Fleet Street, a male comedy a cappella group. Additionally, he has made appearances with the California Bach Society and Volti, a chamber choir specializing in new music. Recent theatrical credits include The Last Five Years (music director), Sunday in the Park with George (music director), Company (music director), The Fantasticks (El Gallo), My Fair Lady (music director), and [Title of Show] (music director). Joel is a graduate of Stanford University, where he received his B.A. in Music with emphases in vocal performance and conducting and studied with Gregory Wait, Laura Dahl, and Stephen Sano. At Stanford, Joel was a recipient of the Carolyn Applebaum Memorial Prize for his work as a conductor in bringing over fifty students together for his senior recital. He also received the Stanford Chamber Chorale Director’s Choice Award for his leadership and dedication to the group. Joel later received his M.A. in Music, Science, and Technology from Stanford at the Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics (CCRMA), where he studied digital signal processing, recording technologies, and specialized in sound design.

Executive Director/Co-Founder of 4th Walrus/Stage Manager - Sophie Burke///Sophie Burke is a graduate from Stanford University (B.A. Science, Technology, and Society ‘14) pursuing stage management in the Bay Area. Recent Stanford production credits include: The Last Five Years (Stage Manager), Chocolate Heads Movement Band present Good Water (Production Manager & SM), Sunday in the Park with George (SM & Props Manager), Company (SM & Sound Designer), The Fantasticks (SM), and My Fair Lady (Production Manager & SM). She has interned in the TheatreWorks Silicon Valley Artistic/New Works Department and volunteered as an Assistant Stage Manager and Producer for Peninsula Youth Theater. She is currently Assistant Stage Managing My Fair Lady at Broadway By the Bay.
