story:
Support Adam Barruch Dance and the development of a new dance theater production of Sweeney Todd!

Check out our gallery for more videos!!!

About Adam Barruch...

Adam Barruch is a New York based choreogrpaher who began his career as a young actor, performing professionally on Broadway and in film and television, working with prominent figures such as Tony Bennett, Jerry Herman and Susan Stroman. He later received dance training at LaGuardia High School for Music & Art and Performing Arts. After three years, he graduated early and was accepted into the dance department at The Juilliard School. Adam’s work has been presented at venues around the world such as Dance Theater Workshop, City Center, NYU/ Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, Joe's Pub, The Juilliard School, The Baryshnikov Arts Center, Ailey-Citigroup Theater, The 92Y: Buttenweiser Hall, Jacob’s Pillow: Inside/Out, LaMaMa,The Cedar Lake Theater, The Harris and Auditorium Theaters in Chicago, The Yard on Martha’s Vineyard, Bates Dance Festival and Theatre Usine C in Montreal. He has also created works for companies such as Ailey II, River North Dance Chicago, Keigwin and Company and BalletX, as well as for dance icons Margie Gillis and Miki Orihara. Adam was the recipient of a 2014 Lotos Foundation Prize in the Arts and Sciences, which recognizes institutions and individuals for distinguished accomplishments and exceptional talent in the arts and sciences.     View Adam Barruch's Website


DANCEworks Santa Barbara: 'Sweeney' begins...

Led by Artistic Director, Dianne Vapnek, DANCEworks is an annual choreographic residency that partners with The Lobero Theatre in Santa Barbara, California. This residency provides artists with 40 hours a week in the theatre to explore their creative ideas and to make new work. The only requirement is that the work/exploration be shared with Santa Barbara audiences at the conclusion of their residency.

In September, Adam Barruch Dance will be the DANCEworks company-in-residence at the Lobero Theatre. During this time, Adam Barruch and six performers from New York will explore a new dance theater production of Stephen Sondheim's masterpiece, Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street. During the process, which will be mentored by acclaimed choreographer and dancer, Margie Gillis, the company will work with the score to create a new interpretation of this classic work, emphasizing the role in which the body is used to portray both character and narrative. The intent of this research is to incorporate elements of contemporary dance, mime, puppetry and visual design into the musical to enhance the audience's experience of Sondheim's rich and complex score. The goal of the four week process is to begin adapting the material and create a new paradigm that can be used to stage a full scaled production in the future.     Learn more about DANCEworks


We Need Your Support! 

In order to facilitate this journey in September, we are in need of your support. We are looking to raise $8,000 which will help with expenses including: 

  • Artists' Fees: We have six multi-faceted performers coming to Santa Barbara from New York. 
  • Costume Design: For this project we will be collaborating with designer Marine Penvern to create original costume pieces for the performers. Your support will help with costs for design concepts, fabric and materials, and costume construction.
  • Travel Costs: Your support will help provide each artist with airfare from New York to Santa Barbara.
  • Preparatory Musical Rehearsals: It is essential that the artists-in-residence have time to prepare vocally and familiarize themselves with Sondheim’s complex score before September. Your support will help fund space rentals, and fees for our musical director in New York. 


Artists-in-Residence

Chelsea Bonosky 

Tim Heck

Jodi McFadden

Zach McNally

Haylee Nichele 

Lily Ockwell

William Dixon Popp 

...and guest artist Margie Gillis


From Adam Barruch...

“As one’s creative life pushes forward, there are always seeds of ideas that remain in the back of the mind. In some ways, they appear as complete works, just waiting to be actualized. As time passes they often sit there steeping, and because of certain limitations–lack of time, energy, or space–they cannot become a reality. I think the greatest gift, and perhaps greatest challenge, is when circumstances align and that passion project can finally come onto the drafting table. Dianne Vapnek and Santa Barbara DANCEworks has given me the chance to catalyze this process, and delve deeper into my craft then I have ever been before. I am extremely honored and incredibly excited for the 2015 DANCEworks Residency, and hope that you can join us and support the beginning of an amazing journey."

Haylee Nichele 
Lily Ockwell
William Dixon Popp 
...and guest artist Margie Gillis

I am extremely honored and incredibly excited for the 2015 DANCEworks Residency, and hope that you can join us and support the beginning of an amazing journey."

story:
This campaign is raising funds on behalf of Matter Dance Company, a verified nonprofit. The campaign does not necessarily reflect the views of the nonprofit or have any formal association with it. All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose.

Matter Dance Company is proud to present our 9th Annual Summer Concert, Unlocked.

Matter Dance strives to present performances that will excite and thrill their audiences. We are not your average dance company - We create pieces for the audiences. We want to make sure that every patron has a unique, interactive and outside of the box experience. 

Our 2015 show will take all of the concepts MDC has become known for and smush them all into one unbelievable show. 

But we can't do it alone.... We need YOUR help!

Did you know putting up a show is EXPENSIVE?  Holy Cow! There are a lot of costs! 

Here is how you can help us:

Donate - $15 to pay for water for the dancers backstage

Donate - $50 to pay for shoes for one of our dancers

Donate - $150 to pay for costumes for an entire piece. 

Donate - $500 to pay for our Lighting Designer

Donate - $2500 Pays for our theater for one week

Help us put on the best show we can. We want to make you smile!

story:
The Show

Fox vs Kingdom is a new theater production, an ancient beast epic, based on the darkly funny escapades of Reynard the Fox. As told by a trio of French troubadours using puppetry, dance and live music, animal appetites dominate in this retelling of a medieval blockbuster. 

Veering from sweet folk song to operatic satire to salacious tango, we flip through the playbook of puppetry: shadows, crankies, rod puppets, hand puppets, masks. By turns raucous entertainment, gorgeous shadow play, masked dance, this original performance, produced by Studio Reynard, will be launching in October.

  • Premiere:  October 28 - 30, 2016 in Woodstock, NY
  • If you're ready to plan ahead: TICKETS ARE ON SALE
  • If you want to be part of making this all happen - please see the Perks at right! Your name as a backer will be listed, with love, on our website and in the program!


It goes something like this: Reynard dupes everyone, devours a few, sweet talks his way out of trouble, and side-steps a sure death by hanging. In the process, he blithely exposes hypocrisy, corruption, greed, lechery, and gluttony, including his own. 

The story of Reynard was wildly popular eight centuries ago: the witty outlaw who triumphs over entrenched power through sheer rhetoric had resonance in a violent feudal society with nascent rule of law. We believe it has resonance today: Reynard is a trickster, who muddies the waters between right and wrong, between what we say we want and what we actually do. 

We are animals after all.



The Team

A show of this scale is a labor of many. In addition to the four artists below, we work with a fantastic production manager and technical director, plus we rely on an army of wildly talented volunteers both for the development of the work and for the shows.

  • Hélène Lesterlin creates performances that fuse theater, dance, puppetry, sound and visual art. She's insatiably curious about the creative process: she's a collaborator, performer, director, choreographer, improviser, and hands-on maker. Fascinated by fables, memories, and ancient songs, she digs into history, archives, poetry, art and music to create her performances. Founded in 2012, Studio Reynard is home base for her work. Hélène also has a passion for working with contemporary performing artists to help bring their works into being: she currently serves as Director of Programs at Mount Tremper Arts, and was the founding curator for dance and theater at EMPAC.
  • Anastacia Bolina is an artist, performer, puppeteer, and a key collaborator with all Studio Reynard projects. Using materials such as the skeletal remains of plant roots, vintage clothes and fabric, papier mâché and armatures made of recycled electrical wires, Anastacia creates puppets and costumes rich with fine detail, exploring a dark, wild edge in design balanced by an earthly elegance. She is currently creating a video dance project that focuses on the transition of seasons, involving creatures that are part plant, part forest animal and part human. She also runs her own company, designing and installing vegetable gardens in the Catskills - evidence of her time outside can be seen in her art work. 
  • Laura Brenneman was raised by musician parents in San Diego, California, and grew up on a steady diet of show tunes, English choral music, and Abba. Described as “the love child of Joni Mitchell and Stephen Sondheim, raised by Muppets,” Laura writes pop music. She is the resident musical director of the neo-vaudevillian performance troupe, The Fabulists, and regularly performs as part of the Bushwick Book Club. She worked with director Martha Clarke on a workshop reading of The Threepenny Opera (Atlantic Theatre Company, NYC), was commissioned by the Women’s Project (NYC) to write music and lyrics for Gurley, a new musical, amongst other collaborations. As a singer-songwriter, Laura performs her original songs in NYC. Her self-titled EP (2010) was produced by Tony Maimone (They Might Be Giants).
  • Scott Bolman is an NYC-based lighting designer and educator working in theater, dance, music and opera. Scott recently developed several projects with Robert Wilson, including The Odyssey, 2012, and Zinnias: The Clementine Hunter Story, 2013. Other recent projects include re-creating David Finn’s lighting for Parsifal (Metropolitan Opera), 50 Ways (Chautauqua Theater Center), We Play for the Gods (Women’s Project), Songs from the Uproar (The Kitchen). He is a founding member of the collective Wing Space.


History and Future

Fox vs Kingdom is our biggest, most ambitious production to date, and has been in progress for over four years!

Our premier performances will be presented Halloween weekend at the Byrdcliffe Theater in Woodstock, NY. If you want to see the final steps of the work in progress, follow us on Instagram! @studioreynard


Developed as part of the Puppet Lab at St. Ann’s Warehouse (NYC), a part of Fox vs Kingdom was seen at the Labapalooza! festival of new puppetry. We also hosted a series of salons called Café Isegrim: we showed scenes in progress while sharing a feast with our community of fans.

We are so grateful to our supporters who have followed this project along its journey, from our local funders and The Jim Henson Foundation, to the essential time provided by residencies at Mount Tremper Arts, and Drop, Forge & Tool. 

Plans for the show's future include touring nationally and even further afield! We are so grateful to you for reading till the end. If you'd like to stay in touch with us, join our mailing list at studio-reynard.com!

Studio Reynard is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Studio Reynard must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
UPDATE YOUR LIFE

UPDATE is an immersive performance-ritual using music, dance, theater, creative technology, and installation art to create an interactive landscape that transforms audience members into performers and strangers into a community. A response to the noise, desensitization, and disembodiment of the internet, UPDATE empowers individuals using interaction and improvisation to generate agency and responsibility in an unfamiliar world. Together, we'll struggle to understand what it takes to connect in this increasingly mediated age of human experience.

WHY OUR WORK MATTERS

What does it mean to experience life through virtual interaction? Swept up in a hurricane of accelerating information that leaves us oversaturated yet insatiated, paralyzed and isolated yet active and connected, we asked ourselves: How can we get our bearings in an ever-changing landscape? How do we clear the fog to see ourselves and each other? How can we regain a sense of personal value beyond narcissism? And what do these things mean for where we are, where we’re going, and what we’ll become?

UPDATE is our response. 

Facilitating agency and collective responsibility through immersion, improvisation, and interaction, UPDATE offers a new kind of audience experience: a performance shaped by its audience and their choices; a space that integrates every individual within it; a ritual that transforms its audience into liberated performers. In doing so, we are pushing against a rigid tradition of spectatorship, passivity, and control, opting instead for integration, activity, and freedom.  

We began developing UPDATE in November of 2018. We had no resources, no assumptions, no predetermined course of action. What we had was a small group of ambitious artists and an impulse that we couldn't describe but all understood: the feeling of being subsumed by the internet. Every idea our ensemble pursues is measured by its truthfulness to that impulse, because we didn't just want to make another piece of theater about the internet—we wanted to create something that was our living experience of it at every level of performance. 

To date, our group of 5 collaborators has expanded to 16 artists across a range of disciplines: actors, dancers, composers, live musicians, and creative technologist. This number grows with every performance as audience members, moved by their experience, are compelled to join UPDATE without assured compensation or financial support, all because they believe in the importance of our vision.

Our cast + collaborators: 

Michael DelaFlor / Benjamin Satchel / Adrian Collins / Shannon Barnes / Fernando Casablancas / Jade Manns / Hope Luna / Richard Pannullo / Marlaina Riegelsberger / Mateo Hernandez Almeyda / Diego Blanc Zoco / Aaron Jean / Jon Clancy / Cesar Pinzon / Tyler Neidermeyer / Nola Latty / Irmak Hatirli  

"There's so much stimuli. I was totally on edge throughout the show and I loved it." @kingdiegs

"I stopped thinking and just started doing. And it felt right." @milesk3

"Unlike anything else. Be ready to be surprised." @imariasofia

"They challenged us to choose our role within the work. It's incredible to see artists and audience members collaborating on the same mission, especially when neither can predict exactly what will happen or where it will lead to." @jordanryder_

OUR PROCESS + VALUES

A community of synchronized individuals. We believe community begins with individuals in relation. To be, and to listen, means having the courage to lead and the humility to follow. The decision of one is simultaneously the decision of many: to listen or ignore. Within UPDATE, anything anyone does or doesn't do, whether observing quietly or screaming obscenities, becomes part of the performance and changes its outcome. This is what we share with our audience: a space where the effect of every choice is seen and felt, where the power of an individual is found in those around them.

We work with what we have. We rehearse in apartment spaces and practice with strangers in the street. There is no waste in our process. This means that as we gain resources, every new element is valued and incorporated into the heart of the piece.  

Collaborative experimentation and exploration. This means we devise exercises, we try and fail, we adapt and try again. Our rehearsals and performances are laboratories  committed to the experience of each and every individual; to offering, listening,  responding, and never settling. 

Accessible and uncompromising. While drawing from diverse influences across the spectrum of art, we believe the audience experience should transcend any familiarity with those mediums. We want to bring an uncompromising vision to as many people as possible, and we work rigorously to ensure that no matter who you are or where you come from, you can be a part of UPDATE.  

Ethical interaction. Simply said, this means our audience is free. There is no wrong way to be an audience, because in the world we envision everything that everyone does is perfect. We do not tell you how to be; we only offer opportunities to discover what you could be. 

FEED US AND WE FEED YOU

UPDATE is independently run by a group of young artists. This is both to our advantage and disadvantage: we are free to explore what this performance could be without fidelity to institutions or traditional demarcations, but are tasked with innovating a sustainable model for a new style of performance. 

In anticipation for our next work-in-progress showing at Dixon Place on June 22, 2019, this campaign is directed at supporting the continued development of our ambitious undertaking  by putting money in the hands of the deserving artists who are making this experience possible. Our campaign goal represents our determination to pay each and every collaborator who has labored hundreds of hours to make this performance a reality, and who will continue to do so well into the next year to deliver UPDATE to as large an audience as possible.

The capital generated by this campaign will also be allocated to securing future venues, rehearsal spaces, and technology ranging from projectors, audio equipment, motion sensors, and practical LED lighting. 

IMPACT

Now more than ever, our society requires the exploration, contradiction, and community that UPDATE provides. As a self-produced experimental performance piece stretching beyond the container of any one discipline, there are innumerable obstacles to making UPDATE possible. However, whether you purchase our 'malware' or become part of the show, your contribution aids in the grander project of making UPDATE a phenomenon across the country. The life of this project extends far beyond any one show, and will continue to develop, grow, and expand over the next year. We have big plans ahead of us, and we are confident that with your support we can make the full vision of this performance a reality. 

OTHER WAYS TO SUPPORT

Share our campaign! Spread the word and help us get the lid out.

Follow our social media! FB: @updateirl 

Come to a performance! There's truly no better way to understand the experience of UPDATE than to become part of a performance.

story:
Lured

A new play based on real events

Lured, by Frank J. Avella, is a brutal, visceral new play that examines the nature of hate crimes against gays, using real events in Russia as a backdrop.  Sadly, in this current world climate, the play could not be timelier. We are hoping to shed light on these horrific atrocities and create a dialogue for change.

We are grateful to be bringing this important piece directed by Frank J. Avella and Carlotta Brentan to Theater for the New City (Crystal Field, Artistic Director) in November 2018, and then take the production to the inaugural edition of the OnStage! American Theater Festival in Rome, Italy in January 2019. 

 

Why we are telling this story

Shedding light on darkness. Sparking conversations. 

The scenes depicted in Lured are strongly grounded in real, documented events that have been taking place in Russia since 2013. As a result of 2013's "Anti-Propaganda" law (Federal Law No. 135-FZ), the country saw a spate of anti-LGBTQ violence, often carried out by organized hate groups who followed their discriminatory agenda with impunity. 

These stories are not well known in the U.S. We believe this must change. Moreover, while rooted in a specific cultural and social milieu, the questions that Lured asks are universal: is hate innate, or taught? Is revenge ever a viable answer? Where will the cycle of rising hatred, tangible everywhere we turn in the world today, lead us? 

Lured is a story that elicits unparalleled passion in everyone who comes into contact with it. At ever stage of its development, we have been blown away by audience reactions to this challenging piece. Lured is not an easy sit, but we believe it is a vital one, and we hope you will agree.

 

 

Lured's history so far 

Where we've been, and where we're going

An early version of Lured was first presented at the Dream Up! Festival at Theater for the New City in the Summer of 2016, playing six performances to sold-out audiences. The New York Times recommended the play for those "looking for adventurous theater.” 

In 2017, the piece was chosen to take part in the 36th Annual William Inge Theater Festival (PlayLabs). The latest incarnation of Lured was a semi-finalist for the 2018 O'Neill National Playwrights Conference, and received a 2018 grant from the Arch and Bruce Brown Foundation. 

Which brings us to today: Lured will have its World Premiere produced by Theater for the New City for a 3-week run, November 8 - 25, 2018. We will then be taking the entire production overseas to Rome, Italy, where Lured will be part of the inaugural edition of OnStage! American Theater Festival in January 2019. 

We can't wait to bring Lured to a wider audience, and we hope that you'll consider coming with us on this exciting journey. 

 

Why we need your support

Producing independent theater requires support from people who believe in the project and the craft - and the artists involved. That would be you!

Your contributions will go directly towards funding our upcoming productions in NYC, Rome - and beyond.

Key budget items include: 

  • Rehearsal space
  • Costumes and Props 
  • Cast and creative team stipend
  • Flights to & accommodation in Italy for the cast
  • Insurance
  • Marketing and Publicity

We have budgeted extremely aggressively for Lured, stretching every dollar to its fullest, most creative potential, so you can rest assured that your contribution will be used efficiently and make a real difference to the future of the project. 

 

Who we are

Frank J. Avella (Playwright, Co-Director)

Frank is the recipient of a 2018 Bogliasco Foundation Fellowship. He was also awarded a 2015 Fellowship Award from the NJ State Council on the Arts, the 2016 Helene Wurlitzer Residency Grant and the Chesley/Bumbalo Foundation Playwright Award for his play Consent, which was a 2012 semifinalist for the O’Neill. His play, Vatican Falls, took part in the 2017 Planet Connections Festivity and Frank was nominated for Outstanding Playwriting. Lured was a semifinalist for the 2018 O’Neill and received a 2018 Arch and Bruce Brown Foundation Grant. Other stage plays include: Mad, Orville Station, For Mamma, Nemesis, Less Than 2 Degrees, The Bubble, Michael's #1 Fan, 3 Cains, Iris and Unhinging. Frank recently adapted Consent for the screen. He is a proud member of the Dramatists Guild.

 

Carlotta Brentan (Co-Director, "Zhanna")

Carlotta is a New York-based theater artist, specializing in fostering original play development as an actor, translator and producer. She has loved collaborating with Frank J. Avella on multiple plays since 2012. The stories she's most passionate about telling center on people fighting to fully own and yield their power. Recent acting highlights: world premieres of Paolo Bignami's The Journey I Never Made (Cherry Lane), Erik Ehn's Clover (LaMaMa), Cyndy A. Marion's You Are Perfect (WorkShop Theatre). Carlotta is the Executive Producer of In Scena! Italian Theater Festival NY, as well as a published and produced translator. Training: American Academy of Dramatic Arts, Academy Company. www.carlottabrentan.com

 

The Cast

We are thrilled to be bringing Lured to life with an exceptional cast of brave, exciting and devoted actors. Find out more about them on our website. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Our ultimate goal with Lured is to raise challenging questions about human nature and the direction we are headed in as a society - and to spark conversations that wouldn't have otherwise taken place. So if you can't contribute, we would love for you to spread the word. Ask us questions. Continue the conversation. Post about Lured on social media: let's talk. 

 

Thank you for reading: we hope you'll consider making a donation to help us take another important step towards the future of Lured. 

 

--------

Photography by Shushu Chen. Fundraising video shot & produced by James Eades. 

Find us on Facebook, Instagram & Twitter: @LuredThePlay

Check out our website: www.luredtheplay.com
story_txt:
Lured
A new play based on real events
Lured, by Frank J. Avella, is a brutal, visceral new play that examines the nature of hate crimes against gays, using real events in Russia as a backdrop.  Sadly, in this current world climate, the play could not be timelier. We are hoping to shed light on these horrific atrocities and create a dialogue for change.
We are grateful to be bringing this important piece directed by Frank J. Avella and Carlotta Brentan to Theater for the New City (Crystal Field, Artistic Director) in November 2018, and then take the production to the inaugural edition of the OnStage! American Theater Festival in Rome, Italy in January 2019. 
 
Why we are telling this story
Shedding light on darkness. Sparking conversations. 
The scenes depicted in Lured are strongly grounded in real, documented events that have been taking place in Russia since 2013. As a result of 2013's "Anti-Propaganda" law (Federal Law No. 135-FZ), the country saw a spate of anti-LGBTQ violence, often carried out by organized hate groups who followed their discriminatory agenda with impunity. 
These stories are not well known in the U.S. We believe this must change. Moreover, while rooted in a specific cultural and social milieu, the questions that Lured asks are universal: is hate innate, or taught? Is revenge ever a viable answer? Where will the cycle of rising hatred, tangible everywhere we turn in the world today, lead us? 
Lured is a story that elicits unparalleled passion in everyone who comes into contact with it. At ever stage of its development, we have been blown away by audience reactions to this challenging piece. Lured is not an easy sit, but we believe it is a vital one, and we hope you will agree.
 

 

Lured's history so far 
Where we've been, and where we're going
An early version of Lured was first presented at the Dream Up! Festival at Theater for the New City in the Summer of 2016, playing six performances to sold-out audiences. The New York Times recommended the play for those "looking for adventurous theater.” 
In 2017, the piece was chosen to take part in the 36th Annual William Inge Theater Festival (PlayLabs). The latest incarnation of Lured was a semi-finalist for the 2018 O'Neill National Playwrights Conference, and received a 2018 grant from the Arch and Bruce Brown Foundation. 
Which brings us to today: Lured will have its World Premiere produced by Theater for the New City for a 3-week run, November 8 - 25, 2018. We will then be taking the entire production overseas to Rome, Italy, where Lured will be part of the inaugural edition of OnStage! American Theater Festival in January 2019. 
We can't wait to bring Lured to a wider audience, and we hope that you'll consider coming with us on this exciting journey. 
 

Why we need your support
Producing independent theater requires support from people who believe in the project and the craft - and the artists involved. That would be you!
Your contributions will go directly towards funding our upcoming productions in NYC, Rome - and beyond.
Key budget items include: 

Rehearsal space
Costumes and Props 
Cast and creative team stipend
Flights to & accommodation in Italy for the cast
Insurance
Marketing and Publicity

We have budgeted extremely aggressively for Lured, stretching every dollar to its fullest, most creative potential, so you can rest assured that your contribution will be used efficiently and make a real difference to the future of the project. 

 

Who we are
Frank J. Avella (Playwright, Co-Director)

Frank is the recipient of a 2018 Bogliasco Foundation Fellowship. He was also awarded a 2015 Fellowship Award from the NJ State Council on the Arts, the 2016 Helene Wurlitzer Residency Grant and the Chesley/Bumbalo Foundation Playwright Award for his play Consent, which was a 2012 semifinalist for the O’Neill. His play, Vatican Falls, took part in the 2017 Planet Connections Festivity and Frank was nominated for Outstanding Playwriting. Lured was a semifinalist for the 2018 O’Neill and received a 2018 Arch and Bruce Brown Foundation Grant. Other stage plays include: Mad, Orville Station, For Mamma, Nemesis, Less Than 2 Degrees, The Bubble, Michael's #1 Fan, 3 Cains, Iris and Unhinging. Frank recently adapted Consent for the screen. He is a proud member of the Dramatists Guild.
 
Carlotta Brentan (Co-Director, "Zhanna")

Carlotta is a New York-based theater artist, specializing in fostering original play development as an actor, translator and producer. She has loved collaborating with Frank J. Avella on multiple plays since 2012. The stories she's most passionate about telling center on people fighting to fully own and yield their power. Recent acting highlights: world premieres of Paolo Bignami's The Journey I Never Made (Cherry Lane), Erik Ehn's Clover (LaMaMa), Cyndy A. Marion's You Are Perfect (WorkShop Theatre). Carlotta is the Executive Producer of In Scena! Italian Theater Festival NY, as well as a published and produced translator. Training: American Academy of Dramatic Arts, Academy Company. www.carlottabrentan.com
 
The Cast

We are thrilled to be bringing Lured to life with an exceptional cast of brave, exciting and devoted actors. Find out more about them on our website. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help
Our ultimate goal with Lured is to raise challenging questions about human nature and the direction we are headed in as a society - and to spark conversations that wouldn't have otherwise taken place. So if you can't contribute, we would love for you to spread the word. Ask us questions. Continue the conversation. Post about Lured on social media: let's talk. 
 
Thank you for reading: we hope you'll consider making a donation to help us take another important step towards the future of Lured. 
 
--------
Photography by Shushu Chen. Fundraising video shot & produced by James Eades. 
Find us on Facebook, Instagram & Twitter: @LuredThePlay
Check out our website: www.luredtheplay.com

story:
SPACESLAM

Party World Rasslin' is a seasonal party and bizarre wrestling spectacle. At our last event, your support let us build a terrifying Halloween Forest filled with monstrous creatures, lush and terrifying foliage, and wrestling! The brutal Schoolteacher, MRS. FENNENBAUM was defeated, and our favorite UNFROZEN COLONIAL WOMAN, THEODOSIA, earned her GED, through combat. NONE WERE LEFT UNMOVED!

PWR now prepares for our 14th Party! Can you believe that??? Thanks to you—the MULTIVERSE—PWR has  become something far beyond what we ever could have imagined. In 3.5 years we've gone from a handful of people watching a home-made ring in a backyard to attendance of a thousand+ and a full spectrum of professional audio, video and lighting. And we've built almost all of it ourselves, thanks to you! We continue to do a DIY show that is all-ages and free to the public, even as costs increase. Your continued support allows our core ethos to flourish. It means so much to us. The show remains FREE TO ATTEND, even as we mount mammoth costs. Here's what we want to do for our next show.

SPACE CHRISTMAS

Each PWR show has a special theme: we've explored HAUNTED FORESTS, surived the ROBOT APOCAYLPSE, and traded blows with REANIMATED DINOSAURS.
The HOLIDAY SEASON is always a great opportunity for cool art and stories, and offers a special challenge to be unique. Our WINTER WONDERSLAM shows have had varied styles: We've done one with a Holiday Atmosphere, a Christmas/Halloween Mashup, and an ICE CAVES one. This next one will be arguably our coolest yet, and perhaps our most exciting theme of all time: OUTER SPACE!

We're going to build 4th Tap Brewing Co-Op into a STAR-WORTHY craft to take us on a journey to the deepest stars. Prepare for an immersive environment with horrific and awe-inspiring cosmic monstrosities, star trek-style tech, glorious cosmic phenomena, and of course, plenty of aliens. 

And you'd better believe we're going to wrestle those aliens.

At our last event, the PARTYWEIGHT BELT was taken into space by the dreaded QUEEN GALEXIA: Empress of Voids, Sovereign of Planets, Mayor of Neptune! Our TRVE CHAMPION, the Unfrozen Colonial Woman, Theodosia, must find her and reclaim our belt in an INTERGALACTIC CHALLENGE! This is the greatest single wrestling conflict in human history.

Our roster of PARTY ATHLETES will compete in distinctly SPACE-ORIENTED challenges. The Intergalactic Express, Dan "The Man" Ziglar, Luigi Primo, Alexandra Cage, Charlie Frown, the Dumpster Babes, Big Daddy Bolero, Dino Rida, and more will be there hopping from planet to planet, waging merciless PARTY VIOLENCE!  HAIL BABY WORM!

What is this money used for?

$5000 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?

First, an important recitation: PWR is free and we want to keep it free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for as long as we can.

PWR is also now a 80-person organization putting on a show for 1500 people. One and a half thundo! Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spent north of $9000, each, to produce our last 2 shows.

Through diligent saving and prudent investment, we've managed to cap our fundraising goal at ~$5000. We are continuously able to improve the show and make it grander; your support and our rigorous planning have allowed us to do this without ballooning our costs! And it's all on the backs of our beautiful volunteers who submit themselves to the Multiverse out of love. We've survived more than two years as we've grown into the massive wrestling party you know today—and we're not slowing down! Accept no impostors! HELL RIGHT

Some of the cool things your donations have let us do include:

  • Art and design. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage. 4th Tap was turned into a HAUNTED MEGAFOREST by their selfless, capable hands. The SPRAWLING OUTER REALM they're building will suck you into the world of SPACESLAM! Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.

  • Paying artists. We work hard to make sure everyone who contributes to our production gets some money in exchange—whether our art team, our powerful tech wizards, or our A/V crew.

  • Safer space/security: PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem, no questions asked. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.

  • Projection and lighting. Space might be lightless- but you'll see everything with crystal-clarity! PWR has some of the most advanced lighting for an independent wrestling show in the country! And we built it ourselves, with your help. We still have improvements to make; you'll notice and love our latest generation of lights! Our projection system allows people to watch the show from 3 different places in the venue, each with different sitting and standing options!

  • Training: Party Violence is its own unique sport. We have crafted a training program that makes use of experienced pro-wrestling coaching to help keep our PARTY ATHLETES smooth n' safe.  

For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a majority of them. Below is our complete budget.


Show Expenses: $2075

Props: $250

Art: $550

Staff Food: $80

Live Video Projection: $235

Promo Material $100

Security: $140

Insurance: $385

Printing: $260

Construction: $100

PA: $225

Operational Expenses: $3538.11

Artist and staff pay: $2650
New Projects Capital : $400

Indiegogo Reward production and fulfillment: $2307
Indiegogo and credit card fees: $390

Extremely Hype Swag

We've got great rewards available for donating. Check out the EXCLUSIVE SHIRT DESIGN, by Zug Goodina! Also available on a hoodie! Only available from this Igg campaign:



And how about a SCREENPRINTED, 20" Poster by Rory Blank? Here's the draft version: He's still working on it, even, adding even more detail and BLACKLIGHT REACTIVE SICKNESS!


And how about some NEW ACRYLIC PINS? Here's the design work from Nat Bradford.

But what's this...a new EMBROIDERED PATCH by Zeke Guadiana?


And finally, hang on: We've got TWO TYPES OF PLUSHIES! These 10" pals are squeazable and battle-resilient! Choose from TIMMY QUIVERS or a TRANSFORMABLE INTERGALACTIC EXPRESS!

Risks & Challenges

 

Challenges:

PWR has become robust and its universe swole with powerful party drama. As it continues to grow wantonly like an uncontrollable teen (and our expectations for our performance climb) we approach a new realm of costs we could not have imagined before.  We are depending on the support of our Multiverse to keep our show free and open—thank you for your continued support.  Rest assured we are working night and day to make sure this event is the most fun thing you do all quarter.

 

Risks:

The only risk is the risk of not partying hard enough. We laugh at the concept of "risk." It is as outmoded as "shame," or "weakness." We have sworn to party 'til death, and we will do so.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and SPACESLAM!


Here is the Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/1686280844724620/

HMW

story:
About The Play

Four friends band together to play the English translation of best-selling JRPG, The Four Holy Beats. However, due to slow buffering speeds, our heroes-in-training must wait to “press START.” However, that doesn't mean the game hasn't already started. Choose Your Character marinates in (esoteric) memes and video game culture, meditating on what it means to have an identity when IRL and virtual realities intersect.

Creative Team

Jordan Ho (playwright/performer)

This is Jordan's playwriting debut. Mx. Ho wrote "Choose Your Character" to give trans artists space to flesh out what identity means beyond the basics of "preferred" gender pronouns. Memes. Internet Jargon. Keyboard Smash Text Monologues. There is humor in the tears and sadness in the laughter. Xe creates theater because there is something to be said in that can only be done through the communal experience of sharing space and time.

Jordan has performed at venues including: Joe's Pub, The Wild Project, The Tank

More collaborators to be announced.

What We Need &(!) What's in it for you

We are thrilled to opening our show as a part of The Trans Theatre Festival. This is a festival hosted by The Brick in Williamsburg that celebrates art created by transgender and gender-nonconforming artists. 

We value the work of queer artists and want to ensure that all levels of the production are properly compensated for their time and effort; this is why for this production of Choose Your Character we are only employing queer artists in the cast and design team.

Costumes, rehearsal space, lighting, sound, performers all have one thing in common: they all cost money. In late-capitalism it's becoming more and more difficult to see indie queer theatre experiences on stage. With your help we will be able to fully fund and realize this chaotic good new work. Your support of queer theatre speaks volumes, and any contribution you can make is greatly appreciated.

Budget

We are completely transparent with our budget, please see below how we got to our campaign total:

  • (3) Performers : $300
  • Playwright/Director: $200
  • Lighting designer: $100
  • Sound designer: $100
  • Costume designer: $100
  • Video designer: $100
  • Props Designer: $100
  • Photographer: $100
  • Sets: $200
  • Costumes: $250
  • Props: $100
  • Rehearsal space: $360

Common Questions

How do I get my perks?
Shortly after you make your contribution we will contact you to confirm all information and make further arrangements.

How Soon Will The Perks Be Shipped?

The latest your perks will arrive is early August. Please make sure we have a proper e-mail and mailing addresses so we can send digital and physical prizes

Make-up Consultations do not expire and can be scheduled with Jordan, feel free to e-mail xem at mx.jordanho@gmail.com.

Art commissions will also depend on the complexity of the request. Morgan's parameters are up to 2 characters, backgrounds; Katy's are up to 3 including a background.

Morgan's art page

Katy's art page

More Questions?

If you have any questions or concerns, please send us an email at cyctransfest@gmail.com and we will answer as soon as possible!

If you like our project but you can't contribute at the moment, please consider 
sharing this page and any other forms of media we post~

tysm <3

story:
Christine Bonansea – a French-born, NYC-based choreographer known for her striking, virtuosic performances – brings OnlyHuman, a visually arresting, media-enhanced work to New York for its US premiere at Danspace Project. Developed in collaboration with an international group of stellar multidisciplinary artists, and following successful presentations at DOCK11 in Berlin and 2018 Tanzmesse in Düsseldorf, Germany,  and the BIDAM in Korea, the evening-length version of this production will be presented for the first time to the American audiences November 15-17.

Tickets ($22 General / $15 Danspace Members) are available online through OvationTix (https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/996935) or by calling 866-811-4111.

Inspired by Friedrich Nietzsche’s aphoristic volume Human, All Too Human, Bonansea investigates the stark contradiction between our race’s capacity for beauty against its most destructive tendencies, embodying the struggle with her intensely kinetic choreography. In OnlyHuman, Bonansea ruminates on corporeal images and stereotypes of self in the context of the landscape of emotions, geography and social structures. As most of Bonansea’s multidisciplinary works, OnlyHuman has been created during an intimately collaborative process. The dance – featuring a lead performer and a cast of supporting ones – is wrapped into a ultra-modern, Matrix-like, futuristic layer of striking multimedia visuals.

“This work observes the future of the human race with a critical gaze. It reveals tensions between contradictory and conflicting information in our physical life experiences. It also embodies the paradox of human condition as our species is transforming from the human to the post-human in the digital age,” says Bonansea. Referring to the extended cast employed in the work’s final incarnation, she explains: “Because OnlyHuman performances engaged local community as well as international audiences, I created a longer version including an eclectic cast of nine dancers completing the multimedia team, each bringing their own, unique moving history and potent presence.”

The show’s animated visuals are conceived and executed together with acclaimed photographerRobert Flynt, video and multimedia artist Yoann Trellu, and lighting designer Solomon Weisbard; the composer Nicole Carroll’s droning sounds create an aural environment for the performance. Originally developed as a solo performance with Bonansea as a main dancer, this iteration of the work features Mei Yamanaka in the lead and a supporting cast of nine dancers – including well-known New York performers Alvaro Estado, Maya Orchin, Becca Loevy, Amelia Heintzelman, Ichi Go, Cameron Mckinney, Charles Gowin, Kristopher K.Q. Pourzal, and Malcolm Betts.

OnlyHuman is presented as part of Danspace Project’s Community ACCESS which provides subsidized off-season rental opportunities for Danspace Project community members. The production was made possible in part with public funds from Creative Engagement, supported by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and administered by LMCC.

Inclusion of an exceptional, eclectic cast, all with their own unique moving histories is imperative for this work. The work explores the human condition, and needs to expose “what it is to be human” through many lenses. These creative ambitions come with many financial setbacks, and the process of rehearsing and producing a piece with over 10 cast members and 3 additional collaboratoes has proved financially challenging for the company. We are in desperate need of additional funds to fairly compensate all artists, collaborators, and performers involved in the project.

WE NEED YOUR HELP!!

Donations no matter how big or small make a HUGE difference in the production of OnlyHuman. Here is what your donation goes towards: 

$10 = equates to an hour of rehearsal space $25 = a dancers pay for one rehearsal 

$50 = one costumes for cast members

$100 = six hours of administrative work 

$200 = a photographer's fee

$500 = covers additional production materials (marley, subwoofer, etc) 

$1000 = average artist's fee (dancer, lighting designer, musician) 

$2000 = one night's rental fee for the theatre space
story_txt:
Christine Bonansea – a French-born, NYC-based choreographer known for her striking, virtuosic performances – brings OnlyHuman, a visually arresting, media-enhanced work to New York for its US premiere at Danspace Project. Developed in collaboration with an international group of stellar multidisciplinary artists, and following successful presentations at DOCK11 in Berlin and 2018 Tanzmesse in Düsseldorf, Germany,  and the BIDAM in Korea, the evening-length version of this production will be presented for the first time to the American audiences November 15-17.
Tickets ($22 General / $15 Danspace Members) are available online through OvationTix (https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/996935) or by calling 866-811-4111.
Inspired by Friedrich Nietzsche’s aphoristic volume Human, All Too Human, Bonansea investigates the stark contradiction between our race’s capacity for beauty against its most destructive tendencies, embodying the struggle with her intensely kinetic choreography. In OnlyHuman, Bonansea ruminates on corporeal images and stereotypes of self in the context of the landscape of emotions, geography and social structures. As most of Bonansea’s multidisciplinary works, OnlyHuman has been created during an intimately collaborative process. The dance – featuring a lead performer and a cast of supporting ones – is wrapped into a ultra-modern, Matrix-like, futuristic layer of striking multimedia visuals.
“This work observes the future of the human race with a critical gaze. It reveals tensions between contradictory and conflicting information in our physical life experiences. It also embodies the paradox of human condition as our species is transforming from the human to the post-human in the digital age,” says Bonansea. Referring to the extended cast employed in the work’s final incarnation, she explains: “Because OnlyHuman performances engaged local community as well as international audiences, I created a longer version including an eclectic cast of nine dancers completing the multimedia team, each bringing their own, unique moving history and potent presence.”
The show’s animated visuals are conceived and executed together with acclaimed photographerRobert Flynt, video and multimedia artist Yoann Trellu, and lighting designer Solomon Weisbard; the composer Nicole Carroll’s droning sounds create an aural environment for the performance. Originally developed as a solo performance with Bonansea as a main dancer, this iteration of the work features Mei Yamanaka in the lead and a supporting cast of nine dancers – including well-known New York performers Alvaro Estado, Maya Orchin, Becca Loevy, Amelia Heintzelman, Ichi Go, Cameron Mckinney, Charles Gowin, Kristopher K.Q. Pourzal, and Malcolm Betts.
OnlyHuman is presented as part of Danspace Project’s Community ACCESS which provides subsidized off-season rental opportunities for Danspace Project community members. The production was made possible in part with public funds from Creative Engagement, supported by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and administered by LMCC.
Inclusion of an exceptional, eclectic cast, all with their own unique moving histories is imperative for this work. The work explores the human condition, and needs to expose “what it is to be human” through many lenses. These creative ambitions come with many financial setbacks, and the process of rehearsing and producing a piece with over 10 cast members and 3 additional collaboratoes has proved financially challenging for the company. We are in desperate need of additional funds to fairly compensate all artists, collaborators, and performers involved in the project.
WE NEED YOUR HELP!!
Donations no matter how big or small make a HUGE difference in the production of OnlyHuman. Here is what your donation goes towards: 
$10 = equates to an hour of rehearsal space $25 = a dancers pay for one rehearsal 
$50 = one costumes for cast members
$100 = six hours of administrative work 
$200 = a photographer's fee
$500 = covers additional production materials (marley, subwoofer, etc) 
$1000 = average artist's fee (dancer, lighting designer, musician) 
$2000 = one night's rental fee for the theatre space

story:
WHO WE ARE:

We are RANDOM ACTS!  We are a group of theatre professionals based in Southwest Florida. 

Traditionally performing in the summer, when the theatre season is light, we are dedicated to the production of quality theatre, whether scripted plays, cabarets, burlesque, or any type of entertainment that might not get produced in the mainstream environment. Our main goal is attracting audiences to theatre experiences who might not ordinarily go to see plays, and develop a sense of the love and enjoyment of live performances!

Basically, we want to share the party…to hang out, enjoy art, music, theatre, good food, great spirits, and have fun.  Especially when we can make a statement.

WHAT WE NEED

It takes a village to raise a kid...and to put on a show.  We've partnered with Compassionate Cannabis and Regulate Florida to bring this off-Broadway sensation to Sarasota.  With their help, we have been able to acquire audio equipment, build costumes, and create flyers and help spread the word! We could not get to where we are today without them.  We need your help to get this project to the finish line!

We are looking for $6,000.00 to help off-set the costs of building the set and props ($1,750), musicians and sound design ($2,500), dance and fight choreography ($1,000) and lighting equipment and design ($500), and other production costs ($250).  If we meet this goal, not only would we be able to fully fund the production, but we would be able to compensate our actors, who have poured their hearts and souls into this project.  All of our production staff and actors work full-time jobs in addition to spending many weeknights and weekends doing what we love: creating theatre.

 For your contributions at various levels, we are offering:

  • Behind the scenes videos!
  • Photos and posters signed by the cast!
  • Canvas prints of REAL anti-marijuana propaganda art!
  • and MORE!

WHY NOW?

While we at Random Acts love having a good time and putting on a good show, we also are very passionate about the issues surrounding marijuana, particularly its legalization.  The history of marijuana's prohibition in this country is steeped in racism, xenophobia, and religious bigotry.

By 1936 (the year the original Reefer Madness was produced) Harry Anslinger had already become Head of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics and solicited stories of cannabis addiction to add to his "Gore Files" to build his case for a federal prohibition on cannabis. He relied on shock value, exaggerations, and outright untruth and in the end, he was successful.  The legacy that Anslinger left behind means that right now African Americans are 3.73 times more likely to be imprisoned for marijuana possession than white people (according to the ACLU).  Do you believe that all Americans deserve to be treated equally under the law?  We do too.  That's why we want to use our love of theatre to educate the public.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help spread the word!  Bring your friends, your family, your casual acquaintances!  Come see the show.  Buy your tickets here!

story:
Who We Are

Body. is a devised production that theatricalizes true, personal stories about the relationships we have to the narratives of our bodies.  Through monologues, poetry, and movement rooted in Theatre of the Oppressed, Body. examines to what degree we are able to define that narrative for ourselves.

Our Team

Directed by Madeleine Regina

Produced by Jennie Bissell

Assistant Directed by Katie Keddell and Kanea MacDonald

Technical Direction/ Stage Management by Elliott Shugoll

Cast Includes: Jennie Bissell, Melissa Gump, Reid Herreid, Rebecca Kiser, Axandre Oge, Greg Ongao, Tatyana Ridgeway, Katie Wicklund

Why You Should Help

From the first day of auditions, we've been moved by the (often previously unexpressed) stories held in each person's body.  Throughout the rehearsal process, we've become increasingly more aware of assumptions we make about others' physical forms and our own, and the deep need for a safe space to explore those narratives.  In an original piece rooted in honesty, humor, and expressive movement, we will invite our audiences to reexamine their relationship to their own bodies and those of others.  Ultimately, we aim to create a platform for further exploration, in a space where we as bear witness to the bodies of all.

What We Need

Most Fringe productions make about $1,200 in ticket sales.  With 12 professional artists and original props, set, and costumes, we'll need your help to make Body. the moving production that it can be.

When you donate to the Body. campaign, you're contributing to the following expenses:

Promotion and Publicity (listings/ postings, graphic design, postcards): $830

Production (props, costumes, scenery, space rental): $940

Festival Fees/ Insurance: $865

Artist Stipends (8 actors, director, 2 assistant directors, stage manager): $4950

How We'll Thank You

We deeply appreciate donations of any size!  All donations will be acknowledged in our program.

Donations over $25 will receive a signed poster.

Donations over $50 will receive a signed poster and a VIP reserved seat at the performance.

Donations over $100 will receive a signed poster, VIP reserved seating, and a surprise sweet treat after the show!

Other Ways You Can Help

We ALSO deeply appreciate support of any kind!

Please like us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/body.devisedplay/) and Instagram (@body.devised)!

Most importantly, we'd love to see you at the show!  Tickets are available here: https://capitalfringe.org/events/?action=tribe_...

story:
"ALICE: I’m tired of crazy people. No more crazy people!
CHESIRE CAT: Oh, you won’t be able to help that. We’re all crazy here. I’m crazy, you’re crazy.
ALICE: How do you know I’m crazy?
CHESIRE CAT: You must be, or you wouldn’t be here. Unless you’re a tourist or something. Are you a tourist or something?"

Summery of NWaC and "Alice"

Nothing Without a Company (NWaC) has been producing free, traveling, site-specific theatre since 2005 in Chicago, IL. We have created and developed over 20 shows, collaborated with countless artists, and changed communities by bringing art to their everyday routines!

This summer NWaC is remounting the all-ages show “Alice.” Michael Wise adapted “Alice” from the book Alice's Adventures in Wonderland by Lewis Carroll in 2009 and changed the work this year to allow Alice to explore the wonderland of Chicago. “Alice” directed by Rose Freeman will take place in Lincoln Park near North Pond.

NWaC is raising funds for “Alice” to pay artists, designers, and performers. The funds will also go to production costs such as props, costumes, material, and puppets!

What We Need & What You Get

To keep the costs down we have partnered with The Chicago Park District so NWaC needs $2,500.00 for “Alice.”

Over $1,700.00 to pay artists, actors, production team, designers, wranglers, and more people!

Around $800 for props, costumes, puppets, and anything else needed for the design elements!

For your generous donations you can get VIP or General Admission tickets to our annual gala, video thank you’s, cast photo, NWaC t-shirts, and much more!

NWaC is hosting this campaign through the run of “Alice” to maximize our donations! As you can see, most of our funds will be going to pay artists so if we don’t reach our entire goal the funds we raise here will go to the hardworking people of “Alice.” 

The Project

Alice is a girl on a strange adventure through the Wonderland of Chicago. Bring your walking shoes and join this traveling show as Alice tries to make sense of this crazy city. Thankfully, she has a good head on her shoulders…as long as the Queen doesn’t have it removed.

Adapted by Michael Wise and Directed by Rose Freeman and Based on the book "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" by Lewis Carroll

Featuring:Stephanie Shum as Alice and Will Bennett, Brandon Boler, Anya Clingman, *Dave Fink, Romeo Green, *Rashaad Hall, Dani Loumena, *Val Lyvers, Autumn Teague, and Gage Wallace

Mighty Ensemble:Angela R. Carroll, Nellsyn Hill, Lyndee McPeek, Gaby Labotka, and Chelsea Angeletti.

Production Team:Asst Director- Edgar Sanchez, Casting Director- Kaitlin Carver, Stage Manager- Sarah Collonge, Puppet & Props Design- Jimmy Jagos, Costurme Design- Jesselyn Ewing, Fight Choreographer- Will Bennet, Producers- *Anna Rose Ii-Epstein, Danilo Kobilic, and Jason Weinberg

* Denotes Company Members

Show Information:Check out NothingWithoutaCompany.org for show dates and times! “Alice” is a free, traveling performance, RSVP requested.

Location: Inside Lincoln Park, near Notebaert Nature Museum. 2430 N. Cannon Dr., Chicago, IL 60614

Other Ways You Can Help

Talk about us! Please visit our website (NothingWithoutaCompany.org) to learn more about “Alice” and it’s site-specific nature and share it with your friends. We are Nothing Without a Company and we are nothing without your support.

Attend our Opening night cosmic bowling party on Friday August 16, from 9pm-1:30am at Timber Lanes (1851 W. Irving Park Rd.) $15 at the door includes bowling, shoe rental, and food.

Use the tools indiegogo provides and share the goodness with your friends!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Natasha Mumba and I am the coordinator and director of the Strivers Group; a group of theatre artists based in Montreal, QU at the National Theatre School of Canada. This Project has been in the making since I decided to pursue acting. I have always had a passion to teach theatre workshops back home in Zambia, not just as a training tool for an aspiring theatre artist but as an outlet for disadvantaged youth. A place where these young artists form low income families and also those living on the streets, could connect with people their age and join together to create and share stories too impact and change their lives. A few years ago, I found out about a theatre company in Zambia called the Barefeet Theatre Company; they are dedicated to helping youth get off the streets through the use of theatre. Every summer, since 2008, they host a festival performance where 2000 kids participate through acting, dancing and singing. The moment I found out about this program I contacted the artistic director, Adam Macguigan and told him we were interested in participating by hosting one of the workshops with the kids. After several e-mails we were please to have come to an agreement for a three week intensive workshop with thirty of the kids starting on July 15th and ending with a performance on August 3rd 2013.

 

Your support to this project is essential. With your gift you will be supporting us in sharing our knowledge of theatre with at risk youth in Lusaka, helping them hone and sharpen their skills of communication through theatre. This is an extremely powerful tool to have.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I have a budget of $13,635 CAN in total and have already received responses from several different artists, organizations and grants that in total will give this project $5,000 CAN. The funds will be covering the costumes, rehearsal space, performance space, lights, transportation and travel expenses as this is an International project. Leaving $8,635.35 CAN to be covered. Your contribution and your participation to this project is highly appreciated. And your involvement will not end with just the donation but their will be a full documented package containing all the things accomplished during this project that will be available to you, as well as an acknowledgement of your participation in making this project come to life.

The original plan with this project; is to build a strong enough relationship with the Barefeet project to make our workshops annual. If we don’t meet our goal, we will maintain all the funds that we have earned and keep them in the project bank account and we will work toward the summer of 2014.

 

The Impact

My goal at the end of this is to have inspired these kids to begin telling their own stories and leave them with the tools to do it. I have created a syllabus involving  movement based on acting, singing and script work and with these elements, my peers and I have designed a structure that will hold the foundation of our project. We’re going to take their stories; their fears, their goals, things that move and inspire them and create individual devised pieces, which will be the life and core of the piece. Then as a collective we will combine all these individual elements through a theme that will be informed by the stories that they share.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot financially support us, please don’t think you can't be a part of this campaign! Please share this information via Facebook, Twitter and whatever social media you are connected too and spread the word!. Thank you, so much for your time!

story:
WHO WE ARE/WHAT WE ARE DOING:

A group of students studying at Eugene Lang College, The New School for Liberal Arts is producing a work loosely based off Caryl Churchill's Mad Forest, found texts, and original work. With the help of our director and project advisor, Royd Climenhaga, we are producing a work heavily influenced by the ideas of LOVE and REVOLUTION, as well as the intersections between the two, and the profound impact these ideas have.  The structure of rehearsals is informed by an innovative array of artistic techniques, including Grotowski, the Steppenwolf Theatre Company, Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker, and Pina Bausch. The piece will provide aspiring theater artists with an understanding of how to self-produce new work, which will be an invaluable tool when entering the professional downtown theater scene.  

The Revolve Project is a collaborative and experimental theater work. This piece seeks to provide an encouraging and stimulating creative environment that will serve as both an introduction to the collaborative rehearsal process for theater novices as well as an opportunity for experienced theater artists to hone their skills. 

 

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:

We are funding this project entirely on our own. As broke college students, that task is easier said than done. Donations on this site will go towards renting our performance space, purchasing costumes and props, as well as set design, lighting design, and sound design.

 

We would greatly appreciate any donation to The Revolve Project!

 

We will be performing this piece on April 25th-27th at Teatro La Tea (107 Suffolk Street, 2nd floor). We hope to see you there!
story_txt:
WHO WE ARE/WHAT WE ARE DOING:
A group of students studying at Eugene Lang College, The New School for Liberal Arts is producing a work loosely based off Caryl Churchill's Mad Forest, found texts, and original work. With the help of our director and project advisor, Royd Climenhaga, we are producing a work heavily influenced by the ideas of LOVE and REVOLUTION, as well as the intersections between the two, and the profound impact these ideas have.  The structure of rehearsals is informed by an innovative array of artistic techniques, including Grotowski, the Steppenwolf Theatre Company, Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker, and Pina Bausch. The piece will provide aspiring theater artists with an understanding of how to self-produce new work, which will be an invaluable tool when entering the professional downtown theater scene.  
The Revolve Project is a collaborative and experimental theater work. This piece seeks to provide an encouraging and stimulating creative environment that will serve as both an introduction to the collaborative rehearsal process for theater novices as well as an opportunity for experienced theater artists to hone their skills. 
 
WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:
We are funding this project entirely on our own. As broke college students, that task is easier said than done. Donations on this site will go towards renting our performance space, purchasing costumes and props, as well as set design, lighting design, and sound design. 
 
We would greatly appreciate any donation to The Revolve Project!
 
We will be performing this piece on April 25th-27th at Teatro La Tea (107 Suffolk Street, 2nd floor). We hope to see you there!

story:
As you may know, Stania Diffey, Tango dancer, teacher and dear friend, has had major surgery and is now in recovery.
 
I am calling out to friends and family, to the local and international Dance community, professional and amateur...To artists of all genres.
 
I know from experience: The Dance community is a strong one... ANY style: Tango, Belly Dance, Hip Hop et al. I have seen dancers all over the world come together to make incredible things happen. I would like to channel that energy towards this dancer. Even if you don't know Stania personally I would love for you to do this for a fellow dancer.
 
You will know that being unable to dance for any reason is a nightmare scenario. As dancers we need to dance, it's our passion, it's our lifeline. I believe we can help her through this difficult time by alleviating some of her financial worries.

Stania has been through years of great discomfort with utmost poise and grace.  Three years ago Stania had an abdominal operation to remove fibroids from her womb, but unfortunately over the past 2 years the fibroids have returned causing  severe symptoms and great discomfort, and limiting her ability to work.
 
After consulting a variety of medical practioners, Stania was referred to a private surgeon to undertake the procedure, scheduled in early May, followed by 7 weeks recovery. The operation went well and she is now at home. She will not be able to get back to work for a while, which means no income until she has healed, as well as  fees owed for the surgery.

Although the financial cost of this operation was daunting, it was fundamental that she receive the best possible medical treatment for her condition in order to end this long and draining experience.
 
The operation cost £5,500, the total sum has been lent by a friend but she will need to pay it back. in order to support her financially through this challenging time, we have decided to host this fundraiser and various Tango events.  

I am sure any self employed artists out there will understand how much of a struggle making ends meet can be, add to this the pressure of paying medical fees.

Please forward this on to other friends and family, the wider we can spread the word the better, via Facebook, Twitter, Email, Phone Calls, Word of Mouth, any way possible!

Perks:

I am offering my first Tribal Fusion Private on line classes, one to one via Skype!

No matter where you are in the world, thanks to technology, we can practice together

You will find Tango perks on offer with the wonderful Fernando Guidi. http://www.vidadetango.co.uk/aboutus/aboutus.html

He is very kindly offering private lessons AND class cards for couples or singles (based in Devon). Perks for beginners and experienced Tango dancers alike.

As some of you know I make my own Raw Vegan Chocolates and will make up a few batches to send to UK backers should you choose that option (sorry I cannot ship my chocs overseas)

If you can only spare a quid, that's GREAT as I know times are tight for many of us these days. If each friend/follower/fan across social media platforms gave a little something, we could cover her medical fees and maybe even a little more to help Stania through her recovery. This campaign is very close to my heart, any contribution is GREATLY appreciated.


Thank you SO much.

story:
"If you thought the only way to get your message out was by using Ben Franklin's mouth, then you, my friend, don't understand the power of words."

The Princemaker is a brand-new two-hander satirical play all about the politics of money and the money of politics. Les, an eighteen-year-old with an unlimited bank account and unlimited ambition, says the above words to his protege (who is nearly twice his age) to convince him that money's power in politics is overstated. That may be true, but the fact remains that making theatre and producing plays does indeed cost money. We are going to stage a production of The Princemaker in this year's FringeNYC, and we need your help to do so. The Supreme Court tells us that money and speech are the same thing. If that's the case, then let your voice be heard!

"That's a lot  of zeroes..."

Congressman George Lee, the titular "prince" of The Princemaker, is given a blank check at the top of the play in order to fund his Presidential campaign. We wish we had a rich benefactor like he does, but unfortunately we do not. That's where you come in. We are asking for $3000 to cover the cost of our production. Here is exactly where your investment will go.

  • Overhead costs associated with FringeNYC - they're a non-profit and need money to do their awesome work.
  • Scenic design - you're going to make our show look pretty as pretty can be.
  • Marketing - word-of-mouth ain't enough these days. You're going to help us make posters and purchase ad space and hire a town crier.
  • Paying our cast and crew - This is by far the most important one. We wish we could promise our actors, designers, and crew members compensation up front, but the reality is that we can't. Whatever money we don't spend on the above costs will be split among our awesome team.

"I know that the door is being opened, but more importantly I know that you're the one opening it for me."

You give to a political candidate, you get a bumper sticker. You give to us, you get our gratitude first and foremost, and if you give at a certain level you get some pretty neat perks. These perks include:

  • A social media shout-out for a donation of any level
  • A digital copy of the script
  • A signed poster
  • Your name in our program
  • The opportunity to win free tickets

"If this is a game, then I don't want to play."

We get it. Money is precious and it's fun to have money. That's kind of why we're making this play in the first place. We understand that you may not be able to help with a monetary investment. That's cool. There are tons of other ways you can help bring The Princemaker to the stage. For one, we're always looking for volunteers to help with marketing. We need people handing out information about our play on the street during the festival. Interested? E-mail us to 16-4287@fringenyc.org to let us know.

Alternatively, if you can't invest in The Princemaker yourself, we're sure you know someone who can! Tap into your networks and share our information with your people so that we can reach our goal.

story:
Our Story

    Against the dawning of the Machine Age, Edgar Allan Poe embarks on an obsessive, erotically charged love affair with poet Sarah Helen Whitman. But a fateful past encounter casts its shadow forward in time as inexorably as the hands of a clock, threatening to destroy their bridge to a new life with each other.

    The initial staged reading of this musical, held in June of 2011 at the Bainbridge Museum of Art, received an extraordinarily positive response from an over-capacity audience and informed subsequent revisions of the script.

    Our second workshop reading took place on February 11, 2013 at the Center Theatre and featured 11 local actors, an orchestra of 3 and was attended by industry peers in an effort to flush out more of the script. The Hours of Life is currently in the final stages of rewrites.

    The Hours of Life will be produced at the Cornish Studio Theatre (formerly the Intiman Black Box) December 5th -14th 2014 for a compressed run of 12 performances in only 10 Days.  


    Check out our "gallery" for video conversations, music samples and images.   CLICK HERE 

    OR visit the Gallery Link at the top if your browser does not support "click here."

    About the playwright/composer, Paul Lewis

    Paul Lewis is a Seattle-based playwright and composer whose previous staged work includes musicals (Alley Dog, The Crossing, The Recollection of Flight, and a recent adaptation of the children's literature classic Caps for Sale); The World Below, an opera for young people; Last Poem on Earth, a choral and orchestral requiem; and both one-act and full-length plays. His one-acts have been staged across the country, and include A Place that Looks Like Davenport, winner of both the Jury Prize and Audience Favorite Award at the 2014 Driftwood Players Festival of Shorts; Timmy Perlmutter Goes Flying (seven productions in 2014); Oblivion, winner of the Audience Favorite Award at Driftwood in 2013, and published in The Best Ten-Minute Plays 2014; and Guess What?, which won the 2012 Audience Choice Award at FUSION Theatre's short works festival. His full-length adaptation of Oblivion will be produced in 2015, both at Driftwood and at HRC Showcase Theatre in Hudson, NY. Paul is a member of BMI and The Dramatists Guild of America.


    What we need

    • Theatre22 has assembled a cast, crew, orchestra and producing team of 36 local artists, designers and musicians.  96% of our staffing has offered to "volunteer" their services towards the production in order to assist in this new work's launch and world premiere. 
    • Your donation dollars, which are fully tax deductible, will go directly to the ARTISTS' FUND  to offer stipends and payments for their services and contributions.

    The Impact

    • Theatre22 wishes to contribute to the local reputation that Seattle is a regional powerhouse for new works in theatre. 
    • The Hours of Life will mark Theatre22's first new-works production and is the final production in their inaugural season.  Joining the ranks of the region's top theatre companies, Theatre22 is excited to contribute to Seattle's reputation of being a "spring board" for new plays, musicals, playwrights and artists. 

    Producing theatre is costly and risky.  Magnify the risks when working with new material that has not been tried, tested and audience approved.  Theatre22 embraces the challenges of producing new works by local playwrights and composers and gratefully accepts your support in these ventures.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Help Theatre22 get the word out and make some noise about The Hours of Life  Artists' Fund campaign.
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
    • Purchase your tickets to The Hours of Life in advance at http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/858076
    • Season 2 announcement is coming in the weeks ahead.  Theatre22 season subscriptions will be available for the first time ever.  Support Theatre22's financial foundation by subscribing.  Subscriptions available in December.  Stay tuned through our website at www.theatre22.org.
    • Remember Theatre22 in your end of year giving at www.theatre22.org/donate.


      The Cast, Crew, Musicians and Producer's Team

      (Our LARGEST Team Yet!!)
