story:
Who We Are

TE San Pedro Rep offers the Southern California community a unique alternative to the typical L.A. theater experience. A wholehearted celebration of empowered artistic innovation - from every background and medium, TESPR strives to reawaken the creative spirit in each of us. 

True to its name, TE San Pedro Rep is an artistic paradise - a caring, dedicated community fully invested in the work of every inspired craftsman. We joyfully embrace the interdisciplinary nature of performance, utilizing every aspect of human experience to delve further and further into the unknown. Through intelligent and fearless exploration, TESPR is committed to reexamining the fundamental works that have defined performance from Ancient Greece to Modern America. We knowingly stand on the shoulders of giants, casting our vision forward into a new era of American performance.

We remain committed to fueling the next generation of American art, creating visionary work that rattles the foundations of modern performance.

What We Need & What You Get

Your generous contribution will help "Raise The Curtain" on TE San Pedro Rep's production of MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING- opening March 20th, 2015!

The Goal: $1,000 for the show's inspired costuming needs + beautification of the courtyard + expanded marquee!

TESPR is giving all supporters of our production a Supporting Cast, Producer or Executive Producer credit - each with it's own perks and levels of recognition.

The Production

From the director of Cymbeline and the modern fairy tale Wouldn’t It Be Lovely, comes an  extraordinary adventure of theatrical imagination and wonder! Theatrum Elysium San Pedro Rep (TESPR) invites you to celebrate life, laughter, and love as Shakespeare's most inspired, romantic comedy comes to life with this Spring's production of Much Ado About Nothing!!!

Other Ways You Can Help

The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person - no matter their talents - can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream - that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

story:
What's The Story:

The team who brought you New Dawn (Winner of Outstanding Full-Length Musical in the Midtown International Theatre Festival) is bringing you Super!, a musical about a young man who must become the superhero that he was meant to be.  The show is being presented by the Midtown International Theatre Festival this summer at the Times Square Arts Center.

How You Can Be A Superhero:

The money raised goes towards:

  • Festival Fees
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Production Costs
What you get in return could include:
  • Demos from the show, featuring the festival cast
  • Special Thank you printed in the program
  • Poster signed by the cast and creative team
  • Two tickets to a performance of Super! (travel to NYC not included)
  • Special Access to rehearsal for Super! (travel to NYC not included)

The Impact: 

New musicals can be very difficult to get off the ground, especially at a smaller level.  Of course this show has the action-packed fight sequence that you'd expect from something of the genre, but more importantly, the show delves into the very real struggles that make this extraordinary young superhero a relatable human.  Complete with an original book and score, the show promises to be more than your average musical experience.

Other Ways You Can Save The Day:

Just because you can't donate money, it doesn't mean you still can't be a superhero!

  • Share this Indiegogo Campaign on your Facebook
  • Tweet about the show and Campaign
  • Post a vlog on Youtube and tag us in it
  • Spread it through good old word of mouth

And you, too, can be #doingsomethingsuper

Like us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/SuperTheSuperheroMusical
story_txt:
What's The Story: The team who brought you New Dawn (Winner of Outstanding Full-Length Musical in the Midtown International Theatre Festival) is bringing you Super!, a musical about a young man who must become the superhero that he was meant to be.  The show is being presented by the Midtown International Theatre Festival this summer at the Times Square Arts Center.   How You Can Be A Superhero: The money raised goes towards:

Festival Fees
Rehearsal Space
Production Costs

What you get in return could include:
 Demos from the show, featuring the festival cast
Special Thank you printed in the program
Poster signed by the cast and creative team
Two tickets to a performance of Super! (travel to NYC not included)
Special Access to rehearsal for Super! (travel to NYC not included)    The Impact: 

New musicals can be very difficult to get off the ground, especially at a smaller level.  Of course this show has the action-packed fight sequence that you'd expect from something of the genre, but more importantly, the show delves into the very real struggles that make this extraordinary young superhero a relatable human.  Complete with an original book and score, the show promises to be more than your average musical experience.
Other Ways You Can Save The Day: Just because you can't donate money, it doesn't mean you still can't be a superhero!  Share this Indiegogo Campaign on your Facebook
Tweet about the show and Campaign
Post a vlog on Youtube and tag us in it
Spread it through good old word of mouth   And you, too, can be #doingsomethingsuperLike us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/SuperTheSuperheroMusical

story:
Short Summary

Mastodon Theatre Company and Wide Eyed Productions are two NYC based theatre companies coming together to co-produce a four week run at The Barrow Group in April 2016 of KEEP, an unpublished and up until now unproduced play about hoarding, family, and the love that binds us.

Our two companies have been flirting for a while now, and couldn't be happier to come together and produce together.  It is incredibly important to us to build community and work together to lift one another up.  By joining forces we will be able to accomplish so much more than if we stand alone.  

Mastodon is led by Madison Comerzan, Jenna D'Angelo and Kim Krane.  The three met in college and since forming their company in 2013 have produced and acted in four shows in the city to sold out houses.  They proudly focus on producing work that is engaging, fun, thought provoking and fostering work with emerging artists.

Wide Eyed is led by Artistic Director Kristin Skye Hoffmann and Associate Artistic Director Stephanie C. Cunningham.  Wide Eyed has been producing in NYC for the last 8 years and exists to bring brave, bold and culturally relevant new texts to production.  With a core ensemble of emerging theatre artists they are dedicated to leaving audiences wide eyed. 

KEEP is an incredible story about a young hoarder, Naomi. Naomi is trapped in her home by her own belongings, unable to throw anything away after losing her only friend, Margo. When Naomi’s sisters surprise her with an intervention, she is forced to start cleaning her home. Her sisters don’t realize, however, that Naomi blames them for Margo’s disappearance, and that her resentment towards them grows larger the longer they clean. As Naomi extracts her revenge—trapping her sisters in her home.  We have assembled an amazing team that will only continue to grow and expand.  Madison, Kim and Jenna will have roles in this ensemble piece with exquisite direction from the wonderful Stephanie C. Cunningham.

What We Need & What You Get

Making theatre in New York City is EXPENSIVE and that's why we need YOUR help!  To rent our theater The Barrow Group is by itself $20,000.  No, that is not a typo. $20,000.  And that doesn't include:

**renting rehearsal space, costumes, set, lights, sound, props, designers, postcard/posters, PR company, PAYING ALL OF OUR ARTIST INVOLVED, and so much more.**

Our projected budget is $30,000.  We have already put down the initial down payment for the theater and will be covering the rest of our production expenses; what we are asking for is your help to cover the rest of the rental of the theater.

We are offering some pretty INCREDIBLE perks if you donate, listed on the side bar.  Also we are a 501(c)3, so all of your donations are TAX DEDUCTIBLE!! And no matter how much you give, big or small, we will be giving you a GIANT bear hug.  All of us.  At the same time if we are all near you.

The Impact

When Mastodon first started out we came to Indiegogo to help raise the funds for our first show.  We worked hard and were blessed to go above and beyond our fundraising goal of $5,000.  For the last two and a half years we have managed our money, hustled, sold out ours shows, and have been a self-sustaining company.  Now, paired with Wide Eyed, Mastodon is looking to take their company to the next level with a four week run of a great show in Midtown Manhattan.  We have proved that when we raise money we earn it back.  Let us show you once again that if you support us, we will give you an incredible product you will be proud to have invested in.

Wide Eyed has been producing for 8 years as a sustainable company and produced at The Barrow Group last year. They are a team of intelligent, hard working and driven artists who have proven time and again that they produce smart and successful theatre. 

KEEP is a gorgeous, compelling, female driven story that deserves to be heard and given a voice. By donating you are supporting new work, up and coming artists, and the theatre arts. Stories like these need to be told--they feed the soul and keep all of us connected to one another.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign! Send us your love! Tell us you think we rock (it makes us feel good)!

ANY contribution helps, even 1$, and remember, every donation is tax deductible, but If you can't donate today, please help us get the word out! Share with your friends, family, loved ones, neighbors, pets, employers, co-workers, EVERYONE!  Spreading the word is a huge help. Please share on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc. 

Thank you so much in advance!!  We can't wait to share this show with you!

story:
Our Story (...so far....)

PARADOX is a radical approach to theater as a live event, as a historical reality, as an agent for education and change within a community and on the internet. 

We are a new Theater Company! 

Joseph Campbell, following the writings of Carl Jung, argued for a very simple formula: Myths are public dreams and dreams are private myths. To this we can add that somewhere between our 'public dreams' and 'private myths,' there is Theater; and Theater is how we learn to believe.... Just as all good Fairy Tales begin with the words "Once upon a time..."; all good plays and all good performances begin with the idea "WHAT IF..."

Do you remember the first time you went to see live theater? You found your way to a seat, settled in among the crowd. Then the lights flashed two or three times; they dimmed until the entire theater was dark. In that moment, all of us experienced both the memory of the last thing we saw and anticipation for the next thing we might see. This sensation that we have all experienced is the essence of PARADOX. 

PARADOX insists that Theater has always been at its roots, a mad conflation of ritual, myth, folk wisdom, improvisation, spectacle and song. 

PARADOX stands on the knife's edge of this tradition, not just between dark and light, known and unknown, past and future, but between anticipation and fulfillment.

PARADOX is “…a radical approach to Theater,” dedicated to the idea "WHAT IF"....

 PARADOX presents:

THE WRONG SIDE OF EDEN….

A play by

 Kelly Knox, 

with Original Music by

Christopher Boyd Tressler. 

Lighting and Stage design by Michael Means 

 

Your contribution of any amount is greatly appreciated, not only to help us mount the current show, but to found the Theater Group PARADOX as well. Please keep reading, and follow us over the next several weeks as we strive to achieve our goals. 

About the Play: The Wrong Side of Eden

Imagine that someone is trying to tell the simple story of Jack and the Beanstalk. All of a sudden the characters begin to act-out other stories—the stories from age-old ritual and myth, on which fairytales like Jack and the Beanstalk are based. This sudden, quite unexpected development leads us in new and very strange directions. At several points during the play The Wrong Side of Eden, the actors, the director, a mysterious chorus (led by an even more mysterious “Prologue”) and even the crew burst through the fourth wall. It is "as if" in their attempt to resolve the more puzzling aspects of theatrical story-telling, they are revealing the cultural and historical conflicts resident in fairytales, myths and plays; in effect, they ironically dissolve the various media that created them….

Let's Get Started! 

We project that our first show will cost $10,000 to produce; but we also realize that it will cost much more to launch a theater. PARADOX is a very BIG project. Fortunately we have a plan. We have divided our budget into four basic categories:

First,  get organized:  We will secure enough funding to file the paper work to start our theater company; we will fund our first show, put up a website, hold auditions and start rehearsals. The money we raise will also be used to create promotional items like t-shirts, posters and photos--some will be perks; all will be for sale soon, in a virtual or actual lobby near you....

Second, find a temporary home: We will find a facility and everything practical; this includes rehearsal and performance space, lighting and equipment rentals, costumes and properties. This is not a "little theater"; it is not a "community theater"; we need to have a space that is our own, at least for the run of the show, where we can create, free from the limitations sometimes imposed on perofrmers in very conservative small towns.

Third, fill in the details: We will hire some personnel: to run the box office, the concessions and for security and maintenance. Of course it is very important that management of the company be set up legally so that every one is protected, everyone is insured against damages and injuries; and so there are as few disputes as possible over money. This may mean consulting with a lawyer or an accountant.

Fourth,  plan our next steps: Some money will be set aside for sustaining the run of the show and for paying the performers and principals. Ideally, the actors will have a proportional share in the profits from the show. We will include the whole company in product and website development and in the profits.

 

The fine print: We are confident that we will meet our goals!  As is often the case, in non-profit and small start up companies, careful records have to be kept detailing where the money was spent and by whom; and investors or contributors have a right to ask to see those records. 

The really really uber fine print: We are of course crazy to try to do this in a very conservative small town--or in three very conservative small towns. It will either be a very very cool thing, or a great big steaming heap of @#$%; the good news is, either way you get to watch it step by step, frame by frame, scene by scene--on the web! Well almost....

 

Remember:

Ecstasy transforms; Catharsis confirms; Theater appeases the gods....

story:
The play Goyang Penasaran (The Obsessive Twist) was first created and performed at Teater Garasi, Yogyakarta, December 14-16, 2011 presented by Naomi Srikandi and Teater Garasi with the support of Empowering Women Artists Kelola funded by Hivos, Ford Foundation, and Biyan. 


It received various enthusiastic responses and stimulating questions from the audience.


We are currently gathering funds to bring the piece to Jakarta as a part of the Women’s Festival at Teater Salihara, April 2012, to expand the dialogues on the pressing issues of sexuality, religion, and violence in Indonesia today.

 

The Play, the Political Context, and the Staging


Goyang Penasaran (The Obsessive Twist) is a play about Salimah, a female dangdut* singer from a small town, who has been admired, immortalized, and shunned by men. Set in the late 1990s, at the beginning of the Islamic resurgence in Indonesia, the story revolves around Salimah and her undying love for her old time religious teacher who now condemns her, and Solihin, who would do anything to have her after she humiliates him by refusing his proposal to take her as a second wife.


Goyang Penasaran (The Obsessive Twist) is a commentary on both the euphoria and the crisis of visibility after the downfall of Suharto’s authoritarian regime. After a long suppression by the regime, celebrations of sexuality as well as various expressions of Muslim public piety are now inseparable from the democratization package. On the bleaker side, the public sphere is now crowded with some groups who, in the name of religion, conduct violence against symbols of moral decadence, from dangdut shows to LGBT conferences and festivals.


Public policies ranging from the fatwas, the shariah laws, to the controversial Pornography Law testify for the anxieties around visibility that produce the question of what is allowed to be seen and what not.“Seeing,” thus, is a central motif in the play. Goyang Penasaran (The Obsessive Twist) poses a question on the economy of seeing/being seen within the intricate relationship between the sexuality discourse, politics, religion, and violence.


Exploring the possibilities in which the spectator could critically challenge their gaze on the condemned and eroticized body of a dangdut singer, the play experiments with an old tradition in theater: the cross-dressing practice. The performance deploys four male actors to play Solihin, Haji Ahmad the religious teacher, the thugs, and Salimah herself. Stylistically, it is an homage to classic Indonesian horror films and the heyday of dangdut music from the 1970s-1980s.


*Dangdut is a genre of Indonesian popular music that combines Malay, Arabic, Indian, Western, and Latin musical elements. Throughout the history it has been associated with the underclass, commodified, and politicized. In the past decade erotic dangdut dance has been part of the debates of national morality and religion.


 

The Team and the History

Goyang Penasaran (The Obsessive Twist) was first written as a short story by Intan Paramaditha, published in an anthology Kumpulan Budak Setan / The Devil Slaves Club (Jakarta: Gramedia Pustaka Utama, 2010). She and theater director Naomi Srikandi were involved in a discussion forum on gender and sexuality in the Symposium on Performance in Indonesia (Yogyakarta 2009). The forum participants discussed how the long list of discriminations against women and LGBT groups in the public sphere reveals that sexuality is a crucial site that reflects contemporary realities in Indonesia: the tension between civil society, frictions within the ideas of nationhood, and the pervasive sense of disbelief that characterizes the relationship between the citizens and the state.


Intan and Naomi decided to respond to these issues by committing themselves in the collaborative project Goyang Penasaran (The Obsessive Twist). They adapted Intan’s short story into a play, which would then be directed by Naomi. The complete team of Goyang Penasaran consists of Agung Kurniawan (art director), Ari Dwianto (actor), Ignatius Sugiarto (lighting and technical director), Intan Paramaditha (author of the original story, playwright), Irfanuddien Ghozali (actor), MN Qomaruddin (actor), Naomi Srikandi (playwright, director), Rifqi Mansur Maya (stage manager), Risky Summerbee (soundscape composer), Theodorus Christanto (actor, assistant director), Vidyahana Sinaga (costume and makeup artist), with production management by Ratri Kartika Sari and Teater Garasi.


For more information on Goyang Penasaran (The Obsessive Twist) and the team, please click

www.goyangpenasaran.teatergarasi.org


The Impact

We situate our project as a part of cultural activist works that promote freedom to express diverse voices in Indonesian society precisely when, as more clearly shown in the recent years, the state has failed to protect the basic rights of the individual, including the right not to be violated by others. As a complement to the performance we would also organize a discussion on how the performance of religion in public has been discussed and questioned in literature and theater in the past decade. With your donation you are supporting theater both as a form of artistic expression and cultural activism.


Public responses on the Yogyakarta production


“Provocative, subversive pulpy fun.” (Farah Wardani – art curator and critic)


“A must see for those who are into realism.” (Ifa Isfansyah – filmmaker)

“A combination of horror and a social commentary… Goyang Penasaran speaks at the right time – why are sex and women always to blame? The ghostly women appearing in the scenes bring sadness, anger, and mockery.” (Goenawan Mohamad – poet, playwright, essayist) 



What We Need & What You Get

Goyang Penasaran (The Obsessive Twist)in Yogyakarta was a site-specific performance. In order to stage the play in the (black box) theater of Salihara Jakarta we need to create a completely new set.

Komunitas Salihara has already committed to cover 40% of the budget we need. Your support will be meaningful to us in various aspects of production, including travel cost for the team members from Yogyakarta to Jakarta, the logistics, and the costs to re-create the stage in Jakarta, covering the set, props, costumes, and equipment rents. We will be able to pay our contributors for their dedication and commitment (with the budget we currently have, all the team members work as volunteers and are unpaid).

We are offering some fun perks to get you in the OBSESSIVE TWIST spirit while you provide us with vital support.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you could not support us financially, you could help us with the campaign by spreading the words to your friends and network and sharing the link on Twitter, Facebook, Google+, or email.


Thank you!
Goyang Penasaran (Obsessive Twist) Team

“Provocative, subversive pulpy fun.” (Farah Wardani – art curator and critic)

 “A must see for those who are into realism.” (Ifa Isfansyah – filmmaker)
“A combination of horror and a social commentary… Goyang Penasaran speaks at the right time – why are sex and women always to blame? The ghostly women appearing in the scenes bring sadness, anger, and mockery.” (Goenawan Mohamad – poet, playwright, essayist) 





What We Need & What You Get
Goyang Penasaran (The Obsessive Twist)in Yogyakarta was a site-specific performance. In order to stage the play in the (black box) theater of Salihara Jakarta we need to create a completely new set.
Komunitas Salihara has already committed to cover 40% of the budget we need. Your support will be meaningful to us in various aspects of production, including travel cost for the team members from Yogyakarta to Jakarta, the logistics, and the costs to re-create the stage in Jakarta, covering the set, props, costumes, and equipment rents. We will be able to pay our contributors for their dedication and commitment (with the budget we currently have, all the team members work as volunteers and are unpaid).
We are offering some fun perks to get you in the OBSESSIVE TWIST spirit while you provide us with vital support. 



Other Ways You Can Help
If you could not support us financially, you could help us with the campaign by spreading the words to your friends and network and sharing the link on Twitter, Facebook, Google+, or email.Thank you!Goyang Penasaran (Obsessive Twist) Team

story:
We've gathered a beautiful ensemble of theatre makers from around the world to devise a new adaptation of Richard Brautigan's novel  IN WATERMELON SUGAR, a strange and dazzling meditation on the imperfection of human endeavors.  This story, set in a world where the sun shines a different color every day;  the houses are made of watermelon sugar; and each inhabitant is marked by dreams of gorgeous and terrible talking tigers,  cracks open the myth of an American utopia. With the gift of space from SPACE at Ryder Farm, Christopher Burris, Megan Carter, Pia Furtado, Jason Liebman, Tina Mitchell and Kristen Sieh will spend five days developing the novel’s text into a play.

The workshop at Ryder Farm is the first phase of development for IN WATERMELON SUGAR and an absolutely necessary one.  The novel presents a magnificent theatrical challenge – it is almost entirely narrated; the community it depicts is trapped in a state of inertia; and the environment, though simple, has magical elements. The focus of the workshop at Ryder Farm is to activate the text from the ground up with actors and create a draft of the play.

Our $5000 fundraising goal includes travel and housing for an international ensemble of 6 artists, plus a workshop fee for each member of the acting company. Any additional funds raised will go toward subsequent development and production of IN WATERMELON SUGAR (aiming for full production in the summer of 2012).

No gift is too small to start us on this journey! $5, $10, $25 – all lovely numbers.

story:
"Diary of a Mid-Life Crisis"

After almost 18 years in an emotionally abusive relationship, I decided to start my life over again.  Not an easy thing to do at 43. 

Because my friends were interested in what was going on with me, I did what everyone else was doing - I started a blog.  http://diaryofamidlifecrisis.blogspot.com

I figured the dozen people in my immediate circle would be the ones to read it, that no one else would be interested. 

I was wrong.  I started getting comments from women (and men) around the world who had started their lives over or were struggling with an abusive situation or just struggling with trying to figure out life. 

After a great deal of encouragement, I decided to turn this little meandering missive into a stage play.

And so here we are.

"Diary of a Mid-Life Crisis" follows one woman as she begins the journey to rediscover her life.  She deals with her emotionally abusive ex and the tangle of emotions that follow her as she tries to push away the past in order to find her future.  She discovers love - platonic, unrequited and everything in between.  She even has a few close encounters with Jesus... but not in the way you'd think.  Oh, and there will be bad poetry.  Consider yourself warned.

Along the way, she discovers that there are no big answers, only a million tiny ones along the way.

Of course, "Diary" won't be your typical one woman "oh, sad me in a spotlight with a microphone" show.  Nope. There will be clowns - mean, nasty ones that live in her head.  Sock puppets.  Martial arts.  And a pie fight.  Maybe two. 

The Impact

There is a universality in "Diary" that reaches across gender and age.  We all struggle to figure out just who the hell we are and how the hell we fit into the world.  As well, the issue of emotional abuse is often not discussed and it is a topic that needs to be brought to light. 


I intend to donate 16% of any profits to Sojourn, a shelter for women who are victims of domestic violence.


http://www.opcc.net/OurProjects/Sojourn/tabid/8...


The opening night performance will also be dedicated to Sojourn and a special fundraising effort will happen for that evening.


This project ain't "Eat, Pray, Love".  It's a voice that's not often heard - true, honest, brutal.  Too many books out there give women the fantasy of recovering from their troubles in Tuscany with hot young Italian men.  You know what?  Ain't gonna happen.  "Diary" will give it to you real, whether you want it or not.


What We Need & What You Get


I need to raise $300 for a deposit on the theater to get the show locked.  I am a resident director at Eclectic Company Theatre, where the show will be performed, but I do still need to put money down to hold my dates.  If I don't raise the money, I may be in danger of losing my production dates.

If I raise more than $300, anything over and above that will go to paying production costs - paying the stage manager and designers, actors, etc.  I get paid last so I won't see any money out of this fundraising push.

Any amount will help.  $5, $10, $250 or $500.  Skip your latte and help small theater!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, maybe there's some way you could contribute to the production with in-kind contributions.  Host our opening night party, contribute advertising, contribute props or set pieces.  Anything that will help.


The biggest way everyone can help is to spread the word.  Facebook me, Twitter, use the social networking verb of your choice.

story:
Yes, we know, it’s been done before, BUT OUR VERSION WILL ROCK! From the director of the infamous Two Gentlemen of Lebowski and the notorious Bitch Macbeth comes the Halloween spectacular to end all Halloween spectaculars! This production will play late nights in Brooklyn’s hip and happening Brick Theater this October and we need your help to make it as awesome as possible.

Sure, the movie may be cheap, but that was over 50 years ago, and with inflation and all… I mean, have you seen the cost of flying saucer model kits these days? Seriously.

Anyhoo, we know that because you think this is the best idea in the history of the world, you’re ready and willing to help us live the dream and bring the world of Bela, Vampira, Criswell, and all the rest to vivid, sickly life. And, in case you’re not willing and able, we have quite a few enticements that should make you want to crack open that wallet and GIVE BABY GIVE…

Plus, anyone who donates at least $1 will receive video updates giving you the lowdown on the show’s progress, and exclusive content! AND ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE TO THE EXTENT PERMITTED BY LAW! DMTheatrics is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions in behalf of DMTheatrics may be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. With each contribution you will receive a tax receipt from Fractured Atlas. See the perks for exact refundable info.

The incidents! The places! We must punish the guilty! We must reward the innocent! My friends, can your heart stand the shocking facts about PLAN NINE FROM OUTER SPACE! Help us make this happen!

CLICK THROUGH TO GALLERY TO SEE THE TRAILER!

story:
Marilyn is an original piece of inter(act)ive dinner/ dance/ story theater that explores our relationship to our bodies through the vehicle of Marilyn Monroe. Alison Haracznack and Bonnie Gabel of Night Light Collective have been working on the piece for 8 months, and it is set to premiere in a home in the Marigny at the New Orleans Fringe Festival this November.


Our Story

We both have battled with body image most of our lives, turning to extreme measures-anorexia, bulemia, and self mutilation- to fit into an impossible mold. As we mature into out twenties we find other women, men, boys, and girls struggling with this impossible standard. What are we ashamed of? Why is it so hard to look honestly and lovingly at our own naked bodies? How can we deconstruct what is beautiful, and create a space for all of us to love our bodies in all of their individual glory? Join us for the ride (and put a bit of your two-cents in as well).

The Impact

Marilyn is trying to bring a little bit of healing, hope, and glitter to all the dark spots wrapped around how we view our bodies. You can help us buy the glitter.


What We Need & What You Get

$25 for a blonde wig

$25 for Marilyn's make up

$45 for 1950's period underwear

$100 for the white dress

$200 to set up Marilyn's house

$150 for publicity (photos, posters, etc)

$200 Fringe Application

$200 to pay for the complete invasion of our hosts home

$200 for insurance (just in case!)


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell all your friends-Like Night Light Collective on Facebook-Follow us on Twitter-Come out and support the New Orleans Fringe Fest-Buy a bull horn and scream for us uptown downtown all over town-or buy us the bullhorn and we'll do the screaming

story:
NORD-OST MUSICAL @ JETLAG FESTIVAL:  LET'S MAKE IT OURS! 

We are JETLAG, the international multicultural festival, created by a team of American Russian music-lovers. For five years we have been producing this annual celebration of diversity, happiness and good taste, transcending linguistic, cultural and ideological ''jetlags''. 

For five years we have been surprising people (and even ourselves!) with unforgettable encounters and discoveries... But this time we have a craving to do something really extraordinary. 

We want to bring NORD-OST! 

This legendary Moscow musical of a most dramatic fate has become a symbol of hope, heroism and optimism. A gang of Moscow "Bob Dylans" turned a Soviet popular classic novel about polar explorers into the pioneer Russian musical, which mesmerized, inspired and united lots of Russians and visitors. 

The triumphant march of the musical was interrupted by a terrorist attack that took place at the show in Moscow, 2002. After a decade-long hiatus, the team gave birth to a warm and vibrant, festival-friendly concert version of the musical - potentially a powerful headliner at JETLAG-2014. 

Each donation will contribute to re-invigorate this event. LET'S MAKE IT OUR COLLECTIVE EFFORT.  As a sponsor, you will be directly contributing to JETLAG-2014's expenses with regards to travel, visas, and accommodations for the 10 cast members of Nord-Ost.

Each of you (or, rather, each of us!) will get this memorable (and practical!) gift - an EXCLUSIVE FLASK with Olya Chikina's drawing, with the famous line from the musical, the novel and, originally, from Tennyson: ''БОРОТЬСЯ И ИСКАТЬ, НАЙТИ И НЕ СДАВАТЬСЯ (i.e. To strike, to seek, to find, and not to yield)"

                                   $25                                                        $100 and more

We actually need to collect $5000 and even small contribution helps. As well as spreading the word via indiegogo tools. 

All contributor names will be publicly displayed on the Wall of Fame at the JetLAG festival main stage, unless opt out.

NORD-OST MUSICAL @ JETLAG FESTIVAL:  LET'S MAKE IT OURS!

story:
Update!

Thanks to all who helped us reach our goal!

While  our campaign has ended, we still have production expenses that we hope to cover with donations.

You may still donate at https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=9873

We need your support to bring this exciting new musical to the stage at OBERON in Boston for its world premiere on May 29 and 30, 2014. We believe The Weaver of Raveloe deserves the widest possible audience and our goal is to take it to Broadway and beyond. This premiere is an important step in that journey--a step we can only take with your help.

Please consider donating whatever you can.

The Show

The Weaver of Raveloe is a new musical by Erica Glenn and Melissa Leilani Larson based on George Eliot's Silas Marner. The musical tells the timeless story of a reclusive weaver who must flee his hometown after he is accused of murder.  Silas is forced to confront past ghosts and re-discover the importance of human connection in this classic tale of love, loss, and healing. 

Learn more at weaverofraveloe.com. Contact us at info@weaverofraveloe.com.

Our Journey

The journey of a musical to the stage always begins with an idea, with a spark of inspiration. Composer, lyricist, and book co-writer Erica Glenn (ericaglenn.com) recalls how she came to write The Weaver of Raveloe:

I remember pulling George Eliot's Silas Marner from a dusty corner years ago and falling quickly and irreversibly in love with this literary gem. Accused of a crime he didn't commit and abandoned by the woman he loves, Silas becomes a reclusive weaver in a village with secrets of its own--secrets which ultimately drive him to confront the ghosts of his past. Primarily a multi-layered love story, Silas Marner is also a parable of industrialization, a morality tale, and a good, old-fashioned drama. It combines the sweeping themes of a story like Les Miserables with the psychological depth of one likeThe Secret Garden. It is a drama of epic proportions that somehow never loses its intimacy and humanity—a musical just waiting to be written.
In 2010, the first incarnation of the script was workshopped at Brigham Young University under the direction of George Nelson. The following year, the Salty Cricket Composers Collective performed excerpts from the show at the Rose Wagner Performing Arts Center. In 2012, The Weaver of Raveloe was accepted to the prestigious New York Musical Theatre Festival as a developmental reading. The show had three unstaged performances off-off-Broadway at the 45th Street Theater that July and received extensive feedback from audience members and industry professionals. 

So far on this journey, the musical has received media coverage at BroadwayWorld.com and Deseret News. The Broadway composing community has also taken notice of The Weaver of Raveloe. Charles Strouse, the Tony Award-winning composer of Annie and Bye, Bye Birdie!, has called the music "full of drama and rich in harmonic and melodic substance." According to Jill Santoriello, composer of Tale of Two Cities: The Musical, the show demonstrates "an impressive blending of feeling and craft.  Emotional music soars alongside lyrics that are smart and sensitive, faithful to this classic story and its characters."   

In 2013, award-winning playwright Melissa Leilani Larson (melissaleilanilarson.com) joined the project as a book co-writer.Along with Glenn and Larson, an entire team of directors, designers, orchestrators, actors, and other theatre professionals is now hard at work to bring The Weaver of Raveloe to the stage in its world premiere on May 29 and 30, 2014. In association with the Arts in Education Program at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, this production is being presented at OBERON, which describes itself as "the A.R.T.’s second stage, a destination for theater and nightlife on the fringe of Harvard Square." .  

 All of us involved in the production believe this show deserves to reach the widest possible audience on Broadway and beyond. 

Your Impact

We need your help to make our world premiere a success!

The Weaver of Raveloe must generate a minimum of $15,000 (in funds or in-kind support) to make our vision a reality.  Unlike the NYMF reading (pictured above), the OBERON premiere will include costumes, sets, props, lighting, sound effects, amplification, and professional musicians. In addition, there are expenses for insurance, venue and equipment rental, web hosting, mailing, printing, dry cleaning, storage, and more. We are also producing a cast album and video recording.

We are relying heavily on individual donations to secure our venue and cover production expenses. We are also interested in reaching out to corporations, arts councils, and foundations.

Every donation is sincerely appreciated. Every donation helps. Every donation is tax-deductible. Thank you for helping bring The Weaver of Raveloe to the stage.

Ways to Help
  • Donate here!
  • Share our Indiegogo link with friends: http://igg.me/at/weaver-of-raveloe
  • Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/weaverofraveloe
  • Follow us on Twitter: @WeaverofRaveloe
  • Visit our website: http://www.weaverofraveloe.com/
  • Volunteer to help with the production by emailing: producer@weaverofraveloe.com
Our Team

Erica Glenn (Writer/Composer/Book co-Writer) holds an M.M. in Music Composition from the Longy School of Music and a bachelor's in Music Theory and Composition with an emphasis in piano performance from Arizona State University and is currently completing a graduate degree at Harvard.  Erica's classical compositions have been performed under the direction of Sam Pilafin (founder of the Empire Brass Quintet); Steinway Artist, Walter Cosand; Longitude conductor, Paul Brust; and St. Lawrence String Quartet cellist, Christopher Costanza.  She won the 2006 Chanticleer Student Composer Competition, the 2007 International VocalWorks Opera-in-a-Month Competition, and the 2011 and 2012 Longy Processional/Recessional Competitions which culminated in performances by the Redline Brass Quintet. 

Erica has taught professionally and directed music programs for various organizations throughout Boston and New York where she also worked as an arranger and music director for Charles Strouse (composer of Annie, Bye-Bye Birdie).  Notable mentors include John Corigliano, Jason Robert Brown, and Richard Maltby.  Erica's choral compositions have been commissioned by groups across America, and in 2000, her full-length musical, Dancing Shoes, was awarded “Best Play of the Year” at the Valley Center Playhouse. In 2004, her children’s musical, Between the Lines, placed first in the VIP Arts Competition. Erica currently publishes with LazyBee Scripts, and her shows have received performances throughout the US, the UK, and as far away as Hong Kong, Spain, Germany, Australia, and Ukraine. (See ericaglenn.com)

Melissa Leilani Larson (Book co-Writer) “writes dialogue with a directness and simple eloquence.” Her plays been produced all over the country. Martyrs’ Crossing (IRAM Best New Play) had its international premiere at the 2013 Edinburgh Festival Fringe. Melissa’s first commission, an adaptation of Pride and Prejudice, opens at Brigham Young University in March. Produced plays include Persuasion; Little Happy Secrets (AML Drama award, SLAC Fringe selection); A Flickering (Trustus Festival Finalist); Standing Still Standing (Mayhew Award); Lady in Waiting (Lewis National Playwriting Contest for Women winner); Hope Falls; and The Church of St. Pinky at Katy, Texas. Works in progress include Gaskell’s North and South and Alcott’s Little Women as well as an original piece, Pilot Program.

Melissa is a proud member of the Dramatists Guild of America, a certified KC/ACTF adjudicator, an AEA EMC stage manager, and a member of Plan-B Theatre’s Playwrights Lab. She holds a BA in English from BYU and an MFA from the Iowa Playwrights Workshop. (See melissaleilanilarson.com)

Michael Morris (Producer) has 25 years of performing arts experience as a producer, director, dramaturg, sound and costume designer, and performer in professional, community, and academic settings. Michael has worked and traveled globally in Australia, Belarus, Canada, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, Mexico, Norway, Russia, Sweden, and Ukraine.  His experience includes leading strategic HR and PR projects in Fortune 1000 companies.

Currently, he is a doctoral candidate in the department of drama at Tufts University, where he also received his MA. He received an AB in Russian literature from Harvard University and an MBA with an emphasis in organizational behavior from Brigham Young University. He has presented research at meetings of the American Society for Theatre Research, Mid-America Theatre Conference, and the Western Academy of Management. Michael is a member of the American Guild of Musical Artists, Literary Managers and Dramaturgs of the Americas, Academy of Management, American Society for Theatre Research, and Association for Theatre in Higher Education. 

Contact us at info@weaverofraveloe.com.

Update!
Thanks to all who helped us reach our goal!
While  our campaign has ended, we still have production expenses that we hope to cover with donations.
You may still donate at https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=9873
We need your support to bring this exciting new musical to the stage at OBERON in Boston for its world premiere on May 29 and 30, 2014. We believe The Weaver of Raveloe deserves the widest possible audience and our goal is to take it to Broadway and beyond. This premiere is an important step in that journey--a step we can only take with your help.
Please consider donating whatever you can.
The Show
The Weaver of Raveloe is a new musical by Erica Glenn and Melissa Leilani Larson based on George Eliot's Silas Marner. The musical tells the timeless story of a reclusive weaver who must flee his hometown after he is accused of murder.  Silas is forced to confront past ghosts and re-discover the importance of human connection in this classic tale of love, loss, and healing. Learn more at weaverofraveloe.com. Contact us at info@weaverofraveloe.com.
Our Journey
The journey of a musical to the stage always begins with an idea, with a spark of inspiration. Composer, lyricist, and book co-writer Erica Glenn (ericaglenn.com) recalls how she came to write The Weaver of Raveloe:
 I remember pulling George Eliot's Silas Marner from a dusty corner years ago and falling quickly and irreversibly in love with this literary gem. Accused of a crime he didn't commit and abandoned by the woman he loves, Silas becomes a reclusive weaver in a village with secrets of its own--secrets which ultimately drive him to confront the ghosts of his past. Primarily a multi-layered love story, Silas Marner is also a parable of industrialization, a morality tale, and a good, old-fashioned drama. It combines the sweeping themes of a story like Les Miserables with the psychological depth of one likeThe Secret Garden. It is a drama of epic proportions that somehow never loses its intimacy and humanity—a musical just waiting to be written.

In 2010, the first incarnation of the script was workshopped at Brigham Young University under the direction of George Nelson. The following year, the Salty Cricket Composers Collective performed excerpts from the show at the Rose Wagner Performing Arts Center. In 2012, The Weaver of Raveloe was accepted to the prestigious New York Musical Theatre Festival as a developmental reading. The show had three unstaged performances off-off-Broadway at the 45th Street Theater that July and received extensive feedback from audience members and industry professionals. So far on this journey, the musical has received media coverage at BroadwayWorld.com and Deseret News. The Broadway composing community has also taken notice of The Weaver of Raveloe. Charles Strouse, the Tony Award-winning composer of Annie and Bye, Bye Birdie!, has called the music "full of drama and rich in harmonic and melodic substance." According to Jill Santoriello, composer of Tale of Two Cities: The Musical, the show demonstrates "an impressive blending of feeling and craft.  Emotional music soars alongside lyrics that are smart and sensitive, faithful to this classic story and its characters."   In 2013, award-winning playwright Melissa Leilani Larson (melissaleilanilarson.com) joined the project as a book co-writer.Along with Glenn and Larson, an entire team of directors, designers, orchestrators, actors, and other theatre professionals is now hard at work to bring The Weaver of Raveloe to the stage in its world premiere on May 29 and 30, 2014. In association with the Arts in Education Program at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, this production is being presented at OBERON, which describes itself as "the A.R.T.’s second stage, a destination for theater and nightlife on the fringe of Harvard Square." .  




 All of us involved in the production believe this show deserves to reach the widest possible audience on Broadway and beyond. Your Impact
We need your help to make our world premiere a success!The Weaver of Raveloe must generate a minimum of $15,000 (in funds or in-kind support) to make our vision a reality.  Unlike the NYMF reading (pictured above), the OBERON premiere will include costumes, sets, props, lighting, sound effects, amplification, and professional musicians. In addition, there are expenses for insurance, venue and equipment rental, web hosting, mailing, printing, dry cleaning, storage, and more. We are also producing a cast album and video recording.We are relying heavily on individual donations to secure our venue and cover production expenses. We are also interested in reaching out to corporations, arts councils, and foundations.
Every donation is sincerely appreciated. Every donation helps. Every donation is tax-deductible. Thank you for helping bring The Weaver of Raveloe to the stage.
Ways to Help
Donate here!

Share our Indiegogo link with friends: http://igg.me/at/weaver-of-raveloe


Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/weaverofraveloe


Follow us on Twitter: @WeaverofRaveloe


Visit our website: http://www.weaverofraveloe.com/

Volunteer to help with the production by emailing: producer@weaverofraveloe.com
Our Team
Erica Glenn (Writer/Composer/Book co-Writer) holds an M.M. in Music Composition from the Longy School of Music and a bachelor's in Music Theory and Composition with an emphasis in piano performance from Arizona State University and is currently completing a graduate degree at Harvard.  Erica's classical compositions have been performed under the direction of Sam Pilafin (founder of the Empire Brass Quintet); Steinway Artist, Walter Cosand; Longitude conductor, Paul Brust; and St. Lawrence String Quartet cellist, Christopher Costanza.  She won the 2006 Chanticleer Student Composer Competition, the 2007 International VocalWorks Opera-in-a-Month Competition, and the 2011 and 2012 Longy Processional/Recessional Competitions which culminated in performances by the Redline Brass Quintet. Erica has taught professionally and directed music programs for various organizations throughout Boston and New York where she also worked as an arranger and music director for Charles Strouse (composer of Annie, Bye-Bye Birdie).  Notable mentors include John Corigliano, Jason Robert Brown, and Richard Maltby.  Erica's choral compositions have been commissioned by groups across America, and in 2000, her full-length musical, Dancing Shoes, was awarded “Best Play of the Year” at the Valley Center Playhouse. In 2004, her children’s musical, Between the Lines, placed first in the VIP Arts Competition. Erica currently publishes with LazyBee Scripts, and her shows have received performances throughout the US, the UK, and as far away as Hong Kong, Spain, Germany, Australia, and Ukraine. (See ericaglenn.com)


Melissa Leilani Larson (Book co-Writer) “writes dialogue with a
directness and simple eloquence.” Her plays been produced all over the
country. Martyrs’ Crossing (IRAM Best New Play) had its
international premiere at the 2013 Edinburgh Festival Fringe. Melissa’s first
commission, an adaptation of Pride and Prejudice, opens at Brigham Young
University in March. Produced plays include Persuasion; Little Happy
Secrets (AML Drama award, SLAC Fringe selection); A Flickering (Trustus
Festival Finalist); Standing Still Standing (Mayhew Award); Lady in
Waiting (Lewis National Playwriting Contest for Women winner); Hope
Falls; and The Church of St. Pinky at Katy, Texas. Works in progress
include Gaskell’s North and South and Alcott’s Little Women as
well as an original piece, Pilot Program.
Melissa
is a proud member of the Dramatists Guild of America, a certified KC/ACTF
adjudicator, an AEA EMC stage manager, and a member of Plan-B Theatre’s
Playwrights Lab. She holds a BA in English from BYU and an MFA from the Iowa
Playwrights Workshop. (See melissaleilanilarson.com)


Michael Morris (Producer) has 25 years of performing arts experience as a producer, director, dramaturg, sound and costume designer, and performer in professional, community, and academic settings. Michael has worked and traveled globally in Australia, Belarus, Canada, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, Mexico, Norway, Russia, Sweden, and Ukraine.  His experience includes leading strategic HR and PR projects in Fortune 1000 companies.Currently, he is a doctoral candidate in the
department of drama at Tufts University, where he also received his MA. He
received an AB in Russian literature from Harvard University and an MBA with an
emphasis in organizational behavior from Brigham Young University. He has presented research at meetings of the American
Society for Theatre Research, Mid-America Theatre Conference, and the Western
Academy of Management. Michael is a member of the American Guild
of Musical Artists, Literary Managers and Dramaturgs of the Americas, Academy
of Management, American Society for Theatre Research, and Association for Theatre
in Higher Education. Contact us at info@weaverofraveloe.com.

story:
About Shakespeare's VILLAINS

Imagine if Shakespeare's best villains were taken out of their respective plays, reassembled Frankenstein-style, and finally got to be the focus of their own stories. The California Shakespeare Ensemble does just that in Shakespeare's VILLAINS as they weave three of the Bard's finest antagonists into one engaging 70-minute show, using only Shakespeare's original words. 

The show follows three of Shakespeare's villains--Shylock (Merchant of Venice), Macbeth (Macbeth), and Tybalt (Romeo and Juliet)--using Shakespeare's original words and their own separate stories, but with a new adaptation and edit by CSE Artistic Director Brian Elerding.

What the hell is going on?

The show sold out its run in Los Angeles at the end of 2013. Let's take it to the world at the Ediburgh Fringe Festival in 2014!

Shakespeare's VILLAINS hit a sweet spot for our company by providing extraordinary characters to brilliant actors. Mixing three of Shakespeare's stories into one play turned out to be a big success.

The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the biggest and most extraordinary event for independent theater in the world. Over a million people attend from all over the globe, and some of the best small, funky companies bring their projects there to share. We'd like to join that gang.

After the Edinburgh Fringe, Shakespeare's VILLAINS will return to Los Angeles for a full run. 

What We Need & What You Get

The CSE has never asked for donations before; we've always funded our productions from ticket revenue and commissions...we're fundraising NOW because this is way bigger than anything we've done before, and we're growing!

The funding goes to everything from venue rental to travel arrangements to promotion. A lot of factors have to come together for our three week odyssey, which is why getting ourselves sorted financially is crucial. By donating to this campaign you'll bring Shakespeare's VILLAINS to the international stage. 

By supporting the project, you can also get perks like tickets to a performance of the show in Los Angeles, all the way up to private performances. If you're more of a merch-minded type, we've got mugs, shirts and scripts available too!

If, by some misfortune, we don't fulfill our goal on Indiegogo and literally every last thing falls through for this project financially, left-over funds will go to the California Shakespeare Ensemble for our local remount of VILLAINS, and everyone still gets their nifty perks. So it's a win-win situation!

The Impact

The impact of your donation is literally the difference between going to Edinburgh for the Fringe Fest on one hand, and not going on the other. 

The Team

The California Shakespeare Ensemble is a group of professional actors who work in TV, Film and Theater in Los Angeles. The Ensemble performs classical theater and new works, and is also part of the public programming of Descanso Gardens. More about the Ensemble: www.californiashakespeare.org 

The cast includes: J.R. Davidson, Brian Elerding, Roddy Jessup, Aaron Leddick, Jeremy Radin, Shahaub Roudbari, Kate Siegel, and Samantha Sloyan

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to help us get to Edinburgh. Check out our videos, and if you like 'em, post em! Like us and share our posts on Facebook! Get web traffic coming to this campaign webpage or our homepage at www.californiashakespeare.org. Watching our videos will help them get more exposure. And, if you like what we do, bring friends to see our local shows. What makes live theater the magical experience it can be is the live audience.  You, in a seat at the theaer, is the most important way you can support us, and we can bring you the thing we love.

story:
Summary

Introduction

It is with joy and great anticipation that we would like to announce to you the new program by the Austin Eurythmy Ensemble: Project Zero Circle: - beginnings. We are inviting you to join the birthing process of this new artistic project; to nurture our forces of initiative with your freely given donation. By investing in this new impulse you will have the opportunity to co-create with us the future seeds for the Art of Eurythmy.

Project 

The members of this project include: Andrea and Markus Weder, eurythmists; Jeremiah Turner, speech artist; Risa Ando, violinist and Jun Seo, cellist. The Project Zero Circle: - beginnings performance will be performed in two parts with a short intermission. The first part consists of an interwoven sequence of poetry by Denis Levertov and the Sonata for Violin and Cello by Maurice Ravel. We feel the outspoken beauty of this poetry acutely reflects the consciousness of our time, in its spiritual meaning and its bold structure; it is truly prophetic poetry for the 21st century. The composition by Maurice Ravel presents us with a full palette of feelings in its varied colors and moods: from delicate lyricism to moments of joyful exuberance to expressions of deep sorrow and pain – the highest and lowest parts of our human existence. The second part of the program continues the exploration of our inner lives:  Japanese Tankas (modern, short Haikus) and the Preludes for Violoncello by Sofia Gubaidulina. The Tankas are poignant imaginations of soul events, at times poetic and transcendent and in other instances absurd and humorous.  The pieces for violoncello are contemporary, short and succinct, a lively adventure into new soul and soundscapes.

Background

Andrea Weder was born in Germany. Andrea graduated from the London School of Eurythmy after previous training and free- lance work as a sculptor. Markus Weder was born in Switzerland, where he studied curative education before training Eurythmy at the “Akademie fuer Eurythmische Kunst” in Dornach, Switzerland, and at “Eurythmy Spring Valley”, NY.  Andrea and Markus toured together internationally as performers, directors and master teachers with Eurythmy Spring Valley (from 1991- 1996) and the Austin Eurythmy Ensemble (since 1996). They taught for ten years as Artist-In-Residence at the Austin Waldorf School. Andrea and Markus are the founders and Artistic Directors of the Austin Eurythmy Ensemble and initiated the Austin Youth Eurythmy Troupe (AWS High School Eurythmy Troupe, 1999- 2007) and the “International Summer Eurythmy Academy” (2003- 2007). Since 2008 they have been the Project Leaders of the new professional full-time eurythmy training “im- pulse. eurythmy, International Eurythmy Studies” in Austin, USA and Dornach, Switzerland. They are currently free- lancing as performing eurythmists for the Project Zero Circle - beginnings production.

Campaign

With this campaign we are searching funding for production costs and touring expenditures. We are planning to premier our project on March 29, 2014 in Austin, TX and to bring it on tour to venues in California, Switzerland (Goetheanum, Dornach) and Scotland in May/ June 2014. Parts of the funding will also be dedicated for a new documentary video about our work and striving with this project. 

We are offering our performances on tour for the first time with the gift- economy idea. Meaning our performances are given as a gift, free of charge for the hosting presenters. We are suggesting freely given contributions towards our expenditures and informed investments towards our future artistic work. This fact makes our crowd- funding initiative especially crucial and relevant for the well- being of our arts organization.

Your generous contribution will enable us to go ahead with our ambitious and courageous plans!


What is Eurythmy:

What is only heard is partly hidden.

The rustle of the leaves gently swaying in the wind, the flap of the bird’s rapid ascent, the sigh of a contented child.

There is a deeper experience of sound, one that arises out of our most intimate connection to the world – to the earth, to each other, to the intangible qualities of being alive.  The inner life of sound reveals visible form.

“As in the ear, so also in the eye.”

The fullness of the words of the poet, the static form of the pianist’s ode – these are portals into the fluid sculpture that speech and music create in the physical space of our world.

Eurythmy is harmonious rhythm. 

The eurythmist, by observing the structural laws of speech and music, reveals the inner life of language and sound, creating a composition that uses the stage as a three-dimensional canvas.

By joining with that which moves through the air as tone or language, the eurythmist harmonizes with sound.

In this way, the body is an instrument.  It is no different than a flute or a violin, no different than a voice.  Through skilled observation of the laws inherent in speech and music, eurythmy makes visible the invisible form of sound.

Eurythmy is not interpretation; it is a true sounding or singing through the body.


What We Need & What You Get

Budget 

Total Budget $39,800

Revenues:

  • Secured Grants $10,000
  • Secured Donations from our Circle of Friends $4000
  • Projected Suggested Donations from Performances $11,000
  • Projected additional Grants $ 7000
  • Needed at least $ 7800

Expenses:

  • Artist Fees $ 13,400
  • Technical and administrative support $ 3600
  • Costumes $500
  • Rentals $400
  • Webpage/ Design/ Publicity $ 2000
  • Video $ 2000
  • Travel costs $14,900
  • Others $3000

Your support would go directly towards our travel costs and the video production.

What you get

With your investment in our project you will get to co- own our future activities. Our perks will provide you with some special treats for the different funding categories. The Austin Eurythmy Ensemble is a recognized 501(c)3 tax- exempt organization and your donation will be fully tax- deductible. A tax- deductible form confirming your donation will be sent to you.

  • Contributor $10: Personal card.
  • Friend $50: Personal card plus photo.
  • Supporter $100: Personal card, photo and invitation to an open rehearsal in Austin or on our tour in the season 2014.
  • Donor $250: Personal card, photo and a free ticket to a performance in Austin or on tour in the season 2014.
  • Benefactor $500: Personal card, photo plus 2 free tickets to a performance in Austin or on tour in the season 2014.
  • Guardian $1000: Personal card, photo, 2 free tickets to a performance in Austin or on tour in the season 2014 plus a dinner for two with Andrea and Markus Weder. 
  • Redeemer $2500: Personal card, photo, 2 free tickets to a performance in Austin or on tour in the season 2014 and a free workshop/ demonstration to an audience of your choice in Austin in the season 2014 plus a dinner for two with Andrea and Markus Weder.
  • Initiator $5000: Personal card, photo, 2 free tickets to a performance in Austin or on tour in the season 2014 and a free presentation to an audience of your choice in Austin in the season 2014 plus a dinner for two with Andrea and Markus Weder.

Impact

With your generous contribution you will share in our intention and strivings to bring our mission to full fruition in our present and future work.

Mission

The Austin Eurythmy Ensemble cherishes the spiritual wisdom of the human body in motion. By promoting social harmony and spiritual renewal, we seek to achieve individual, cultural, and global transformation. Rooted in the tradition of eurythmy as inaugurated by Rudolf Steiner and yet contemporary in artistic approach, the Ensemble intends to make this art form a relevant part of today’s cultural life. We are carrying eurythmy into the future by performing internationally and educating future generations of eurythmists. Our envisioned state- of-the- arts rehearsal and performance center will include an International Eurythmy Academy. This center will serve as a meeting place for visual, literary, and performing artists to inspire each other and for the spiritually curious and artistically inclined to build community.

History

The Austin Eurythmy Ensemble (www.austineurythmy.org) was founded in 1996. As a performing eurythmy troupe they have initiated incredibly satisfying performance work, whirlwind tours, amazing professional and artistic collaboration as well as important alliances and relationships.

  Over the course of years, the ensemble has grown on many different levels from their beginnings as a 4-member troupe moving from Spring Valley, New York, to Austin, Texas, into a mature troupe of professional artists complete with a devoted Circle of Friends and deeply satisfying professional relationships.

  Having been granted the unique position of artists-in-residence upon their arrival in the US, Markus and Andrea Weder have been able to continue their work as professional eurythmists while at the same time enjoying the inspiring and challenging work of teaching eurythmy at the Austin Waldorf School (1996- 2007).  Providing the school with consistent, high quality eurythmy instruction, which resulted in programs such as the Austin Youth Eurythmy Troupe (1999- 2007), an extra-curricular high school troupe, and the first ever International High School Eurythmy Festival (2004). All this is stemming from, and nurturing a particular passion of the eurythmists to work intensely with youth.

  Since their inception, the group has produced and performed over five different evening programs and numerous children’s programs, traveling across the U.S., Canada and Europe in at least ten extensive performance tours.  Much to their delight, audiences have been very receptive, and generous with praise, commenting on the depth, eloquence, sophistication, precision and quality of cohesion that the ensemble brings to the stage.

  It is important to point out the relationships these eurythmists have cultivated and enjoyed with their collaborative artists, for the nature of their art is to make visible the world of music and speech. Their creations have only been made possible through these indispensable and inspiring collaborations with supporting musicians and speech artists. These fellow artists have offered their talent and expertise in helping to shape the ensemble into its present form.  

  The ensemble has always pursued many opportunities to further develop the presence of eurythmy in the world.  Along those lines, one of the most important manifestations has been the Summer Eurythmy Academy (2003- 2007 in the US, Brazil, South Africa and Switzerland).  In these recurring month-long intensives, graduates of Waldorf education could more fully explore the art of eurythmy as it relates not only to performance work, but also to self-development. The momentum of this work inspired the initiation of a new professional eurythmy training.

 The im-pulse.eurythmy, International Eurythmy Studies (www.impulse-eurythmy.org) was inaugurated in 2008. It is a completely new approach to a professional eurythmy training on the college level. In addition to Austin, TX, the home base of the training, students travelled to campuses in Dornach, Switzerland and Sao Paolo, Brazil. The first course (2008- 2011) was specially tailored to the needs of Waldorf School Alumni from the U.S., Brazil and Switzerland with prior extensive experience in eurythmy. This three year long, full- time course is recognized by the Section for Eurythmy, Speech, Drama and Music at the Goetheanum, Dornach, Switzerland, the worldwide center of the Eurythmy movement.

  In another effort to bring eurythmy to more visibility, the ensemble has branched out into the public sphere with workshops, lecture/demonstrations, and public performances at local venues such as theaters and museums.  With the new Project Zero Circle: -beginnings more of such work is envisioned

  As they continue touring and performing and mentoring youth, the ensemble remains devoted to bringing eurythmy ever more fully into human consciousness.

Other Ways You Can Help

Regardless if you are in a position to contribute to our project you can support us by sharing our campaign and events via social media and the indiegogo sharing tools!
