skilled observation of the laws inherent in speech and music, eurythmy makes
visible the invisible form of sound.
Eurythmy is not interpretation; it is a true
sounding or singing through the body.
What We Need & What You GetBudget Total Budget $39,800Revenues:
Secured Grants $10,000

Secured Donations from our Circle of Friends $4000
Projected Suggested Donations from Performances $11,000

Projected additional Grants $ 7000
Needed at least $ 7800
Expenses:
Artist Fees $ 13,400
Technical and administrative support $ 3600
Costumes $500
Rentals $400
Webpage/ Design/ Publicity $ 2000
Video $ 2000
Travel costs $14,900
Others $3000
Your support would go directly towards our travel costs and the video production.What you getWith your investment in our project you will get to co- own our future activities. Our perks will provide you with some special treats for the different funding categories. The Austin Eurythmy Ensemble is a recognized 501(c)3 tax- exempt organization and your donation will be fully tax- deductible. A tax- deductible form confirming your donation will be sent to you.
Contributor $10: Personal card.

Friend $50: Personal card plus photo.
Supporter $100: Personal card, photo and invitation to an open rehearsal in Austin or on our tour in the season 2014.
Donor $250: Personal card, photo and a free ticket to a performance in Austin or on tour in the season 2014.
Benefactor $500: Personal card, photo plus 2 free tickets to a performance in Austin or on tour in the season 2014.
Guardian $1000: Personal card, photo, 2 free tickets to a performance in Austin or on tour in the season 2014 plus a dinner for two with Andrea and Markus Weder. 
Redeemer $2500: Personal card, photo, 2 free tickets to a performance in Austin or on tour in the season 2014 and a free workshop/ demonstration to an audience of your choice in Austin in the season 2014 plus a dinner for two with Andrea and Markus Weder.
Initiator $5000: Personal card, photo, 2 free tickets to a performance in Austin or on tour in the season 2014 and a free presentation to an audience of your choice in Austin in the season 2014 plus a dinner for two with Andrea and Markus Weder.

ImpactWith your generous contribution you will share in our intention and strivings to bring our mission to full fruition in our present and future work.
MissionThe Austin Eurythmy Ensemble
cherishes the spiritual wisdom of the human body in motion. By promoting social
harmony and spiritual renewal, we seek to achieve individual, cultural, and
global transformation. Rooted in the tradition of eurythmy as inaugurated by
Rudolf Steiner and yet contemporary in artistic approach, the Ensemble intends
to make this art form a relevant part of today’s cultural life. We are carrying
eurythmy into the future by performing internationally and educating future
generations of eurythmists. Our envisioned state- of-the- arts rehearsal and
performance center will include an International Eurythmy Academy. This center
will serve as a meeting place for visual, literary, and performing artists to
inspire each other and for the spiritually curious and artistically inclined to
build community.
History
The Austin Eurythmy
Ensemble (www.austineurythmy.org) was
founded in 1996. As a performing eurythmy troupe they have initiated incredibly
satisfying performance work, whirlwind tours, amazing professional and artistic
collaboration as well as important alliances and relationships.
  Over the course of years, the ensemble has grown on many
different levels from their beginnings as a 4-member troupe moving from Spring
Valley, New York, to Austin, Texas, into a mature troupe of professional
artists complete with a devoted Circle of Friends and deeply satisfying
professional relationships. 
  Having been granted the unique position of
artists-in-residence upon their arrival in the US, Markus and Andrea Weder have
been able to continue their work as professional eurythmists while at the same
time enjoying the inspiring and challenging work of teaching eurythmy at the
Austin Waldorf School (1996- 2007).  Providing the school with
consistent, high quality eurythmy instruction, which resulted in programs such
as the Austin Youth Eurythmy Troupe (1999- 2007), an extra-curricular high
school troupe, and the first ever International High School Eurythmy Festival
(2004). All this is stemming from, and nurturing a particular passion of the
eurythmists to work intensely with youth. 
  Since their inception, the group has produced and
performed over five different evening programs and numerous children’s
programs, traveling across the U.S., Canada and Europe in at least ten
extensive performance tours.  Much to their delight, audiences have been
very receptive, and generous with praise, commenting on the depth, eloquence,
sophistication, precision and quality of cohesion that the ensemble brings to
the stage.
  It is important to point out the relationships these
eurythmists have cultivated and enjoyed with their collaborative artists, for
the nature of their art is to make visible the world of music and speech. Their
creations have only been made possible through these indispensable and
inspiring collaborations with supporting musicians and speech artists. These
fellow artists have offered their talent and expertise in helping to shape the
ensemble into its present form.  
  The
ensemble has always pursued many opportunities to further develop the presence
of eurythmy in the world.  Along those lines, one of the most important
manifestations has been the Summer Eurythmy Academy (2003- 2007 in the US,
Brazil, South Africa and Switzerland).  In these recurring month-long
intensives, graduates of Waldorf education could more fully explore the art of
eurythmy as it relates not only to performance work, but also to
self-development. The momentum of this work inspired the initiation of a new
professional eurythmy training. 
 The
im-pulse.eurythmy, International Eurythmy Studies (www.impulse-eurythmy.org) was inaugurated in 2008. It is
a completely new approach to a professional eurythmy training on the college
level. In addition to Austin, TX, the home base of the training, students travelled
to campuses in Dornach, Switzerland and Sao Paolo, Brazil. The first course
(2008- 2011) was specially tailored to the needs of Waldorf School Alumni from
the U.S., Brazil and Switzerland with prior extensive experience in eurythmy.
This three year long, full- time course is recognized by the Section for
Eurythmy, Speech, Drama and Music at the Goetheanum, Dornach, Switzerland, the
worldwide center of the Eurythmy movement.
  In another effort to bring eurythmy
to more visibility, the ensemble has branched out into the public sphere with
workshops, lecture/demonstrations, and public performances at local venues such
as theaters and museums.  With the new Project Zero Circle: -beginnings
more of such work is envisioned 
  As they continue touring and performing
and mentoring youth, the ensemble remains devoted to bringing eurythmy ever
more fully into human consciousness. 
Other Ways You Can HelpRegardless if you are in a position to contribute to our project you can support us by sharing our campaign and events via social media and the indiegogo sharing tools!

story:
In Michael Mitnick's play Spacebar: A Broadway Play by Kyle Sugarman, Kyle Sugarman, a 16-year-old from Fort Collins, CO, writes a 456-page play that he's sure will be the biggest hit in the history of Broadway. Rejected by his father, the girl he loves, and Broadway itself, Kyle takes matters into his own hands – embarking on an adventure as funny, touching, and surprising as the play he’s written.

Spacebar will have its New York premiere at The Wild Project in the East Village from October 24 - November 8, 2014, in a production directed by Maggie Burrows and designed by Dane Laffrey. (Purchase tickets here!)

In Spacebar Kyle learns what many of us already know: putting on a play isn’t cheap. We are so close to raising the funds we need to successfully bring this play to a New York audience, and we need your help to bridge the gap! We are sponsored by Fractured Atlas, so all donations are tax-deductible.

Most recently, Michael's screenplay The Giver, an adaptation of the Newberry Award-winning novel, was released in August starring Meryl Streep and Jeff Bridges. Maggie was the Assistant Director for the Tony Award-winning Daniel Sullivan on King Lear at this year's Shakespeare in the Park starring John Lithgow (who gave Maggie a nice shout-out in his blogpost on the New York Times website!).

Our extraordinary cast includes: John Ellison Conlee (Tony-nominee for The Full Monty on Broadway), Will Connolly (Once on Broadway), John Doherty (A Bright New Boise at The Wild Project), Willa Fitzgerald (MTV's Scream), Ana Kayne (The Club at Playwrights Horizons), and Morgan Ritchie (The Seagull at Huntington Theatre Company).


Why does putting on a show cost so much? Here are just a few of our expenses:

  • Our cast includes some of the best actors working in New York. We have a tireless production team of designers, stage managers, electricians, carpenters, rigger, board operator, among others. They don't come cheap.
  • Performance space rental: $12,000 for three weeks for use of The Wild Project's stage, lighting grid, sound system, dressing rooms and bathroom.
  • Rehearsal space rental: $3,000 for a space big enough to rehearse a cast of 6.
  • Scenic, Costume, Props, Lighting and Sound costs: $4,500 for materials for sets in Fort Collins, CO, Broadway and Outer Space (harnesses for levitating actors are pricey!)
  • Insurance is $1,000 ... just in case.

Spacebar Team

Playwright // Michael Mitnick

Director // Maggie Burrows

Scenic and Costume Design // Dane Laffrey

Lighting Design // Jen Schriever

Sound Design // Brandon Wolcott

Lead Producer // Adriel Saporta

Producer // Lily Garrison

Line Producer // Allison Bressi

Production Stage Managers // Whitney Dearden and Alexandra Hall

Assistant Stage Manager // Rachel Lebowitz

Artwork // Studio RFA.

Filmmaker // Jack Pearce

Artist Bios

MICHAEL MITNICK (Playwright): Michael Mitnick's theatre credits include Sex Lives of Our Parents (world premiere Second Stage Uptown), Fly By Night (Playwrights Horizons; Dallas Theater Center; TheatreWorks), Ed, Downloaded (world premiere Denver Center Theatre Company), and Babs the Dodo (world premiere at Washington Ensemble Theatre). Alumnus Ars Nova and Page 73 Playgroups. Commissions for The Roundabout and Manhattan Theatre Club. He received his MFA in Playwriting from the Yale School of Drama. He lives in Brooklyn.

MAGGIE BURROWS (Director): Maggie Burrows graduated with a BA in English Literature from Yale University where she was nominated for the Sudler Prize for Excellence in the Arts. Maggie has assistant directed for Daniel Aukin, Davis McCallum and James Bundy. She served as the assistant director to Daniel Sullivan for Shakespeare in the Park on The Comedy of Errors and King Lear. This winter, she directed Fox on the Fairway at Northern Stage. Maggie has worked with Lookingglass, Steppenwolf, Roundabout, Second Stage, and Finborough in London. Maggie has spent four years as an Artistic Associate at iTheatrics developing their Broadway JR. and Broadway KIDS collections. She is a member of the Lincoln Center Directors Lab and a recipient of the World Performance Project Grant at Yale. Most recently, Maggie directed her first short live action film. 

DANE LAFFREY (Set and Costume Designer): Dane Laffrey’s recent off-Broadway credits include set and/or costumes for Bad Jews and Tigers Be Still (Roundabout), Disgraced (Lincoln Center Theater), Arlington (Vineyard), American Hero and The Talls (Second Stage), The Maids (Red Bull), I Remember Mama and The Patsy (Transport Group), The Other Place (MCC), Sixty Miles to Silver Lake (Soho Rep), The Few and Rag and Bone (Rattlestick), Bad Jazz (Play Company), 12 Chairs and Exit (Keigwin + Co, The Joyce Theatre). His work has been presented at major theaters around the US including The Old Globe, The Humana Festival, Williamstown Theatre Festival, Denver Center Theatre Company, Baltimore Center Stage, Dallas Theatre Center, New York Stage and Film, Asolo Rep., Signature, Yale Opera, Two River Theatre, others. He’s worked internationally in Tokyo, Oslo, Osaka and throughout Australia, including "The Roast," airing nightly on ABC2. Nominations for a Drama Desk Award, 4 Henry Hewes Design Awards and a Sydney Theatre Award.

JENNIFER SCHRIEVER (Lighting Designer): Designs include: BROADWAY: John Leguizamo’s Ghetto Klown, also filmed for HBO.OPERA: Die Fledermaus (Metropolitan), Faust, A Midsummer Night's Dream (Mariinsky, Russia), The Pearl Fishers (ENO, London). OFF BROADWAY: Mala Hierba, American Hero (Second Stage); A Second Chance (Public); Sunset Baby (Labyrinth); Triassic Parq (Soho Playhouse); Bullet for Adolf  (New World Stages), Stuffed and UnStrung (Union Square) An Evening Without Monty Python (Town Hall). REGIONAL/OTHER: Marie Antoinette (Woolly Mammoth), Sunday in the Park with George (Signature, VA), The Other Josh Cohen (Papermill); Romeo And Juliet, The Conference of the Birds, A Taming of the Shrew (Folger), Stones in his Pockets (CenterStage), American Hero (Williamstown) DANCE: Liz Lerman: Healing Wars. Adjunct Professor Purchase College. ASSOCIATE DESIGN BROADWAY: A Raisin in the Sun, Betrayal, Death of A Salesman, The Mountaintop, The House of Blue Leaves, The Book of Mormon, Fences, Joe Turner's Come and Gone, You're Welcome America. www.jenschriever.com

story:
We are the UMKC MFA Acting Class of 2014, a group of seven actors from across the country who have come to Kansas City to dedicate ourselves to three years of rigorous training.  We have applied ourselves to an in-depth study of acting, voice, and physical technique.  Our training culminates this March in a New York Showcase - our opportunity to present our talent and skill to professional agents and casting directors.

The road to New York isn't easy, and we need your help to make the leap!  We are hard at work creating a dynamic showcase, and you can help lay the logistical groundwork. Donating to our campaign will help us show our best work during this pivotal moment in our careers.

All of the funds we raise will be divided equally between the seven of us, helping each of us to cover housing, subway fares, headshot and printing costs, props and wardrobe, and advertising and promotional material.

Every donation above $10 earns you a perk, with options including an original sonnet or a lip-sync video to the song of your choice.  Check out the sidebar for the complete list of perks!

Every dollar you donate to our showcase brings us one step closer to a successful premier in New York. There is no contribution too small! For our supporters who are also artists or grad students, you can still show your support by spreading the word on social media and sending us good vibes. 

 Our sincerest thanks!

story:
You’re cordially invited to assist us in the realization of the wedding plans for Anthony Pinnunziato & Andrew Polinski, both of whom are coming together (which is how it always should be) at the Montreal Fringe, June 12 to 22, 2014.

The play satirizes the controversy surrounding same-sex marriage while drawing on larger than life gay and Italian-American characters. Playwright Anthony J. Wilkinson’s off-Broadway mega-smash hit (ongoing in NYC since 2003) is a fast paced wacky - zany comedy (à la sitcom) absurd farce set in Brooklyn NYC, June 2011. This project is equally as entertaining as it is informative, educating everyone on the subject matter it deals with. This character driven piece allows the audience to laugh along with but not at the personas being portrayed, in a non-judgmental format that leaves all of the participants with plenty of ‘food for thought’ a buffet of insight and introspective begging the question… ‘what’s all the fuss really all about?’

In order to bring this production from the page to the stage we need your participation. When it comes to planning and preparing for a theatrical production the need for support often extends far beyond the capacity of the organizing team creating that project. We’re organizing a wedding within a theatre production, doubling the efforts normally required for each objective and outcome, there-for  greater assistance to fulfill those needs. Our famiglia (family) will greatly appreciate any and all assistance in helping us to create a great wedding for Anthony & Andrew promising you an equally entertaining and  educational experience for all of those who attend it in June. 

The funds raised will go directly to not only increase awareness but also to cover: 1) The cost of adequate safe conveniently located rehearsal space. With a cast of over 15 local artists, our own kitchens and living rooms are a just too cramped (we know, we’ve tried.) in size.  2) The cost of some of the basic accountable fixed costs of production including, performance fee rights to the play, the venue, and technical production team costs . 3) Printing and publicity. Media release invitations, flyers and programs and posters. All required in-order to draw attention and bring awareness  about the pending nuptials of Anthony & Andrew. 4) To ensure that at the end of the day, there is enough box office receipts balanced to share and distribute to our generous and talented famiglia of performing artists.

Your contributions, none are too large or too small, will be rewarded by being a part of something truly BIG! Become a member of our production dream team, the famiglia of My BIG Gay Italian Wedding. You’ll become a part of something really BIG while helping others experience something truly special. Come OUT and join us during the production’s run during the Fringe. See production schedule and posted information below. Grazie!

The Pinnunizato family embark on a BIG gay adventure when their only son Anthony Pinnunziato, a gay Italian-American from a large chaotic family, wants to marry his boyfriend Andrew Polinski in a traditional Italian wedding ceremony. Anthony's mother Angela won't give her blessing unless Andrew's estranged mother also gives her blessing and the ceremony is performed by the family priest Father Rosalia. Matters are further complicated by Andrew's ex-boyfriend Gregorio Salinary who's intent on interfering with the plans, and Mario Nicastro, Anthony's best-man, who's determined to break up the couple. -What could possibly go wrong when everyone wants to get involved and help out with the wedding plans? Everything that's what! Come OUT, and be a guest at our BIG show.

It's gonna be ! FUROUSHBALLS !

WHERE:

Performances at Fringe Venue #5:  Cabaret du Mile End
5240 Ave, du Parc.  (N.W. Fairmont) Montreal, Qc.

WHEN:

Performance dates & times:
Saturday, June 14th 19:00; Sunday, June 15th 22:30; Monday, June 16th 20:45; Thursday, June 19th 15:15; Friday, June 20th 21:30; Sunday, June 22nd 12:00

Please become a member of our famiglia and donate by ordering your pre-sale advance purchase ticket package to our production of My BIG Gay Italian Wedding right here via our InDiGoGo campaign. Four packages to choose from, all with special motivational incentive advantages to suit every need and budget. 

!!!VIP NOTE!!!

Please, you must advise the producers (Village Scene Productions) separately of your selected performance date and time via e-mail @ village scene@yahoo.ca a minimum 72 hours prior to the show date in order to pre-reserve and guarantee your table under your name and guarantee that your pre-reserved tickets are waiting for your at the Fringe Venue #5 Box Office an hour prior to the selected performance for pickup. !VIP!

Or: Regular advance ad at the door sales information. Order directly with the Fringe Box-Office (there is no confirmed advanced seating arrangements made prior to performance, it is strictly on a 1st come 1st seated basis) at this site: www.montrealfringe.ca or by phone at the Fringe box office 514-849-3378. 

The regular per-person ticket prices when purchased with the Fringe are: $10.00  (Seniors 60+) $8.00*  (+box office service charge of $2.00). *Or those attending wearing a formal wedding gown, bridesmaid dress, or a tuxedo.

Follow My BIG Gay Italian Wedding on FaceBook events and on Twitter MBGIW _ Fringe 

Please visit us at  http://www.villagescene.com/Villagescene/giw.html  for more details about the production and biographies of the cast & crew.

Join us on our FaceBook event page @ https://www.facebook.com/events/1536359796588457/

Meet the AMAZEBALLS members of the Montreal ensemble cast are listed here in order of appearance:

VICTORIA BARKOFF (Angela Pinnunizato, Matriarch) 

PETROS KLADIS (Joseph Pinnunizato, Patriarch) 

DANIEL CARTER (Anthony Pinnunizato, Groom) 

KSENIA THURGOOD (Maria Pinnunizato Flower girl)  

ZACH RADFORD (Andrew Polinski, Groom) 

ALEXANDRA VALASSIS (Aunt Toniann, God Mother) 

PHILIPPE LAURIN (Gregorio Salinari, Bestman)

NATHANIEL VILLANUEVA (Rodney Jones) CRYSTAL WESTMAN (Lucia Fuccio, Grooms-attendant) DAWN LAMBING (Connie Scuccifufffio, Grooms-attendant) NANDO MERCURI (Mario Nicastro, Bestman) ADAM RECINE (Frankie Falcone, Groomsman)


Featuring for the first time performing at the Fringe:

DAVYN RYALL (Maurizio LeGrande, Wedding planner)

Plus cameos by some of Montreal’s leading talents will make appearances as: Father Rosalia : Howard Rosenstein, Jonathan Marquis, Izak Benrobi,  Stephen Pietrantoni, and Hugo Charland; As the Nun & Wedding Guest : Ellen David, Janis Kirshner, Elsa Perez, Nadia Verrucci, and Kristina Sandev.

Meet the technical members of the wedding party :

- Directed by : VSP's artistic director DAVYN RYALL
- Directorial concultant : JACQUELINE van de GEER
- Vocal accent consultant : JULIA LENARDON
- Accessories : MÉLANIE ANN FALLNBIGL
- Production assistance : RICKY SMITH
- Choreography and Photography & Promotional Graphics :
NATHANIEL VILLANUEVA

Village Scene Production & artistic director Davyn Ryall @ the Montreal FRINGE since 1995…

WE'RE BACK AT THE MONTREAL FRINGE! This production landmarks Village Scene Productions (VSP) sixth participation in the Montreal FRINGE: 'Mauvais Match' 2002 La Chapelle; 'Come Clean & Exploration' 2003 Bain St-Michel; 'May Day' 2006 Portuguese Center (w/ Egg On Theatre); 'William & James' 2007; 'BATHHOUSE: The Musical!' both on the outdoor stage.

Village Scene Productions (PVSP) is a non-profit local community spirited company with an L.G.B.T. (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender) mandate. Producing in both English & French PVSP has mounted over three dozen productions and special events since first established in 2000. Artistic director Davyn Ryall first discovered the Fringe attending a play on the Main in 1995. Davyn volunteered, participated in events, and support numerous productions eventually joining the Fringe staff as Box Office coordinator in 2002, and then held the position of Volunteer Coordinator 2004-05. Since then he's continued to volunteer and show his support for the FRINGE performing artists by assisting in promoting their productions through radio broadcasts, print, and social media blog-cast outlets.

controversy surrounding same-sex marriage while drawing on larger than life gay
and Italian-American characters. Playwright Anthony J. Wilkinson’s off-Broadway
mega-smash hit (ongoing in NYC since 2003) is a fast paced wacky - zany comedy (à la sitcom) absurd farce set in
Brooklyn NYC, June 2011. This project is equally as entertaining as it is
informative, educating everyone on the subject matter it deals with. This character driven piece
allows the audience to laugh along with but not at the personas being portrayed, in a non-judgmental format that leaves all of the participants with plenty of ‘food for thought’ a buffet of insight and introspective begging the question…
‘what’s all the fuss really all about?’
In order to bring this production from the page to the stage we need your participation.
When it comes to planning and preparing for a theatrical production the need for support often extends far beyond the capacity of the organizing team creating that project. We’re organizing a wedding within a theatre production, doubling the efforts normally required for each objective and outcome, there-for  greater assistance to fulfill those needs. Our famiglia (family) will greatly
appreciate any and all assistance in helping us to create a great wedding for Anthony & Andrew promising you an equally entertaining and  educational experience for all of those who
attend it in June. The funds raised will go directly to not only increase awareness but also to cover: 1) The cost of
adequate safe conveniently located rehearsal space. With a cast of over 15 local artists, our own kitchens and
living rooms are a just too cramped (we know, we’ve tried.) in size.  2) The cost of some of the basic accountable fixed costs of production including, performance fee rights to the play, the venue, and technical production team costs . 3) Printing and publicity. Media release invitations, flyers and programs and
posters. All required in-order to draw attention and bring awareness  about the pending
nuptials of Anthony & Andrew. 4) To ensure that at the end of the day, there is
enough box office receipts balanced to share and distribute to our generous and talented famiglia of performing artists.
Your contributions, none are too large or too small, will be rewarded by being a part of something truly BIG! Become a member
of our production dream team, the famiglia of My BIG
Gay Italian Wedding. You’ll become a part of something really BIG while helping others
experience something truly special. Come OUT and join us during the production’s
run during the Fringe. See production schedule and posted information below.
Grazie!
The Pinnunizato family embark on a BIG gay adventure when their only
son Anthony Pinnunziato, a gay Italian-American from a large chaotic family,
wants to marry his boyfriend Andrew Polinski in a traditional Italian wedding
ceremony. Anthony's mother Angela won't give her blessing unless
Andrew's estranged mother also gives her blessing and the ceremony is performed
by the family priest Father Rosalia. Matters are further complicated by Andrew's ex-boyfriend
Gregorio Salinary who's intent on interfering with the plans, and Mario Nicastro, Anthony's
best-man, who's determined to break up the couple. -What could possibly go
wrong when everyone wants to get involved and help out with the wedding plans? Everything
that's what! Come OUT, and be a guest at our BIG show. 
It's gonna be !
FUROUSHBALLS !

WHERE:
Performances at Fringe Venue #5:  Cabaret du Mile End 5240 Ave, du Parc.  (N.W. Fairmont) Montreal, Qc.

WHEN:
Performance
dates & times:
Saturday, June 14th 19:00; Sunday, June 15th 22:30; Monday, June 16th 20:45; Thursday,
June 19th 15:15; Friday, June 20th 21:30; Sunday, June 22nd 12:00

Please become a member of our famiglia and donate by ordering your pre-sale advance purchase ticket package to our production of My BIG Gay Italian Wedding right here via our InDiGoGo campaign. Four packages to choose from, all with special motivational incentive advantages to suit every need and budget. !!!VIP NOTE!!!Please, you must advise the producers (Village Scene Productions) separately of your selected performance date and time via e-mail @ village scene@yahoo.ca a minimum 72 hours prior to the show date in order to pre-reserve and guarantee your table under your name and guarantee that your pre-reserved tickets are waiting for your at the Fringe Venue #5 Box Office an hour prior to the selected performance for pickup. !VIP!Or: Regular advance ad at the door sales information. Order directly with the Fringe Box-Office (there is no confirmed advanced seating arrangements made prior to performance, it is strictly on a 1st come 1st seated basis) at this site: www.montrealfringe.ca or by phone at the Fringe box office 514-849-3378. The regular per-person
ticket prices when purchased with the Fringe are: $10.00  (Seniors 60+) $8.00*  (+box office service charge of $2.00). *Or those attending
wearing a formal wedding gown, bridesmaid dress, or a tuxedo.

Follow My BIG Gay
Italian Wedding on FaceBook events and on Twitter MBGIW _ Fringe Please visit us at  http://www.villagescene.com/Villagescene/giw.html  for more details about the production
and biographies of the cast & crew.Join us on our FaceBook event page @ https://www.facebook.com/events/1536359796588457/

Meet the
AMAZEBALLS members of the Montreal ensemble cast are listed here in order of
appearance:VICTORIA
BARKOFF (Angela Pinnunizato,
Matriarch) PETROS KLADIS (Joseph Pinnunizato, Patriarch) DANIEL CARTER (Anthony Pinnunizato, Groom) KSENIA THURGOOD (Maria Pinnunizato Flower girl)  ZACH RADFORD (Andrew Polinski,
Groom) ALEXANDRA
VALASSIS (Aunt Toniann, God Mother) PHILIPPE
LAURIN (Gregorio Salinari, Bestman)NATHANIEL
VILLANUEVA (Rodney Jones) CRYSTAL
WESTMAN (Lucia Fuccio, Grooms-attendant) DAWN LAMBING
(Connie Scuccifufffio, Grooms-attendant) NANDO MERCURI
(Mario Nicastro, Bestman) ADAM RECINE (Frankie Falcone, Groomsman)Featuring for
the first time performing at the Fringe:DAVYN RYALL (Maurizio LeGrande, Wedding planner)Plus cameos by some of Montreal’s leading
talents will make appearances as: Father Rosalia : Howard Rosenstein, Jonathan Marquis, Izak Benrobi,  Stephen Pietrantoni, and Hugo Charland; As the Nun & Wedding Guest : Ellen David, Janis Kirshner, Elsa Perez, Nadia Verrucci, and Kristina Sandev.
Meet the
technical members of the wedding party :
- Directed by
: VSP's artistic director DAVYN RYALL- Directorial
concultant : JACQUELINE van de GEER- Vocal
accent consultant : JULIA LENARDON- Accessories : MÉLANIE ANN FALLNBIGL- Production
assistance : RICKY SMITH-
Choreography and Photography & Promotional Graphics : NATHANIEL VILLANUEVAVillage Scene
Production & artistic director Davyn Ryall @ the Montreal FRINGE since 1995…
WE'RE BACK AT THE MONTREAL FRINGE! This production landmarks Village Scene Productions
(VSP) sixth participation in the Montreal FRINGE: 'Mauvais Match' 2002 La
Chapelle; 'Come Clean & Exploration' 2003 Bain St-Michel; 'May Day' 2006
Portuguese Center (w/ Egg On Theatre); 'William & James' 2007; 'BATHHOUSE:
The Musical!' both on the outdoor stage. 
Village Scene Productions (PVSP) is a non-profit local community spirited company with
an L.G.B.T. (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender) mandate. Producing
in both English & French PVSP has mounted over three dozen productions and special
events since first established in 2000. Artistic director Davyn Ryall first
discovered the Fringe attending a play on the Main in 1995. Davyn volunteered, participated in
events, and support numerous productions eventually joining the Fringe staff as
Box Office coordinator in 2002, and then held the position of Volunteer
Coordinator 2004-05. Since then he's continued to volunteer and show his
support for the FRINGE performing artists by assisting in promoting their
productions through radio broadcasts, print, and social media blog-cast
outlets.

story:
The Hours That Remain

In fall 2012 we will premiere Metis playwright Keith Barker's moving play The Hours That Remain for audiences in Saskatoon and Toronto.  Haunted by the disappearance of her sister five years ago, Denise desperately seeks answers where she can.  A story of enduring love and a testament to the relentless hope evinced by families of missing women everywhere.  We are proud to partner with Saskatchewan Native Theatre Company to stage this beautiful play.

 

Story of the Play

The Hours That Remain has been developed over the past two years with workshops and readings by Native Earth Performing Arts, Foundry Theatre and New Harlem Productions.  It has been dramaturged by DM St. Bernard and Isaac Thomas.  It has been read at Springworks Festival in Stratford and Weesageechak Begins to Dance Festival in Toronto.  Like all good plays, it has been raised by the village.  We hope you will join us in bringing it to the stage for its premiere production under the exquisite direction of David Storch.

 

Here's the Deal

We are grateful to have secured the partnership of Saskatchewan Native Theatre Company in producing this play.  New Harlem is a small company with mighty ambition.  We are asking for your help to get the show over to Saskatoon where it will be welcomed with open ... risers?  The fundraising amount above represents the cost of airfare for the creative team from Toronto to Saskatchewan.   In exchange for your contribution, we hope you will accept a little piece of Hours for your very own.  Also, we will love you so hard you will feel it in your socks.

story:
Dave Rockenbaugh—composer, lyricist, playwright, creative director, memoirist, game inventor—has just completed his second musical, Hitch’s Missus.

The show has been performed as table reads without music, and now it’s time to show producers and theater companies just what a "heavenly" musical this would be for them to stage.

Set in Dave's unique version of Heaven, Hitch’s Missus is about 7 famous movie stars, all vying for the role of eternal spouse of the Master of Suspense, Sir Alfred Hitchcock. The audition includes his actual, earthly wife, Alma Reville Hitchcock, who was a brilliant editor, screenwriter and collaborator on most every one of Hitch’s films (often, uncredited).

Imagine Doris Day, Grace Kelly, Janet Leigh, Tallulah Bankhead and more, all in competition to be the Forever Missus Hitchcock. Egos and insults will fly, even if these near-angels won’t.

All the music is based on themes from Bernard Herrmann’s classic Hitchcock film scores: North by Northwest, Vertigo, The Man Who Knew Too Much and even Psycho. You'll also hear Doris Day try to sing the "F Bomb" in a rockin' version of Que Sera Sera.

story:
This is the first of two campaigns! Right now we need to get this money as soon as possible to put a deposit down for our space. There will be another campaign following to raise the money needed for the production starting at the end of April.

The Story

 Zombie Prom is a musical comedy set in the 1950's by John Dempsey and Dana P. Rowe.  It is the tale of a sweet teenage girl named Toffee and the "rebel without a cause" Jonny whose name is spelled without the customary "h". While the unlikely pair fall in love at Enrico Fermi High School, the tyrant principle Miss Strict seeks to intervene and persuades Toffee to break up wth Jonny. The distraught Jonny commits suicide by hurling himself into the local nuclear plant. But he's not gone for long. Toffee soon realizes that Jonny has come back for her. But will she take him back now that he's a Zombie? 

The Impact/The Team

We are Jessica Mortellaro and Jamibeth Margolis and we are teaming up to produce Zombie Prom this fall in midtown manhattan.

Zombie Prom was originally produced in New York City in 1996. It ran Off Broadway, but for only 12 performances. This fantastic show was never recognized for the gem that it is. The Rock and roll score is comtemporary with a hint of 50's flare, and the writing is clever, campy, and witty, poking fun at the cliche's of the 50's. 
We want to give this show a new life. We will be producing Zombie Prom under the Equity Showcase Code in Midtown Manhattan.  It will have a stellar cast filled with Broadway faces under the direction of seasoned director Jamibeth Margolis. 

Jamibeth Margolis (Director): NYC directing credits include assistant director to Jerry Zaks on the Broadway revival of The Caine Mutiny Court Martial and also on A Bad Friend by Jules Feiffer and Lincoln Center Theater. Jamibeth Directed Plane Crazy and Far From The Madding Crowd at the New York Music Theater Festival, as well as developmental productions and readings of Owl Creek: A New Musical, Warsaw, Dreamweavers, Berlin, Great Googley Moo, Family Dinner, Don't Blame Me....I Voted For Helen Gahagan Douglas, 1812, and more at prominent NYC venues. Recent regional credits include directing Tosca and Pirates of Penzance for Boheme Opera NJ and Do I Hear a Waltz? and Jekyll and Hyde at the Arvada Center Theater in Denver. Jamibeth is a member of the Licoln Center Directors Lab and specializes in the development of new plays and musicals. She has a B.A. in Drama/Directing from Ithaca College and is a member of the SDC. Jamibeth also cast some of the longest running shows in Broadway history including Les Miserables, Cats, Miss Saigon, and The Phantom Of the Opera. Jamibeth is the Executive Director of the New Paradigm Theater in CT.

It seems like everywhere you turn these days you see scary zombies that want to eat your brains (among other things). What about broken hearted Zombies who just want access to equal education? We feel that now is the perfect time to bring Zombie Prom back to a NY stage. 


What We Need 

This will be the first of two campaigns. Right now we need to book our space so we can get started! We hope to mount the show this coming October during Halloween time, and the faster we get this money, the faster we can ensure a spot in a space that will be really fantastic. The show will be happening in midtown manhattan, right in the heart of the theater district. We need to put down half of the price of the space up front to lock in the theater of our choice. Please help us to reach our goal so that we can move on to the next step in our process. Anything beyond the 2,500 that we raise will be applied towards our production expenses. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out! We appreciate any donation you can give, large or small, but please share this campaign with your friends or anyone you know who may feel passionate about a project like ours. The more people we can reach, the closer we will be to bringing this show to life! 

Also down the road we will need lots of help with the production. You can be a part of our show! We will need people to donate their time and resources to help us with programs, publicity, house managing, costumes, set, etc. Please e-mail us if you wish to help in any way, ZombiePromShowcase2012@gmail.com.

story:
STRETCH GOAL: $3500

Thank you to everyone who helped us reach our initial goal of $3000. We are going after our STRETCH GOAL of $3500! 

If we reach our goal of $3500, we'll be doing the following:

- IndieGoGo tickets will become VIP tickets! VIPs get reserved seating and a choice of drink or snack at our concessions included!

- Backers at all contribution levels will get an exclusive Romeo Juliet thank you postcard!

"For never was a story of more woe 

Than this of Juliet and her Romeo."

Perhaps no story is as well-known as that of Romeo and Juliet, reimergent over the years in various artistic forms, exemplifiying the malleability and transience of storytelling. Drawing from multiple sources of the classic tale, The Opposite of People, a new theater company, pushes Romeo Juliet into the dystopian future as they discover a new interpretation of Shakespeare's text. August 14-16, 2014 at the Arsenal Center for the Arts in Watertown, MA. 

Cara Guappone as Juliet

The Opposite of People

The Opposite of People (TOP) is a newly established theater company that is dedicated to bringing accessible, unconventional theater to the Boston-area community. Romeo Juliet is the second production of TOP, the first being The Line That Picked Up 1000 Babes, which enjoyed a sold-out run.

The success of 1000 Babes was fantastic, and now we are aiming higher. Your contribution to this campaign will not only support the production of Romeo Juliet, but additionally help springboard TOP into a self-sustaining theater company.

Funds raised through IndieGoGo will cover the costs of producing Romeo Juliet, and ticket sales from the performances will provide the budget for our next production.

Your help will have a huge, direct impact on the success of this production. Moreover, it will help us succeed in our mission of bringing accessible, unexpected, quality theater to the community.

Stephen Sacchetti as Romeo

Where your support goes

All of your support will help fund...

  • Blackbox theater rental at the Arsenal for the Arts in Watertown, MA

  • Insurance for our actors

  • Extended budget for our designers

  • Promotional materials including posters, flyers, and programs

The initial budget for our set, costumes, lighting, sound and props is being raised via program ads and concessions, but additional funds will be put to use to extend our design budget and provide more flexibility to our resourceful designers.  

By contributing, you will not only help us cover these essentials, but also earn rewards including exclusive backstage footage, tickets to the show, and signed memorabilia. Check out our rewards section for more information!


Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can’t contribute doesn't mean you can’t help:

  • You can help us by helping to spread the word to people you know who would be interested in donating or learning more about our organization.

  • Share this campaign on social media. Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, you name it.

  • Join our mailing list to get up-to-date information on ticket sales, company news, and other productions.

  • Come see the show! Even if you can't donate now, we would love to see you in the audience. Click here to buy tickets.

Join our mailing list!

story:
A birthday gift for SpeakeasyDC

So it's not SpeakeasyDC's birthday. March 18th is mine. And as a board member, I wanted to use my birthday to raise funds to support the work we do. In case you don't know me:

  • I'm a DC native.
  • I initially started out as storyteller before I became board member.
  • Before I was a storyteller, I had performed on DC stages in musicals, light operas, and dance concerts.

What I have loved about SpeakeasyDC is that it empowers any and everyone to tell their own stories, whether it be developing the ability to craft them in a class as well as the opportunity to share them on our stage.

SpeakeasyDC's Mission

"To be a platform for diverse perspectives; pursue excellence, innovation and authenticity in contemporary, autobiographical story performance; serve as a pipeline and training ground for new voices and talent in storytelling; support the personal, professional, and artistic development of our community members; and promote compassion and community."

Money, money, money

So the money:

  • All the donations (minus the amount Indiegogo takes as a fee (3% if we reach my goal, 6.75% if we don't) are going to to go SpeakeasyDC.
  • This is the "Get" part of my personal "Give or Get" as a board member. That is the financial commitment we make as board members, in addition to the time we give to support the organization.
  • Whether or not we reach my goal, all the funds will still go to SpeakeasyDC. But the fee is higher if we don't get there.

The Impact

In general, I'm not a big birthday person. So I thought I'd try a campaign, for those who might be interested, to use my birthday as an opportunity to give to an organization whose work I am very passionate about:

  • SpeakeasyDC provides what I believe is a rare opportunity for people in DC to get together and share stories, and particularly to connect in person without the distraction of the online umbilical chord our mobile devices provide.
  • While I've had multiple successful Kickstarter campaigns for performance projects at Capital Fringe, this is the first general fundraiser I am attempting.
  • Every bit you give enables the staff and storytellers at SpeakeasyDC to focus more on their work, providing performances and programs to our audiences and communities.

Other Ways You Can Help

And if you can’t contribute, You can still help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

That's it!! Thank you, in advance, for your consideration!! And every little bit helps, even if it's $1-$5!!

This is the "Get" part of my personal "Give or Get" as a board member. That is the financial commitment we make as board members, in addition to the time we give to support the organization.
Whether or not we reach my goal, all the funds will still go to SpeakeasyDC. But the fee is higher if we don't get there.
The ImpactIn general, I'm not a big birthday person. So I thought I'd try a campaign, for those who might be interested, to use my birthday as an opportunity to give to an organization whose work I am very passionate about:
SpeakeasyDC provides what I believe is a rare opportunity for people in DC to get together and share stories, and particularly to connect in person without the distraction of the online umbilical chord our mobile devices provide.
While I've had multiple successful Kickstarter campaigns for performance projects at Capital Fringe, this is the first general fundraiser I am attempting.
Every bit you give enables the staff and storytellers at SpeakeasyDC to focus more on their work, providing performances and programs to our audiences and communities.
Other Ways You Can HelpAnd if you can’t contribute, You can still help:
Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!
That's it!! Thank you, in advance, for your consideration!! And every little bit helps, even if it's $1-$5!!

story:
~~UPDATE! As of APRIL 30th: AUDIENCE IS AT CAPACITY!  We are grateful for your support but will now have a WAITLIST for further reservations if you wanted to attend the performance.  Thank you!! ~~


***So we can send you your PERKS, please leave us your contact e-mail as a private comment!***

About the Show

STRATUM is a one-night-only performance of new dances featuring the respective works of 3 choreographers:  Craig Zarah, Frances Rosario-Puleo, and Karesia Batan.  They are excited to present their individual experiences of choreography to you in a harmonious evening at Gibney Dance Center on Saturday, May 3rd 2014 at 7:30 PM.

We hope you are able to join us on May 3rd! 

We ask for your support in this fundraising endeavor toward our showing, to help off-set our venue and rehearsal costs, as well as offer our dancers a grateful stipend for their hard work & dedication.  

The Dances

Choreography:  Craig Zarah
All original music by Zarah
Uprising 
Dancers: Karesia Batan, Corinne Sarian, Stephanie Schwartz, Frances Rosario-Puleo, and Dawn Yuster

Venusian/earth chain
Dancer: Craig Zarah

Remaining virginal
Dancers: Stephanie Schwartz and Craig Zarah

Choreography:  Frances Rosario-Puleo
Heliodor
Dancer: Frances Rosario-Puleo, live music: Brian Goonan

Bubble
Dancers: Stephanie Schwartz and Craig Zarah, music by Woody Herman

Choreography:  Karesia Batan
Torque
Dancers: Karesia Batan and Melissa Miller, music by Live Footage

Currents
Dancers: Sharyn Korey, Michelle Micca, Melissa Miller, and Susan Steinman, music by Live Footage and The Glitch Mob


About the Choreographers

Craig Hoke Zarah is a dancer/choreographer, composer/vocalist, visual and motion picture artist.  Trained at the Erick Hawkins School beginning in the early 1970’s, he danced with the Nancy Meehan Dance Company 1972-75 (and 2011 for its 40th anniversary season).  He attended Corcoran School of Art in Washington, D.C. from 1968-70, and studied at Art Students League in New York City from 1970-71.  He has been composing/recording music since the early 1970’s.  His choreography has been presented at Gibney Dance Center (June 2013), the American Dance Guild ‘Bare Bones’ series (May 2013), Greenspace ‘Fertile Ground’ series (December 2012 & 2013), and ‘Greenspace Blooms’ spring series (April 2013).  Craig also performs with Gloria McLean/LIFEDANCE, Nancy Zendora, and in Frances Rosario-Puleo’s choreography. 

Frances Rosario-Puleo danced with the Nancy Meehan Dance Company for over 20 years. She holds an M.A. in dance from Brigham Young University, studies dance with Patty Bryan, and studies singing with Susan Gregory. She is a member of the Bergen Dance Makers and has presented her choreographic works with various artists including the dancers Cristina Livingston, singer Marian Wasserman, pianists Iris Perry, Janice Friedman, Joshua Williams, Caroline H. Newman, and most recently Brian Goonan. She performs with Zendora Dance and Craig Hoke Zarah. She is also a soprano with the New Jersey Verismo Opera.

Karesia Batan’s choreography has been presented at HERE Arts Center, Northside Townhall, Triskelion Arts, Theaterlab, WAH Center, and Gibney Dance Center, as well as MA and CT.  Her dance projects span installation, film, humor, and her development of Aikido-based dance movement.  Selected company credits include Nancy Meehan Dance Co., Abby Bender/Schmantze Theatre, Frances Rosario-Puleo, Anne Zuerner, Poliglot Theater, Jenny Rocha, EmmaGrace Skove-Epes, VESSEL, and Neville Dance.  She currently dances for Beth Soll & Co and Craig Zarah.  Karesia is also a founding producer of Forward Flux (multi-disciplinary artist programs), producer for National Choreography Month, and co-creator of The Moves Project, an outdoor site improv series.  www.karesia.com


We look forward to welcoming you on Saturday May 3rd!

story:
CAN'T TAKE MY (EYES) OFF OF YOU

Written by Fiona Lakeland  - Directed by Adrian LaTourelle 

Starring Fiona Lakeland, Melanie Alexander and Jeff Bowman

WHO WE ARE AND WHAT WE DO! 

  • Hi Everyone! We are Fermented Apples! On our team we've got, Fiona Lakeland (writer/actress/creator/producer), Kimberly Connolly (collaborator/creator), Jeff Bowman (actor), Melanie Alexander (actress), and Adrian LaTourelle (director/creator).
  • This year we will be bringing CAN'T TAKE MY (EYES) OFF OF YOU to Theatre of NOTE for our second year in The Hollywood Fringe Festival! 
  • The story centers around the relationship between Holly and Stefan, and then Katherine, who is Stefan's best friend, and the tensions that arise because she's a girl…
  • It's really Holly's story, though. She meets Stefan when she has a lot going on in her life. Her dad is dying, she never really knew him, and she very quickly falls in love with him, and their relationship develops at a pace that is probably a little bit faster than either of them expected it would be…She finally realizes that she may have gotten herself into something a little too quickly that, now, she's not sure that she can really go through with. 
  • The main point of the piece is knowing how to stay true to yourself. Being able to recognize when we are caught in situations that are uncomfortable or foreign to what we know and really staying true to who we are in those moments, and sometimes having to make some drastic decisions in spite of all that. 
  • The script has changed quite a bit from the beginning which is a natural part of the process. As the characters start to reveal themselves to the writer the story changes and that's all great!  
  • We've already got people really excited about it! We've got reviewers coming to our first couple shows from Bitter Lemons and Examiner.com, we've got people tweeting about us, and we've even got the fantastic support of the LAFPI, which is the "The LA Female Playwright's Initiative"! 
  • All that being said, we just need a little bit of help making everything come together in our final stages of production. Your donation will help us cover the cover the cost of the venue…We're doing the show at Theatre of NOTE which is in Hollywood, and it's a really great space in a 42 seat Black Box theatre. It will also help us cover the cost of the registration, the printing of postcards, and all of our props and costumes!
  • We are so excited to bring this show to the Hollywood Fringe this year and we hope that you'll consider making a small donation. Thank you so much and have a great day!

A LITTLE MORE ABOUT FERMENTED APPLES AND WHAT WE'RE ALL ABOUT

  • Last year, we created our first original World-Premiere play called STRANDED in which we explored Sexual Abuse and it's Effects on Mental Health. The play was  inspired by Journals and Writings of Sylvia Plath and Marilyn Monroe, also written by Fiona Lakeland and directed by Adrian LaTourelle from a collaboration with Kimberly Connolly
  • With Fiona Lakeland as Lucy, and Kimberly Connolly as Annabelle, STRANDED received rave reviews such as: "This is a show that should be seen!" -Bob Leggett, Examiner.com, "Sure to be a festival favorite! This duo is both talented and bold." -John W., "Intense and talented performances. I left invigorated!" -Josh Hillinger, and "I was gripping my arm rests the entire play." -Grant P…just to name a few!
  • Fiona says, on working with her team, "Kim and Adrian and I, we just get each other artistically and it's rare that you find that with another actor/director on such a deep level. We are excited to welcome Jeff and Melanie to the team. We've all got an incredible passion, love and respect for each other's work!" 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

In order to bring CAN'T TAKE MY (EYES) OFF OF YOU to the Fringe this year, we need your help. To keep the lights on and get the word out about the show, we need to raise $950! 

Below is a breakdown of all of our expenses and an outline of exactly where your money will go:

  • Theatre Rental and Insurance: $500
  • Registration: $250
  • Postcards / Posters / Publicity: $150
  • Props and Costumes: $50

We want to thank you for your donation and give something back! For all of our great perks, please take a look on  the right! 

THE IMPACT

Here's why we feel that this show is important and how your contribution will make a difference:

  • We believe that the Theatre is the best way to provoke thought, to inspire change, and to give a voice to the people.
  • Fermented Apples was created to serve as a platform for asking and addressing uncomfortable, yet essential questions and topics through new works in the Theatre. CAN'T TAKE MY EYES OFF OF YOU is universal to people of all ages. It is a piece that weighs on the importance of staying true to who you are no matter what your circumstances whether with a loved one, with a boss, or even with a friend! 
  • Last year we raised $1360 for STRANDED and it was a huge success! Because of the subject matter of STRANDED, How Sexual Abuse Affects Mental Health, we were able to give a voice to the victims of Sexual Abuse and make a mark that raised awareness of this Silent, yet ever present epidemic. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We know that money is tight, so if a monetary contribution is not realistic for you at this time, that's OK! Here are some other fun ways that you can help us out:

  • Come see the show! 
  • Tell your friends about it, Blog about it, Tweet about it!
  • Leave us a review after seeing the show to let us know what you thought!
  • Ask us for some Postcards and give them to everyone you know...maybe even a stranger or two! 
  • Facebook, Twitter, and Google+ are all great ways to share online and it's so easy! Just use the share tools below and help us get the word out today!
  • The more people that we can reach, the better!
  • Come hang out with us at Fringe Central, have a drink, make some awesome connections and encourage people to come out and see the show!

And that's all there is to it! Thank you so much for your support, and have a great day!

We look forward to seeing you at Theatre of NOTE in June for the World Premiere of CAN'T TAKE MY (EYES) OFF OF YOU!

OUR TEAM - FERMENTED APPLES

FIONA LAKELAND

(Actor/Writer/Creator)

http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3739131/

After graduating from The Pacific Conservatory of the Performing Arts, Fiona moved to Los Angeles where she continued her acting training with Sondra Kerr Blake. She has since studied with Adrian LaTourelle and Pamela Daly at Berg Studios since August 2012. She is also a member of the Antaeus Academy with The Antaeus Company where she was studied with Rob Nagle, John Achorn and Geoffrey Wade.

In January of 2013, Fiona began writing her first One-Act play called STRANDED. STRANDED was inspired by Journals and Writings of Sylvia Plath and Marilyn Monroe, and made it's world-premiere at Theatre of NOTE for the Fourth Annual Hollywood Fringe Festival in June, 2013. Fiona also produced and acted in STRANDED alongside Kimberly Connolly, and was directed by Adrian LaTourelle. Her work was celebrated by a nomination for Best Writing by Ezra Buzzington for "The Spirit of the Fringe Award" in June 2013. She has since written CAN'T TAKE MY (EYES) OFF OF YOU which will make it's World Premiere at Theatre of NOTE for the Fifth Annual Hollywood Fringe Festival on June 17, 2014.

Originally from Davis, CA, Fiona speaks both English and German as she spent much of her childhood splitting time between Northern California and North-Western Germany. She is a proud member of SAG-AFTRA and The LAFPI, and has been in Los Angeles since November 2008.


ADRIAN LATOURELLE

(Director/Creator)

http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0490347/

Adrian LaTourelle's many stage credits include work in some of the best theaters in the country, such as the Mark Taper Forum, the Shakespeare Theater in DC, The Old globe, the San Jose Rep, the Dallas Theater Center, the Antaeus Company, and the Yale Repertory Theater.  Adrian has also worked abroad, performing in theater and film in Russia and the Netherlands.

Adrian has appeared in numerous television series such as Castle, Last Resort, The Closer, House, NCIS:LA, Boston Legal, Without a Trace, Criminal Minds, Numbers, with a recurring role on Sons of Anarchy. Adrian is also an accomplished voice over actor and recently completed season two as the voice of the evil Unalaq on Nickelodeon's Avatar: Legend of Korra.

Adrian is a graduate of the Yale School of Drama.

KIMBERLY CONNOLLY

(Collaborator/Creator)

http://www.imdb.com/name/nm5476056/

Kimberly Connolly has been performing in theatre productions since the age of 13. Raised in Port Saint Lucie, Florida, she first stepped foot onstage at Indian River State College where she also performed in musical theatre. After high school, she studied in New York at the New York Conservatory for Dramatic Arts.

Since recently moving to Los Angeles in order to pursue film, Kimberly has studied Meisner at the Elizabeth Mestnik Acting studio, and is currently taking classes at Gregory Berger Sobeck/Berg Studios under Adrian LaTourelle and Pamela Daly.

Her favorite stage credits include Laurey in “Oklahoma!” and Shelby in “Steel Magnolias.”


(BIOS FOR JEFF BOWMAN AND MELANIE ALEXANDER WILL BE AVAILABLE IN THE PROGRAM)


So thanks for checking us out! We hope we have left you excited, exhilarated, and anxious to check out CAN'T TAKE MY (EYES) OFF OF YOU!

story:
PETRIFIED, a new musical...
Staged Reading in NYC, May 2014

Part comedy, part drama, part satire with a lot of heart, PETRIFIED is the story about a middle-American family trying to keep their lives together during this century's Great Recession.  With book and lyrics by Joel Adlen and music and additional lyrics by Leonard Moors, this musical which has been in development in New York and the San Francisco Bay Area, is now ready for an Equity staged reading. Performances are scheduled for Monday and Tuesday, May 19 and 20th, at Cap 21 Studios, New York City, New York.

As much as we would love to see you at the performance — and we'd love to see you at the performance — we also need something else — your help.

Part of this showcase has been subsidized by some generous donors. These friendly benefactors have been able to keep some of our production costs down (rehearsal and performance space most especially). The rest of the funding is up to us, which is why we're reaching out to you.


What We Need

Our campaign is set at $ 7,000.  This covers: 

  • Artistic Personnel  (12 person cast, director, musical director, pianist, stage manager)
  • Photo copies of script and score, plus binders 
  • Music stand rentals
  • Travel costs of the writers (airline/cheap hotel)
  • Incidental/fundraising fees: 6-9% (processing fees)

AND if your generosity is beyond our wildest hopes and dreams, we'll be able to fund our NEXT step: our professional demo recording (used to shop the show to theatres and producers across the country).


The Creative Team: 

  • Terry Berliner (Director) has worked on and off-Broadway and has a passion for developing new work.
  • Kristen Lee Rosenfeld (Music Director) conducted the first national tour of SPRING AWAKENING.
  • Jeromy Hunt (Assistant Director/Stage Manager) An AD/SD of many talents whom we could not be without.
  • Joel Adlen (Bookwriter, Lyricist) 
  • Leonard Moors (Composer, additional Lyrics)
  • Cap 21 (Venue) The wonderful Collaborative Projects in NYC where this show will be presented.

OUR CAST

  • Jim Newman (Broadway's Hands on a Hardbody and Curtains)
  • Meg Pryor (Off-Broadway: Hair, National Tours of Damn Yankees, Grease! )
  • Gael Schaefer (New York's Counselor-at-Law, NYMF's Emma and I Come for Love)
  • Annie Dow
  • Max Perlman
  • Ben Roseberry
  • Michael Barattini
  • THE REST OF THE ENSEMBLE to be announced SOON!


Other Ways You Can Help

If it's a tight month, or year, or just state of being, there are two other ways we could use your help: 

  • Make a little noise: feel free to spread about our new show, and…
  • If you're in New York City, Monday May 19th 7pm, or Tuesday May 20th at 2pm, send us an email to info@petrifiedmusical.com and come see the show!
story_txt:
PETRIFIED, a new musical...Staged Reading in NYC, May 2014Part comedy, part drama, part satire with a lot of heart, PETRIFIED is the story about a middle-American family trying to keep their lives together during this century's Great Recession.  With book and lyrics by Joel Adlen and music and additional lyrics by Leonard Moors, this musical which has been in development in New York and the San Francisco Bay Area, is now ready for an Equity staged reading. Performances are scheduled for Monday and Tuesday, May 19 and 20th, at Cap 21 Studios, New York City, New York.As much as we would love to see you at the performance — and we'd love to see you at the performance — we also need something else — your help.Part of this showcase has been subsidized by some generous donors. These friendly benefactors have been able to keep some of our production costs down (rehearsal and performance space most especially). The rest of the funding is up to us, which is why we're reaching out to you.What We NeedOur campaign is set at $ 7,000.  This covers: 
Artistic Personnel  (12 person cast, director, musical director, pianist, stage manager)
Photo copies of script and score, plus binders 

Music stand rentals
Travel costs of the writers (airline/cheap hotel)
Incidental/fundraising fees: 6-9% (processing fees)

AND if your generosity is beyond our wildest hopes and dreams, we'll be able to fund our NEXT step: our professional demo recording (used to shop
the show to theatres and producers across the country).The Creative Team: 

Terry Berliner (Director) has worked on and off-Broadway and has a passion for
developing new work.

Kristen Lee Rosenfeld (Music Director) conducted the first national tour of SPRING AWAKENING.
Jeromy Hunt (Assistant Director/Stage Manager) An AD/SD of many talents whom we could not be without.
Joel Adlen (Bookwriter, Lyricist) 
Leonard Moors (Composer, additional Lyrics)
Cap 21 (Venue) The wonderful Collaborative Projects in NYC where this show will be presented.
OUR CAST

Jim Newman (Broadway's Hands on a Hardbody and Curtains)


Meg Pryor (Off-Broadway: Hair, National Tours of Damn Yankees, Grease! )


Gael Schaefer (New York's Counselor-at-Law, NYMF's Emma and I Come for Love)

Annie Dow
Max Perlman
Ben Roseberry
Michael Barattini
THE REST OF THE ENSEMBLE to be announced SOON!
Other Ways You Can HelpIf it's a tight month, or year, or just state of being, there are two other ways we could use your help: 
Make a little noise: feel free to spread about our new show, and…
If you're in New York City, Monday May 19th 7pm, or Tuesday May 20th at 2pm, send us an email to info@petrifiedmusical.com 
and come see the show!

story:
What is Party World Rasslin'? 


What started as a wrestling-themed birthday party has spiraled out of control into a bizarre party/wrestling/comedy/theater/party/event with free beer, food, and wrestling entertainment.  WRESTLESLAM I: THE RIOTS OF SPRING will be our flagship, ultimate, yearly show and we want everyone to experience the "mania" of this "wrestling".  Our last event, Winter Wonderslam, surpassed the attendance, pump-levels, and party athleticism of ALL our previous events. Now in this darkest of times, we need your help once again.

 

What We Need and What You Get


WRESTLESLAM I: THE RIOTS OF SPRING will be our biggest and baddestassed event to date.  With the help of our enthusiastic fanbase we've put on three kickass shows, each of which has slammed harder than we have ever slammed before.  We're now looking to slam beyond the limits of humanity and we need your help to raise our evil arms to the great cosmos and drive life into the mat headfirst.  This time around we have sweet rewards for donating, including t-shirts, pre-orders for a DVD featuring all video content from the past year, and some life-changing experiences with your favorite PWR wrestlers. Here's what we'll use your money for:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

porta potties - $238

sound permit - $22

PA - $30

Keg - $106

Food/Drink - $100

Ice - $20 (thanks so much to the people who donated ice last time!)

Decorations - $50

Total Needed - $566

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In addition to these things, we've spent LITERALLY THOUSANDS of dollars buying and transporting something VERY SECRET AND SPECIAL for your PARTY-WRESTLING ENTERTAINMENT (HINT: ITS A REAL A$$ WRE$TLING RING) so any donations ABOVE THIS AMOUNT will help us recoup our devastating but WORTHY losses.
 

Risks & Challenges


Challenges:

We're getting closer to making PWR self-sustaining but we still need help overcoming a few financial hurdles.  We've begun printing awesome merchandise but in order to keep our events FREE we still need the PWR Multiverse to give us the $$$HIGHFIVE$$$ so that we can achieve COMPLETE, MAXIMUM EVIL.

Risks:

The only risk is our lives (which is fine... whatever).
 

Other Ways You Can Help


If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and our upcoming event, Wrestleslam.  In addition to the keg, PWR has coolers and ice available for people to bring their OWN beers, and if you want to bring some extras for other party-people, hey... we won't stop you.

Here is the facebook event page:

https://www.facebook.com/events/759764607448160/

story:
Hello folks! We are BOX Revolution Productions       

"The subject matter combined with Tom and Sarah's creativity and vision is sure to make something magical. They are two of the most committed, driven, professional people I have ever met. 

On top of being brilliant actors and all-round creatives, they have helped and inspired me personally through their knowledge, generosity and passion for what they do. " Sani Mahmood, a student, friend and collaborator of BOX Revolution


WE DID IT!!!

Well who would have believed! THANK YOU! We have been so overwhelmed with all the support! 

You have helped us take our show Detached for its WORLD PREMIERE to this year's Edinburgh Festival Fringe! 

To stay updated follow us or check us out at - boxrevolutionproductions.co.uk

We have all been working our butts off to make this show the touching, relative, entertaining live performance it's going to be!


   

Above: 

(L) The cast and crew of "Like Happy", a short film that BOX Rev. wrapped in May 2015

(R) Tom and Sarah-Beth, trying their hardest to be cool and cute...Sarah-Beth is succeeding...


OUR CAMPAIGN

"Tom and Sarah Beth! - I've worked with them both several times in the past and know for a fact that apart from being great people and performers they put blood, sweat and tears into everything they do. Their work ethic puts mere mortals to shame. " Paul Comrie, all round cool dude and friend of BOX Rev.


We've all felt so alone in the world. We wake, kind of lost and we wonder what's missing. We wander through the day, hoping to find something. More often that not, we never find it.

Our campaign is simple: raise what we need to tell a story that's never been seen before.

Lucy dissects three failed relationships that encompass a life full of creativity and drama. Robin (The Dancer), Ashen (The Artist) and Daithi (The Musician) are the catalysts for change but will Lucy be able to find the happiness she so desperately craves?


SO WHO IN THE BEJAYSUS ARE TOM AND SARAH-BETH?
"I was more than happy to donate what I could to the Detached project as I know that Tom and Sarah-Beth are capable of putting on an impressive show at the fringe. "  Stuart Smith, super friend of BOX Rev.


Well, below is a Vlog we made quite recently to thank everyone who has gotten us to the 33% mark. We are not trying to be anything other than what we are and in this day and age, that can be a terribly difficult thing to succeed at.

Aside from that...

Tom was a professional magician in his early twenties, regularly performing to audiences and after some brief stints on television he followed his love of music playing bass in a band before concentrating solely on producing and acting.

Sarah-Beth is a professional musician, having played and recorded with some of the UK's top composers and artists as well as being a professional actress.

Both of us work as producers and directors in the industry and to top it off, we are professional acting coaches in a studio in the heart of Glasgow.

We are not mere dabblers, we are constantly pushing ourselves to break boundaries and tell unique and inspiring stories. 

We hope you can join us in this one.


What Do We Need?

We are campaigning for £5000. Below is a break down of where that will go.

  • Fringe Fee: £2000
  • Marketing: £1000
  • Travel: £500 (cast and crew)
  • Accommodation: £500 (cast and crew)
  • Set/Costume: £250
  • Indiegogo Fee: £200
  • Fees: £450 (cast and crew)

Anything made above £5000 will ALL be thrown into even more marketing and advertising. No penny will be left unspent! 

Complete transparency is what we guarantee to anyone who wants to invest.


The Delicious PERKS...

The perks offered in this campaign are truly one of a kind. From donating to campaigns in the past, the perks seem to have a common thread and what we offer here, is something we've never seen before.

  • An album of five songs that will be yours and yours alone. 
  • An intimate performance for you and your family/friends 
  • Personal tuition in either acting, singing, music from Tom and Sarah (we are also professional actors/acting coaches and musicians)
  • A play or film written specifically about you or a subject of your choice
  • Come Party with us!!!
These are just a few perks and they are different, they are unique and they best represent the story we are trying to tell - the change in thinking we want to bring about.

VLOGS, VLOGS EVERYWHERE!
We are running an event night this coming 31st of May in Glasgow, check out the vid below for details!


AND NOW...

That's it. That's who we are, that's what we're doing and the story we're telling.

If you want to support us, you will have our gratitude. If you don't, then you have our respect. Nothing is worse than feeling you have to do something and we respect your decision either way.

Until we speak again,

Tom Moriarty

Sarah-Beth Brown

Nothing is worse than feeling you have to do something and we respect your decision either way.Until we speak again,Tom MoriartySarah-Beth Brown

story:
Short Summary

Inspired by love letters written in 1944 from my soldier great uncle to my great aunt, this new experiential dance work, “Paper Hearts,” explores the ways that hearts reach out to each other across visible or invisible barriers. My uncle writes, “The more I write to you the lonesomer I get.” Using these emotional sentiments, I am collaborating with ten well-known Houston dance artists to tell stories of vulnerability, companionship, loneliness, and love through generations of families. 

After a performing career in NYC, I have returned to my home state of Texas to contribute to the dance community as a teacher and as a choreographer. I am incredibly honored to be the 2015 Dance Artist in Residence at Rice University in Houston, and am creating "Paper Hearts" for this project.  

I am fortunate to have experienced and highly creative Houston dance artists contributing their time to this project because they believe in new dance and in what they are saying with their talent. Please help me support them while we create!

What We Need & What You Get

Rice University Dance has generously donated rehearsal space and theater space for the performance, so I am able to produce this evening on a minimal budget. The dancers have generously donated their time and talent, but as professionals, they deserve support. 

I am only asking for this support to pay the artists involved. If I do not reach the entire goal, whatever is raised will be put towards the dancers' honorarium.

All who donate will receive recognition in the program and the knowledge that they are supporting the development of new dance and the growth of dance artists. (and lots of good karma!)

The Impact

Common Humanity is my guiding choreographic value and in this work I hope that by telling my personal history of family love, I will encourage the audience to reflect on their own stories of love and survival.
I am also passionate about creating opportunities for dancers in Texas, and with this project, I hope to give these dancers opportunities to develop as performers and to receive support for their craft.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please share this campaign!
  • Attend the performance! December 3rd and 4th, 8pm. Rice Dance Theater!

story:
We met our $10,000 goal! Thank you so much to all our incredible donors! We've just announced a stretch goal. If we can raise an additional $2,000 (12k total) we can add designers to our Sans Everything process, which will impact our abilities as artists and cultural creators to no end! If you have anything to spare and love supporting big, exciting projects built in a variety of communities: Now is the time.

Here's more about the project:

Strange Attractor (PVD) is teaming up with Lightning Rod Special (PHL) to create a new devised theatre piece called Sans Everything. Set so far in the future that Shakespeare has been forgotten, Sans Everything follows a ship of elite space explorers as they are forced to perform Shakespeare's As You Like It by a hostile space presence, which causes the very fabric of their society to collapse. Sans Everything explores how our culture is shaped by what we choose to forget, and asks if what we are passing down is what we truly want to live on. 

We will be developing Sans Everything throughout 2015-2016 in Philadelphia, at the New Orleans Fringe, Providence's AS220, and Charlestown Working Theater in Mass. The two companies received funding from the Network of Ensemble Theaters which requires a $10,000 match, which is why we are coming to you for help.

Strange Attractor is a sponsored project of AS220,  a non-profit community arts center in Downtown, Providence, RI. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Strange Attractor must be made payable to AS220 only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Hello, my name's Rowan Williams and I need your help.

I have been offered a place on the MA Acting course at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama. The school is one of the best in the world, and its alumni include Laurence Olivier, Judi Dench, Vanessa Redgrave, and Harold Pinter.

This is my dream. I've wanted to be an actor for years, and with training from Central I can develop my potential and work professionally as an actor. But now that I'm finally pursuing my passion head-on I've run into a pivotal obstacle - money.

Central may be one of the world's best drama schools, but this comes at a price. While I will be borrowing money to fund my studies, even with the maximum government loan there is a £7,000 shortfall.

I will to work to support myself while I train, but without the money to fund the tuition fees themselves there is no way I can study here.

It is with this in mind that I turn to you. If you can spare any money - big or small - you would be helping me more than you could know. I will be eternally grateful for your help, and one day when I'm acting professionally there will be free tickets for everyone. But until then, check out the perks below. Thank you for your time.

Perks

I want to make you pleased as well as proud. A good deed may be its own reward, but cake is even better. Donations will be met with perks!

£5 - You will receive a shout-out of thanks on social media, and a hug when next we meet.

£15 - You will receive a hand-written 'Thank You' from yours truly.

£30 - I will write a poem for you. The poem can be as stylish or as dirty as you like.

£40 - You get a free ticket to one of my shows this year.

£50 - I will personally bake you a chocolate Guinness cake. Noone has ever eaten this cake and not fallen in love with it, but other cakes are available on request. Due to the logistic demands of cake, this perk is only available within the London area.

£75 - I will give you a (Mandarin) Chinese lesson.

£100 - I will come to your house and cook you an incredible dinner. Or you can come to mine! Again, this perk largely applies to the London area - but if you're not in London and don't mind waiting till next I am in your area then go for this.

£150 - EITHER I will cook you dinner and bake you a cake;

OR I will run a bespoke game of Dungeons and Dragons for you and 2-4 friends. You will all receive unique, personally created characters especially for your adventure. I dare you to cast aside your preconceptions and go for this perk - you will not believe how much fun you will have.

£500 - Me and a few friends will come to your house (other locations are available) and perform a cabaret show for you. Unfortunately, this perk is also London-only.

£1000 - The Complete Package - Gets you ALL of the above perks. PLUS I will personally brew you a beer created specifically to your tastes, and name it after you.

I would like to include even more perks, but if all goes well then I will be exceedingly busy for the next 12 months. I feel that this is the maximum commitment I can make while still prioritising my studies.

Finally, a special thank you to Emily Bates and Nigel Fullerton for helping me to make the pitch video for free.
