PLUS I will personally brew you a beer created specifically to your tastes, and name it after you.I would like to include even more perks, but if all goes well then I will be exceedingly busy for the next 12 months. I feel that this is the maximum commitment I can make while still prioritising my studies.Finally, a special thank you to Emily Bates and Nigel Fullerton for helping me to make the pitch video for free.

story:
What is... Together We Make IMPACT?

The essence: Together We Make IMPACT is a campaign to support IMPACT 15, a unique international theatre festival that brings together artists from all over the world to expand our hearts and minds with their stories, and inspire creative diversity in our community.

The story:  Eleven years ago, visionary and founder of the MT Space (Multicultural Theatre Space), Majdi Bou-Matar, dreamed of a dynamic week of culturally diverse physical theatre; a platform for artists of all backgrounds to showcase their work and dialogue with audiences and each other. He saw a cross-pollination of artistic and cultural forms, transforming differences into innovation.

Eleven seasons later, the biennial IMPACT festival makes its fourth appearance in Kitchener-Waterloo Ontario, from Sept 22-27, 2015!

IMPACT 15 presents the work of artists from Morocco, Iraq and Australia, theatre and dance from Halifax, Toronto, Edmonton, Vancouver and Whitehorse, in addition to locally born and bred work.  This year, we introduce our very first Stage&Story Market, a space where you can share your story and interact with artists and the community.  The theme of our Smart Stage Conference is Technology, Social Media, & the Revolution celebrating the marriage of the smarts of technology and the wisdom of the arts, and reflects on questions of how technology changes us. And we conclude with our Youth Conference, with performances by two youth companies.

TRAILER:

How Can We Make IMPACT Together?

Together We Make IMPACT is the 2nd Indiegogo Crowdfunding Campaign held by MT Space. With our first campaign in 2013 “We Are Culture,” lovers of theatre and cultural-creatives like yourself, came together to surpass our goal of 16,000.

This year, we are raising the bar to $20,000 to support the programming and artists of IMPACT 15, and with your help, we expect to be successful again.


Specifically, your contributions will support:

  • Artists fees

  • Getting the artists here! transportation & housing costs

  • Production costs (lighting, sound, video, costuming, set, etc.)

  • Staffing costs (administration, promotion, design, volunteer coordination, etc.)

You can make IMPACT by helping us reach our goal by October 31st, 2015.

Visit our website for more info, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and help us by spreading the word far and wide!

Together, we enrich our community with space for all voices.

Together, we create the conditions for innovation and connection.

Together, We Make IMPACT!

If you are unable to donate, there are many other ways you can help us. If you would like to show your support for the belief in the need for diversity of voices in arts and culture, please consider getting involved in any of the following ways:

• Attend our events - be part of our community, volunteer, say hi and get to know us

•  Spread the word online - share our campaign, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, your blog or anywhere else online

•  Talk to your friends – discuss the ideas behind Together We Make IMPACT with those you know, like co-workers or members of your book club

•  Subscribe to our MT Space newsletter

What is MT Space?

MT Space is Kitchener-Waterloo’s first and only multicultural theatre company. Founded by Artistic Director Majdi Bou-Matar in 2004, MT Space has created and produced high quality artistic performances such as The Art of Getting Married, Paradise, Last 15 Seconds, and Seasons of Immigration. These and other productions have both premiered locally and toured Canada to rave reviews. MT Space’s newest production Paradise, is a collaboration with a theatre company in Whitehorse and explores human rights, mental illness and addictions inside the systems that cage us all.

What are some of the Perks of donating?

If you donate to this campaign, there are many perks - see the list on the right side bar!  Here is a description of some special offerings:

  • One of our great perks is a Puppet Show by the talented Arlene Thomas of Shadow Puppet Theatre for $750.  Visit: http://www.shadowpuppettheatre.com
  • A couple of perks at $500 and $2,500 make you the proud owner of a Puppet Creature from Puppet Master Joel Brubacher at Banjo Puppets. You can choose your own colours. See more: https://www.etsy.com/shop/banjopuppets?ref=shop_name_search_sugg

  • Another perk is your very own Private Contact Improvisation Dance Lesson for you and a friend with MT Space's Artistic Associate, dancer and instructor, Tanya Williams.
     Contact improvisation is a whole-body practice in the art of collaboration.  It involves following what makes sense for you while exploring gravity, momentum, & whatever is happening in the moment, including the physical & energetic contact with your dance partners.  At times playful, at times meditative, dancers may share a shifting centre of gravity that can take them into a dynamic dance of lifts and rolls, or into a subtle movement conversation.  Learn more: http://tanyawilliams.ca

  • Our General Manager, Amanda Lowry, who happens to also be an accomplished musician and our Associate Artistic Director, who is an actress and operatic singer, have offered to write a Song Especially for You, if you donate $5,000.

story:
Skin is an original musical dramedy written, directed and composed by Jessie DePasquale for the 2015 Boulder fringe festival. Jessie interviewed woman of all shapes and sizes and married her own experiences with roller coaster weight, addiction, loneliness, physical inadequacies, community and mother/daughter relations  to create a funny and moving piece filled with song, dance and beautiful monologues inspired by real everyday woman. In order to share this important work  with the masses, we are humbly asking for your kind support. Thank you!
  • Venue rental: $800
  • Costumes: $200
  • Set Piece: $100
  • Promotional Material and programs: $ 400
  • Talent: $3200
Cast Members:

Jessie DePasquale, Chie Saito, Jane Shepherd, Bryan O'Malley, Christina Chandrajot Coates, Erika Hodges, Elaine Spivey Niesen, Jess Houwen, Madoka Asari

Skin Description:
Soak in the biographical, whimsical world of Skin, where all are welcome: the tall, short, plump and thin…
Jessica Blane was a girl who would lock herself in her room: an endless world of fantasy, fame and shimmering beauty. When she ventured outside of her room and into the “real” world, Jessica was taught to look in the mirror and hate herself.
Throughout her life Miss Blane slowly spiraled into a deep, dark, savory chocolate pit of despair. Enveloped by a river of sugary bliss, then later torture, Miss Blane went to seek the help of a community of women who have suffered from a similar addiction: food, &/or lack of food.

Will Jessica build the courage to face herself in the mirror? Will she find the soul that is buried deep within the crevasses of her plump flesh? Will she learn to love the skin that she lives in?
With a strong cast, moving music and seductive movement come and see the answers revealed. Caution: Dancing Chocolate bar may penetrate your soul with desire and ecstasy.
Hope to see you soon!!! 

See our Fringe festival reviews at :

http://www.boulderfringe.com/programs/2015-programs/theater-2015-programs/jessie-depasquale/      

Our next run of SKIN is at Naropa University October 8-10, 2015!

story:
WHAT?

Culture Collective Studio is an English speaking theatre in Bangkok Theatre.  Opened in 2015, it produces high-quality plays at affordable prices in a boutique-style black box theatre.  The theatre has established itself as an award winning theatre, winning BEST PLAY in the 2015 Bangkok Theatre Festival.  The company offers professional acting training, voice-over and improvisation workshops, outreach programs to elementary school students, and a two-week international acting intensive for college students.


WHAT ARE THE GOALS?

This campaign is to garner support for the upcoming season:

·  Little Shop of Horrors

·  12 Angry Men

·  Deathtrap

·  Miss Julie


HOW WILL THE FUNDS BE SPENT?

General production expenses.

· Costumes

· Sets

· Advertising


PERKS?


THE CULTURE COLLECTIVE STUDIO TEAM?

·  Loni Berry, Owner and Artistic Director, holds graduate degrees from Brown University and the Yale School of Drama.  With over 20 years experience as a playwright/director, his work has been produced by some of the most prestigious theatres in the United States.  He has worked with a long list of Broadway and Hollywood actors.

·  Kelly Jones, Producer, studied acting in Sydney, Australia and film making at SAE Institute in Bangkok.  In addition to acting in feature films, plays, she does voiceover work in numerous animated TV shows and films.

·  Saratsanan Sasitvirarom, Producer, studied performance and communication arts at Assumption University and has over 10 years experience in art design and IT.


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

  • Share our campaign with ALL of your friends!
  • LIKE us on Facebook!
  • FOLLOW us on Twitter! 
  • Visit us at Culture-Collective.com

story:
What Screams I Hear Are Mine follows a fourteen year old who believes she hears a woman being raped. Her search for the perpetrator takes her and those around her on a tumultuous journey searching for truth and justice.

JUNE 17-18 2016

VENUE: PVPA Theatre, 15 Mulligan Drive, South Hadley, 01075

The Clementine Collective is composed of four members: Micky Strachota, Annalise Cain, Mia Wurgaft and Hannah Simms. Mia, Micky and Annalise met attending the Pioneer Valley Performing Arts Charter High School in South Hadley. We loved working together in school, and joked about founding a theater company after we graduated; with Annalise writing, Micky directing, and Mia acting. We all went our separate ways, but over the past year have come together over a play: What Screams I Hear Are Mine.

Annalise began working on the script her junior year of high school, and was lucky enough to read it with Mia, Micky and our teacher at the time, Hannah Simms. Annalise attended Boston University’s School of Theatre, and had various readings of the play her freshman year. This spring it’s being workshoped by graduate director Kelly Galvin, and will culminate in a staged reading.

OUR CAST:

DANA JACOBS: Lily Lipman

MIRABELLE JACOBS: Mia Wurgaft

NILS KAUFMANN: Zachary Zamsky

APRIL SOUZA: Sade Murray

KENT SOUZA: Miles Jordan

BRENDAN PAVESI: Benjamin Swimmer

As young artists, we’ve taken it upon ourselves to make the art we deem important; stories that are socially relevant and excite us. As each of us have experienced the beginning of our adult lives, the mishandling of sexual cases has been present at each of our campuses, has affected our families and friends, and scarily enough, has been present the whole time. This is an issue that must be discussed, that is exacerbated by a lack of acknowledgment. With our artistry at our disposal, this is how we intend to fight it.

We want to bring this story to our community, and we’re so grateful for everyone who’s helped us so far. To fully realize this vision, we need your help. Your contributions will go towards set, costumes, venue, props and other production expenses.

In return for your help, our group is offering a variety of rewards related to the show. Among these are:

Free Concession

Production Photos

Reserved Seats

Your Name in Our Program

Presale tickets

AND EVEN Coffee and Conservation with the Playwright

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT! We are so grateful for your help and so excited to share our work with the Pioneer Valley!

story:
Mocean Dance is a Halifax based contemporary dance company that believes in the value of bringing Nova Scotian art to new audiences nationally and internationally, and pride ourselves on the technically rich, leading-edge dance works that challenge and engage our audiences.

In April 2015, we presented the world premiere of Sable Island, a tour-de-force quintet commissioned from renowned Canadian dance icon Serge Bennathan. The work has been invited to the Canadian Dance Festival in Ottawa.

We're excited to round out our 14th season with such an exciting and important presentation. As we finish up our last fundraising push for 2015-16, we thought we might make it a little more fun --- so watch the coming campaign trailers, pick your favourite perk, and help us celebrate ending the season on a high note! Artistic fees and accommodation are covered by the Canada Dance Festival, but we need your help to cover some pre-production costs (rehearsal time, to bring Choreographer Serge Bennathan back to Halifax to be in the studio during our remount, and to help get the whole team of wild horses to Ottawa including our production personnel).

About the Canada Dance Festival:
The Canada Dance Festival is a national leader on the vanguard of our dance scene, commissioning and presenting the best of Canadian Dance. This year marks the first time Mocean Dance has been invited to present on the festival's stage. This is a big step for the company, and it is a fitting recognition on the eve of our 15th Anniversary season.
Other ways you can help!

Can't contribute but want to help us out?

  • Share this page with your friends!
  • Come to our home events: we've got free movement workshops at the Halifax Central Library April 6, 13, 20 at 10 AM and a big International Dance Day Celebration at 4:30 April 29 where Co-Artistic Director Susanne Chui will share the national message---she's the first Eastern Canadian Dance Artist to be chosen!

story:
Who Are We?

Borderline Confrontational is an international theatre company founded by students from the Birmingham School of Acting in Birmingham, England. Godspell is our third production. 

Our company stretches across curriculums at BSA, we have students and graduates from the BA Acting, BA Stage Management, MA Acting, and MFA Acting courses from all over the United States and the United Kingdom! 

Why Donate?

We need your help to take Stephen Schwartz's brilliant musical to Edinburgh! You'll help us pay for all the Fringe costs, our venue, accommodation and travel. As students, we can't fund this on our own, so we really need you! 
Our perks are wide-ranging:
  • Postcards from the company from Scotland 
  • Singing voicemail greetings by our talented cast
  • Autographed pictures of the cast 
  • Tickets to the show 
  • Fancy Scottish gifts 
  • Credits in the program
We are also prepared to privatise perks, should anyone wish to donate a large sum! We can offer acting classes, singing or piano lessons, personalized crafts, etc.

How You're Helping 

Here's a breakdown of our budget so you know precisely how much you're helping us by donating! 

£4500 Accommodation for 13 people, 9 nights
£2700 Venue Fees
£1300 Living Costs (Meals and Transport in Edinburgh)
£1200 Travel to and From Edinburgh
£1000 Licensing Fees
£300   Fringe Registration
£350   Costumes/props
£250   Advertising (Printing flyers, posters, and programs)
£100   Insurance
£1300 ~10% Contingency

The Show

Our company is unique in its make-up: we are all students or recent graduates who are working on this project solely for the love of musical theatre. Godspell is a challenging show that presents age-old stories, but we'll present them in a nuanced way. 
Having produced Fugitive Songs and a self-created cabaret to absolutely fabulous results, our team is well-prepared for Fringe. We want to share our talents with a broader audience outside of the Birmingham School of Acting and make our mark on the Fringe Festival with a beautiful, moving show. 

Our Stakes

This project is coming straight from the heart and our producing team has already put our blood, sweat, tears and funds into it. Your donation will help us get to Scotland and feel secure during our time there so that we can focus on putting on the best show possible. 

Give Us A Shout

If you can't contribute (or you can!) please consider sharing our campaign with your friends and family. We can't do this without your help, and given that our company stretches across the pond, we hope our impact and donors can too!

If you can't contribute (or you can!) please consider sharing our campaign with your friends and family. We can't do this without your help, and given that our company stretches across the pond, we hope our impact and donors can too!

story:
Winnie and Mook Dance Company

My name is Winnie Berger, and I moved to New York City from Tucson, Arizona to attend the Fordham University and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater BFA program. My choreographic enthusiasm began in high school, transitioning into college in which I created my most powerful thirty minute piece for my Autistic sister, Violet. As consequence for creating such a personally momentous work, I found an incredible succession of support, stimulation, and empathy by all who attended the performance. This is when I decided that I needed to persevere in creating new pieces, continue telling my story, and embark on a path towards my own dance company: Mook Dance Company. 

This campaign is significant because it is incredibly arduous to begin a dance company—especially in New York City. Choreographers require multiple hours of rehearsal rentals, costumes, application fees, production fees, and of course, paying their dancers to perform. Any contributions through this campaign will go solely towards the foundations required for sustaining this contemporary dance company, and will aid in the spreading of my artistic voice, subjective life and the importance in sharing our anecdotes and narratives.

Funding
The amount of funding I am aiming to raise is $5,000. As evidence from the past few months of 2015, I have spent $1,250 out of my pocket in preparing for and in booking events. The breakdown of the company's spending, so far, is as follows: $600.00 on performance fees, $215.00 on application fees, $345.00 on rehearsal space and $96.00 on costumes. Unfortunately, paying my dancers was not included in this spent amount. I have 8-10 dancers performing per show, and as of this summer, Mook has 7 confirmed shows we are participating in, and likely more. If we do not get the full funding we need to strive towards company sustainability, the amount will continue being spent on logistical endeavors, such as fees and rehearsal space, and less on promoting and supporting the artistry of the dancers that perform my work. They are incredibly committed and brilliant and deserve to receive compensation for their ability and willingness to dance with Mook Dance Company.

Donors, depending on amount, will receive the choice of a bundle of creative gifts including postcards of original artwork, water colored thank you's, acrylic paintings, and framed and autographed company photos. Creating art and performing art is my life's sole objective, thus, I would love to share any of my work in exchange for your support. 
Why Mook Matters
Dance is oftentimes difficult to understand because of its dependent use of metaphor and evocation of an idea without an obvious subject matter or purpose. Yet, what Mook Dance Company aims to accomplish is bridging the gap between metaphor and reality for dancers and non-dancers alike. It is my goal as a choreographer to utilize my voice and tell my story. But if I aim to share with an audience, I feel it is important that my work is comprehensible to understand. This is why my company's repertoire consists of real, palpable, and personal instances and elaborates on those ideas with movement that is both ethereal and literal. My choice to use authentic, natural movement alongside ornamented contemporary movement adds a criteria of relatability and human recognition, while still remaining evocative. I want to combine daily human perceptions with contemporary movement to narrate my own experiences.
Despite discrepancies and drawbacks, I know that I am meant to create a company and share my voice in an artistically prominent sense. I know that I will have to continue paying out of pocket for some of the company's spendings, but will continue doing so. I want to exude prominence, respect, and a sense of acknowledgement for my insight, and I am willing to overcome these hardships in being an artist, dancer, and choreographer. With this donation money, I want to begin the path of collaborating with fellow artists in my company that can contribute artistically: photographers, graphic artists, business model brains, grant writers, musicians. Anyone that can advocate and rise my work to its highest self, while supporting them in an equally compassionate way, is a valuable relationship I hope to sustain. Creating my own dance company is a very important next chapter into my artistic career. 


Thank You For Your Support

Even if you cannot contribute monetarily, please share my Indiegogo campaign with anyone you may know. Word of mouth is a valuable tool in becoming prominent and well known, and I would be continually grateful for that. Thank you!

story:
PhysiKal Bodies: Who Are We? 

We are a group of current students, recent college graduates, and committed artists. Our goal is to share what's important to us; dance and its ability to communicate, with as many people as we can. "Remnants" is our second company production, and we've stepped it up for this year's audience, bringing our show to the 2015 Philadelphia Fringe Festival, with 4 new works, and more energy than ever! Help make this show our best!!

Show Description:

PhysiKal Bodies is proud to present "Remnants," a dance performance exploring the complex interactions between thoughts and emotions, and their tendancies to become jumbled up, lost, imagined, and reformed. Amidst outside influence which parts of us remain the same? What clings to us despite our desire to move forward? How can past decisions influence present actions, and what old habits lie just beneath a clean surface? Witness the composition and decomposition of movement, playing with the mind's inner workings, manifested in the PhysiKal Body. 

Who's Involved?

Dawn Mazzola: Co-Director/Choreographer/Dancer

Dawn holds her BS in Dance from Drexel University, with a minor in Psychology. She is currently pursuing  her Master's degree from Drexel, in Dance/Movement Therapy and Counseling. She is a member of modern-based dance company SomaticMovers, with which she has performed in Philadelphia and Baltimore. Through her student career with Drexel Dance, Dawn traveled to Singapore and England to study and perform. She has participated in and choreographed for Drexel Dance concerts, and worked with choreographers such as Olive Prince, Leah Stein, Manfred Fischback, and Clyde Evans, Jr. For several years, Dawn has performed, choreographed and produced for the Philadelphia Fringe Festival. She currently works with Penn Campus Recreation, as a fitness programming assistant and dance instructor.

Catherine Natter: Co-Director/Choreographer/Dancer

Catherine Natter holds her BS in Dance, as well as her MS in Teaching, Learning and Curriculum from Drexel University, and is a certified elementary school teacher. She was honored during her time at Drexel to complete a dance study tour in London, and in addition to performing with Drexel Dance, Catherine has performed in the Live Arts/Fringe Festival, and in the independent dance film “Momentum,” released in 2014. She's choreographed several works for Drexel Dance Ensemble, as well as for the Philadelphia Dance Academy’s Youth Ballet and the Philly Fringe Festival. Catherine currently teaches at the Conservatory of Music and Dance in Harleysville PA and at The Creative Living Room in Swarthmore, PA where she acts as a children's camp director. She also currently serves as a Pennsylvania substitute teacher. 

Dancers:

Matt Soojian

Sara Simpkins

Elise Mele

Mary Stickney

Cara Slemmer

Francesca Flamminio

Catherine Natter

Dawn Mazzola


How You Can Help/What We Need:

As current University students and recent graduates one of our greatest needs is funds to help bring our vision to life. Your generous donations will help us with production costs including acquiring appropriate venue space, costumes, and more! Our desire is to share our talent and passion for art and dance with the city of Philadelphia, and any support received is appreciated. 

When you donate you can also win prizes and get some exciting perks! So please check out our perks as you continue to explore our page. 


Other Ways You Can Help:

Come see the show! Our dancers will be rehearsing all summer to put together what we predict to be an outstanding performance. If you can't donate, no worries. Come to be entertained! Tell your family and friends and come support the arts and students in Philadelphia! We hope to see you there!


Performance Dates:

September 3rd & 4th: 7:30pm & September 6th: 5:30pm

The Rotunda: 4014 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA 19104

When you donate you can also win prizes and get some exciting perks! So please check out our perks as you continue to explore our page. 

Other Ways You Can Help:
Come see the show! Our dancers will be rehearsing all summer to put together what we predict to be an outstanding performance. If you can't donate, no worries. Come to be entertained! Tell your family and friends and come support the arts and students in Philadelphia! We hope to see you there!

story:
Theatre Uzume is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Theater Uzume must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Who are we?

Theatre Uzume was founded at the New School for Drama in 2014 by Suzanne Karpinski. It is a platform for emerging artists to work collaboratively on the development of hybrid or multidisciplinary theatre and its performance. We bring together media from live rock music, dance, visual art, fashion, and puppetry to circus with narrative theater. This rehearsal-intensive, devised manner of working empowers artists to explore fresh manners of expressing their ideas.

How far would you go to reach the one you love?

You try on their friends, you try on their opinions. You change your hair. You change your life.  Then you look in the mirror and realize you no longer know who you are….

Lamia is the latest devised project here at Theatre Uzume. Working in collaboration, it is an exciting new dance-theatre project that features the music of psychedelic guitar rocker John Barber of Ellis Ashbrook and Brooklyn pop chanteuse Janna Pelle, fashion designer Jessica Lapidos of Tilly and William, and choreographer Shannon Stowe of New Dance Theatre!

Lamia is a serpent that yearns to be human. She watches the life of a man she desires unfold, helpless to attract his attention. When a stranger offers her the chance to assume a womanly form, she must carry her shameful secret with her, lest her true identity destroy them both. Part dance, part live-music and part theater, Lamia explores the lengths we go to and what we compromise to reach the promise of love.

We are currently in development! Our first workshop showing concluded on August 7th, 2015 at Westbeth Gallery in Manhattan. We conducted talkbacks after the performance to gather feedback from our audience. We are gearing up with another round of readings this winter, and if we succeed in raising funds, will bring you a full production around April 2016.

How Does Your Money Help?

Lamia is a collaboration of over 15 artists and performers with a common artistic goal. We need $5000 to cover the basic costs of labor and space for the production.

$25 pays for over one hour of rehearsal space;

$50 pays our musicians for one performance;

$100 pays for our website hosting and program printing;

$250 goes towards compensating our lovely designers and making sure they have the materials they need to do great work;

$500 covers half of our marketing costs!

We are fiscally sponsored by the 501(c)3 non-profit organization, Fractured Atlas, and your contributions are tax deductible to the full extent of the law! Every dollar you donate, from $10 to $1,000, will help us reach our goal.

Fiscal sponsorship from Fractured Atlas allows us to raise tax-deductible funds for the project, piece by piece, finding support from individual donations and grants that are exclusively committed to nurturing the developing work. 

Here's a breakdown of our expenses:

Other Ways You Can Help

Please contribute to Lamia!  Other ways you can help are:  

Share this campaign with your network! 

Like our Facebook page!  

Check out our Website: www.TheatreUzume.com

Credits:

Videography & Editing: Joe Roper, Matt Hartman, Shannon Stowe

story:
Fund Meta-Phys Ed's run of JEW VS. MALTA at La Mama

Our goal for this campaign is to raise $5000 to cover production costs:
-Rehearsal space
-Production materials/costs (Puppets!! Black light ink, Kilts and a van rental to put all that stuff in)
-Administrative costs (Photo copies, binder clips, our press agent)
-Artists and production team fee's (Jesse, Youn, David, Rakia, Molly, Jenn, Avi, Ali, Paul & Karen!)

Our total production budget of  $10,000.
Currently we have raise 20% of our total goal. 

ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE THRU OUR FISCAL SPONSOR "FRACTURED ATLAS" 
 

About the play:
This Fall La Mama presents  the world premiere of the Meta-Phys Ed. production JEW VS. MALTA, a raucous new chop and screw theatre piece  based on Christopher Marlowe's problemati' play "The Jew of Malta", the political theater ideas of Bertolt Brecht and Kanye West's album "Yeezus". 

JEW VS MALTA is about monstrosity and virtuosity, fueled by pantagruelism and peppered with puppetry and dance.  `JEW VS. MALTA is a play about monsters and the monsters who make them. Barabas the Jew is gifted businessman, who is turned into a monster when his sizable fortune is confiscated to fund a government bail out.

The cast of JEW VS. MALTA features Youn Jung Kim, Rakia Seaborn and David North. 

The production features lighting design by Jennifer Reiser, costume design by Karen Boyer, scenic design / props by Ali Shrago-Spechler and sound design by Avi Amon. Stage management is by Molly Bicks. The Assistant Director is Mehdya Fassi and the Production Manager is Paul Passaro. 

Tickets are $20. Students and seniors pay less: $15. Visit: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/962608  

Performances of JEW VS. MALTA are on 10/28 at10pm; 10/29 at 10pm; 10/30 at 6pm; 11/4 at 10pm; 11/5 at 10pm and 11/6 at 6pm. 

 

ABOUT META-PHYS ED. 

Meta-Phys Ed. explores religion, spirituality, and politics thru original performance works that hybridize classical or sacred texts with contemporary forms. Meta-Phys Ed. was founded in 2011 by Artistic Director Jesse Freedman and rabbinical student, composer, and playwright Bronwen Mullin.

http://www.meta-physed.com

Last Summer we produced our KARAOKE BACHAE at the New Ohio Ice Factory Festival. This year we are honored to be presented by La Mama, an historic experimental theater venue in Manhattans east village.  Our company is growing!

 

ABOUT LAMAMA

La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club is dedicated to the artist and all aspects of the theatre. Founded in 1961 by Ellen Stewart, La MaMa is recognized as the seedbed of new work by artists of all nations and cultures. To date, La MaMa has presented more than 150,000 artists from over 70 nations. Each season, LaMaMa offer’s more than 80 productions and receive 34,000 visits from people of all ages and all backgrounds who attend performances, exhibitions, educational activities and the Archives. LaMaMa supports the people who make art, and it is to them that they give $2 million of in-kind support including free theatre and rehearsal space, and audio/visual package, tech support, marketing support, and ticketing services. LaMaMa enables artists explore their ideas and translate them into a theatrical language that can communicate to any person in any part of the world. La MaMa is the place where emerging artists learn from established artists and where artists from around the globe share work and ideas. Its East Village campus has grown to include four theatres, an art gallery, artist work and living space and an extensive Archive.

 Jesse Freedman/Meta-Phys Ed. is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Jesse Freedman/Meta-Phys Ed. will be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Contributions for the charitable purposes of Jesse Freedman/Meta-Phys Ed. will be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
ABOUT PAGEANT TALES AND BEAUTY FAILS

Pageant Tales and Beauty Fails is a hilariously offensive mockumentary style play that follows the crazy characters that inhabit the fictional America's Goddess Pageant in sunny Sarasota, Florida. With characters including Miss Alabama and her overbearing mother, Miss New Jersey and her personal gay, the has-been soap star host, the quintessential pageant coach-slash-stylist, and the ever so sweet pageant coordinator, everything is bound to be a hot mess. Pageant Tales and Beauty Fails brings everything from tiaras to catfights and the dreaded question & answer.

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Pageant Tales and Beauty Fails will be presented at Theater for the New City's Dream Up Festival at the end of August. This is an incredible opportunity to bring a broader audience to see the hard work we're sharing. You donation will help fun:

  • a stipend for the company (we like them a lot!)
  • rehearsal spaces (we gotta make sure everything is in tip top shape)
  • a limited budget for sets, costumes, lights, and sound (it's a pageant play! go big or go home!)
  • post cards and posters and pictures, oh my (we got to get butts in the seats!)

WHO'S INVOLVED

Michael Bradley- Playwright

Tony Curtis- Director

Samantha Algieri as Nicole, Miss New Jersey

Heather Cadarette as Bonnie Rae, Miss Alabama

Brian Collins as Joey, Nicole's Personal Gay

Madeline Hickman as Melanie, Miss Texas

Victoria Ann Miller as Loretta, Bonnie Rae's Momma

Matthew Menendez as Terence, Pageant Coach-Slash-Stylist

Sophie Moshofsky as Kayla, Miss California

Alexis Robbins as Marjorie, Pageant Coordinator

Kate Villanova as Colette, Miss Louisiana

Julia Warner as Rhiannon, Miss Utah

Ian Way as Duffy, Kayla bf

Jarrett Alfred Yoder as Alan Price, Pageant Host


WHEN IS THE SHOW?

Pageant Tales and Beauty Fails will be presented at Theater for the New City (155 1st Avenue) August 24th at 5:00pm, August 30th at 5:00pm, August 31st at 2:00pm, September 2nd at 6:30pm, and September 5th at 9:00pm.

For more information on the Dream Up Festival, please visit http://dreamupfestival.org/

Tickets are on sale now at http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?EID=&showCode=PAG6&BundleCode=&PackageCode=&GUID=0f04c020-7785-4bdc-906a-7cbaefc06e95

For more on Pageant Tales and Beauty Fails, visit us at facebook.com/pageanttalesandbeautyfails
story_txt:
ABOUT PAGEANT TALES AND BEAUTY FAILSPageant Tales and Beauty Fails is a hilariously offensive mockumentary style play that follows the crazy characters that inhabit the fictional America's Goddess Pageant in sunny Sarasota, Florida. With characters including Miss Alabama and her overbearing mother, Miss New Jersey and her personal gay, the has-been soap star host, the quintessential pageant coach-slash-stylist, and the ever so sweet pageant coordinator, everything is bound to be a hot mess. Pageant Tales and Beauty Fails brings everything from tiaras to catfights and the dreaded question & answer. WHY WE NEED YOUR HELPPageant Tales and Beauty Fails will be presented at Theater for the New City's Dream Up Festival at the end of August. This is an incredible opportunity to bring a broader audience to see the hard work we're sharing. You donation will help fun:
a stipend for the company (we like them a lot!)

rehearsal spaces (we gotta make sure everything is in tip top shape)

a limited budget for sets, costumes, lights, and sound (it's a pageant play! go big or go home!)
post cards and posters and pictures, oh my (we got to get butts in the seats!)
WHO'S INVOLVEDMichael Bradley- PlaywrightTony Curtis- DirectorSamantha Algieri as Nicole, Miss New JerseyHeather Cadarette as Bonnie Rae, Miss AlabamaBrian Collins as Joey, Nicole's Personal GayMadeline Hickman as Melanie, Miss TexasVictoria Ann Miller as Loretta, Bonnie Rae's MommaMatthew Menendez as Terence, Pageant Coach-Slash-StylistSophie Moshofsky as Kayla, Miss California Alexis Robbins as Marjorie, Pageant CoordinatorKate Villanova as Colette, Miss Louisiana Julia Warner as Rhiannon, Miss UtahIan Way as Duffy, Kayla bf Jarrett Alfred Yoder as Alan Price, Pageant HostWHEN IS THE SHOW?Pageant Tales and Beauty Fails will be presented at Theater for the New City (155 1st Avenue) August 24th at 5:00pm, August 30th at 5:00pm, August 31st at 2:00pm, September 2nd at 6:30pm, and September 5th at 9:00pm. story: Ballet Theatre of Illinois is a 501 ©3 not for profit dance company for pre-professional artists. BTI was established to enhance the training of aspiring dancers. Our purpose is to provide company members with opportunities to perform and cultivate personal artistic growth, without requiring a specific studio affiliation.

story:
Our Story

The Program Notes:

Kitsune Circus is a group of young adults between the ages of 24 & 30 who have decided that the status is not quo. Much of our lives we've been told that the only way to make a good living in this world is to get a college degree. So we went out and got them. Then the economy tanked and we had to reexamine our plans. When we really sat down and thought about it, we decided the current system is flawed. Big corporations own everything and working for a corporation is no fun. We want to be a part of something meaningful, impactful and enjoyable for us and those around us. We want to make our living doing things we feel passionate about and the best way to do it is to start your own business, so we are! 


So, the breakdown. 

Who: Joan, Lauren, Jeff, Diana, Vinny and Laura. We're a mix of advanced and beginner circus performers hoping to make a living doing what we love and bringing it to you. 


What: Kitsune Circus. A brand new company designed to make circus arts and entertainment fun, affordable and accessible to everyone. 


Where: Our home base is in Long Island, NY. We hope to tour throughout the north east this summer and spread further and further as we get more and more recognition. 


When: The kickstarter will run for 65 days. Then we'll purchase our equipment, train over the winter and start up with an epic Launch Party in March of 2012. In the summer we plan to both private gigs, booked through our website and public performances at renaissance faires and fringe festivals throughout the northeast!


How: We use the funds you send us to purchase equipment & other necessary start up costs, then with the leadership of our senior members, we whip ourselves into shape for the Launch Party in March and the subsequent tour in the summer!


The Impact

The Mission a.k.a. Save the Circus, Save the World:
It seems like these days everyone you meet is struggling with something. They're overworked, underpaid and super-stressed all the time. At Kitsune Circus we believe that one of the most important things in life is enjoying it! If you can't relax and have a good time every so often, it makes all the difficult things that we have to do in a day seem that much worse. What's more, we truly believe that laughter is the best medicine. Laughter and excitement help to battle stress which, in high levels, can lead to high blood pressure, headaches, upset stomach, trouble sleeping, problems with your immune system, and possible mental health and chronic disease problems. We can keep the world healthy and happy by giving everyone a chance to enjoy and participate in circus arts, a fun and unique experience, both for the audience and the performers. When people can relax and have a good time in a safe environment, it enables them to get inspired, take risks, build confidences and do things they never thought they were capable of. We want to bring these qualities to you. 
 
In order to deliver our special brand of "medicine" though, we need your help. Without you we're just a struggling start-up, like everyone else. With you, we're a charming, exciting and unique new performance group with the ability to change the world, one audience at a time.  


What We Need & What You Get

The Pre-Show Meeting: 

Alright people, here's where we get down to the nitty gritty. The money we're trying to raise is going to pay for 3 major categories of items. The first category is aerial and safety equipment. This includes our portable rig, an aerial hoop with rigging, a massive crash pad for safety during practice and rehearsal as well as a ground gymnastics pad for practicing and performing partner acrobatics. This stuff is mostly first priority because it will enable us to practice more safely and bring you longer, better and more exciting shows. 


The second category is individual equipment. This includes stuff like bullwhips, fire fans, an LED staff and a handful of other stuff. Though all the equipment will be owned by the company it's primarily used by one performer at a time. This stuff will allows us to practice on our own time and make our shows more comprehensive, professional and flexible by allowing us to adapt our show to different conditions (e.g. fire, LED, daytime, etc). This stuff is second priority because we want to ensure we have a professional, beautiful and exciting look when we come to you to perform.


The third category is non-performance equipment/services. This includes a Graphic Designer fee, a portable amp and a DSLR camera (+ necessary accessories). We've added this category to our budget to ensure that we can perform in any space with extreme flexibility and little to no dependence on outside circumstance. The graphic designer will work with us to develop a beautiful website, brand identity and marketing campaign.The camera will help us document our performances and rehearsals with photos and video so you can always see what's going on. This stuff is our third priority because it will help us achieve the highly polished and professional look of a great circus company while also enabling us to stay connected with you, our fans. 


In the unfortunate event that we don't reach full funding, we'll start with Category 1 and work our way through to the bottom priorities until we run out of funding. If you'd like to see a more detailed account of what we're planning to do with the money and how things are prioritized, feel free to email us for a pdf of our budget! We'd be happy to show you. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Be a Barker!

In the circus, a barker is not an overactive pooch. Rather, it's the person that uses their charm and boisterous personality to call people to the tent and let them know what's going on! If you commit to being a Barker for Kitsune Circus you can get a free upgrade from your donation level (even if that level is 0$!) to the next! All you have to do is use your social network to get us noticed. Get five people to like us on Facebook or follow us on Twitter and you can get a 1 free upgrade. If you get at least 2 people to donate 10$ or more, you can get another free upgrade! You can get both of these upgrades and they can stack, but the limit is 3 upgrades of any combination. For example: If you get ten friends to like/follow us and 2 donors, you can get 3 upgrades, but if you get ten friends and 4 donors, you still only get 3 upgrades - otherwise we'd spend all our money sending you gifts, and while awesome, it'd kind of defeat the point. Perks above the 1000$ level are not eligible for upgrades.

story:
George V. Higgins' The Friends of Eddie Coyle

Since it was published in 1972, George V. Higgins' The Friends of Eddie Coyle has set the bar by which all badass Boston crime stories are measured.  Written by a master of dialogue and a federal prosecutor, the dialogue sounds as if it was pulled from wiretaps and the story is among the most realistic, unforgiving, portrayals of criminals ever written.

 

We're launching a world premirre of the first stage adaptation of The Friends of Eddie Coyle, bringing the dialogue, the characters, and perhaps the most realistic depiction of crime's underbelly to the stage.  We open at Oberon, Harvard Square, in December -- and we're seeking funds to ensure tickets remain affordable so we can tell this one of a kind story in a new way, to a new audience.

 

Eddie Coyle is a couple of weeks away from a jail sentence for trucking stolen booze, and making some money supplying guns to a crew of bank robbers.  He's trying to stay alive and out of jail among his friends: robbers, bartenders, cops, rats, and hitmen.

 

Elmore Leonard called it the best crime novel ever written.  Writers from David Mamet to Quentin Tarantino learned from the use of dialogue.  And no one has captured the character, the humor, and the poetry of the Boston dialect as well, before or since. 

 

Performed live, in a nightclub style theater, the story can unfold all around the audience.  A story of lies and betrayal at the lowest rungs of the crimnal underworld. 

 

No fake accents -- Local talent

 

We're casting locally grown, experienced actors to bring this story to life and be true to the time and place where it's set:  greater Boston, winter of 1969-70.  The play swirls around from neighborhood bars, to supermarket parking lots, to a trailer park in Orange, to banks, to the Boston Garden to watch Bobby Orr play. 

 

And this is why we're asking for help.  To bring the story to life properly, it takes a crew of eleven actors, lighting designers, sound techs, costume designers, and set designers to do justice to the story.  All of these people will be working diligently to produce a quality show, and bring The Friends of Eddie Coyle to new audiences.

 

All funds raised support these professionals and produce a quality and affordable show for greater Boston.

December 8 - Jan. 15

We will run for 11 performances at Oberon, Harvard Square -- and ticket prices will largely be determined by the success of our fundraising.  All contributors -- at any amount - will be listed in the program as A Friend of Eddie Coyle and we make no bones about it:  You helped make the show possible. 

 

We mean business

Got a business and want to advertise in our program?  We'd love to talk to you.  Send us an email at admin@stickballproductions.com or call 857.756.7056 for advertising and sponsorship information.

 

Make Eddie New Friends

If you can give, we thank you.  If you can't, we ain't mad at ya.  There's other ways to help. 

 

Post this link on your Facebook page with a nudge to your friends.  Tweet us.  Email your friends.

 

Whether they give, or decide to come to the show -- that's enormous -- we thank you in advance. 

 

Got a lot of time and not a lot of money?  There are volunteer opportunities to see the show for free.  Email us at admin@stickballproductions.com. 

 

Come see The Friends of Eddie Coyle in December

Most important:  Oberon, Harvard Square, December 8 through January 15.  The bar's open throughout the performance,  Tickets will be on sale in November -- get on the mailing list at admin@stickballproductions.com

 

We're looking forward to seeing you there.

Thank you

On behalf of all of us at Stickball Productions, Inc. -- thank you!

story:
The Unknown Artists' 321 Festival

3 Plays, 2 Weekends, 1 Act

May 31 - June 9, 2013

The Unknown Artists are proud to present our very first FESTIVAL OF ONE ACTS: The 321 Festival (three plays, two weekends, one act).  This production features actors, playwrights, and crew made up of members from Play Club West, our group which meets weekly in North Hollywood for readings of new and established works. Two of our one acts, "Devour" and "Snakeskin Suit" are original works, developed through Play Club West's NEW WORKS SERIES, and the final slot is filled with the hilarious comedy "Matt and Ben," by Mindy Kaling and Brenda Withers.

After the recent success of our production of the original musical, Right Together, Left Together, we know how instrumental our supporters are to achieving the highest production level possible.


That being said, as we approach opening night we need your help! All donations will go directly to necessities such as theater rental and insurance, promotional materials, production rights, and rehearsal space.


Read about each of the three shows below! If you are unable to donate, you can help by sharing our campaign via Facebook, Twitter, etc. You can also show your support in person by seeing any or all of the performances! You can buy tickets HERE.


SNAKESKIN SUIT, an original play by J. Holtham

Directed by Joshua Hsu

Sound Design by D.A. Strawder

Stage Managed by Travis James Riner

Starring Jeni Incontro, Oscar Gubelman, Tiffany Brain, and Ben Montague

Lily's new boyfriend is funny, charming, more than a little goofy and...the devil. No, really, Satan. Lucifer. The font of all evil. But he's not really that bad. Or is he? Does he have a diabolical plan for Lily's soul? Or does he just want to win her heart? As she falls deeper and deeper, and her friends get more and more worried about her heart and her immortal soul, Lily has to face her own inner demons...and maybe a few outer ones, too.


DEVOUR, an original play by Chelsea Marcantel

Directed by Emily Clark

Stage Managed by Aielo Jimenez

Starring Meghan Allison, Anna Bowen, Cody Clark, Andy Kenarecki, Kate Purnell, Caitlin Reilly, and Travis James Riner 

Anaïs von Windsor is a tabloid queen from the moment she’s born, but nothing can top her confession to the triple-murder of her ex-boyfriends.  Unless of course she’s making it up.  Through a series of non-linear vignettes, we are exposed to both sides of Anaïs: the hard-partying attention-whore she’s proud of, and the frighteningly wounded young girl she tries so hard to ignore.  But does deciding for ourselves whether or not she’s a monster get us any closer to the truth?

 

MATT & BEN, written by Mindy Kaling & Brenda Withers

Directed by Nicole Dominguez

Stage Managed by Cody Clark

Starring Amy Bartlett and Emily Clark

Written by the hilarious best friend duo Brenda Withers and Mindy Kaling, Matt & Ben is a satire on the pre-paparazzi, pre-fame friendship between Oscar-winning screenwriters and actors Ben Affleck and Matt Damon, as played by two women. When the screenplay for 'Good Will Hunting' drops mysteriously from the heavens, the boys realize they're being tested by a higher power.

 

The Unknown Artists’ mission is to provide opportunities for talented, unknown individuals to thrive on a stage, enabling them to show off their gifts of music, acting, dance, comedy, film, and all categories of art. Founded in 2007 by Emily Clark and Pamela Eberhardt, the Unknown Artists search far and wide for an explosive amount of talent that is of a specific, unheard of, untraveled artistry.  Our goal: to make Unknown Artists KNOWN.

 

Performance Schedule

Friday, May 31st - Matt & Ben 7pm, Snakeskin Suit 8:30pm

Saturday, June 1st - Snakeskin Suit 7pm, Devour 8:30pm

Sunday, June 2nd - Devour 7pm, Matt & Ben 8:30pm

Friday June 7th - Snakeskin Suit 7pm, Matt & Ben 8:30pm

Saturday June 8th - Matt & Ben 7pm, Devour 8:30pm

Sunday, June 9th - Devour 7pm, Snakeskin Suit 8:30pm

Ticket info can be found HERE.

All performances will be held at The Magic Mirror Theater at 4934 Lankershim Blvd., North Hollywood, CA 91601.

Ticket info can be found HERE.
All performances will be held at The Magic Mirror Theater at 4934 Lankershim Blvd., North Hollywood, CA 91601.

story:
Small Fish Radio Theatre and Thespinarium is old-time style radio show, that showcases new plays, poetry, stories and music. 

Born out many writers and not enough opportunities, our mission is to give voice to small fish in the big pond. The competition out there is fierce. Our goal is to get as much work heard by as many people as possible. The medium is fun, unique, and we offer it for FREE.

If we’re to mount the next season, we need some help. In addition to the normal costs of producing theatre—we have the added expense of sound equipment and software. All of which we've purchased on our own so far. As we move forward our equipment needs to support our growth, not hold us back. 

Growth. Since our pilot episode, we have evolved to producing a regular live show, and going national with our calls for submissions-receiving 115 for our upcoming horror show. Last spring we were invited to participate in the Atlanta Fringe Festival and the Hear Now festival for six weeks, which helped us gain more of a following.

Please feed the fish. Help us give a voice to emerging playwrights, poets, storytellers and musicians.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Bernard Bey. To be honest and frank the concept and idea for this project is based on my own life experiences growing up. I only want to afford some of the youth in our urban communities who desperately need and deserve it an opportunity to become successful at something we both love, performing arts. When I look back at my life and relive all my own struggles I have this deep longing, thinking to myself if I only had an opportunity to do it all over, but alas, once reality  sets in, as it always does, I realize what is done can never be undone.  Life only moves forward, what I can do is provide direction for youth who endure similar situations. As beneficial as it is for the youth, it will be equally beneficial for myself and all who are engaged within this project. I feel its and opportunity for us to shine a light into the world for people to notice and to help instill a concrete perception of the importance of education saving and finance to these young adults who truly need it. How can a young adult make good decisions without knowing available options or direction from a positive role model on how to execute them? What I wish I had I want to give to someone else and this is my motivation.  With the combined efforts of myself, Dianna and Moni we have committed ourselves to this project and we move forward with passion and conviction to make this event a reality. With your support we shall be victorious.

 We Need Your Help

We need $100,000 dollars in financing to pay for performance space at York Community College, Stage staff, sets, and props.targeted social media marketing, a promotional street team the production of a compilation album as well as other promotional and marketing materials such as T- Shirts, buttons, etc. In a nut shell we need at least 2000 people to contribute $50 dollars to our campaign. The twelve youth selected to participate in the project will receive four weeks of mentoring with and emphasis on education, financial literacy, the incentives of vocations and business and success stories. During and two months following the mentoring aspect of the project, the youth will be working on the production of the theatrical event "Reaching Your Full Potential" This will continue every Saturday from 11am until 7pm at one of the performing arts colleges in NYC.

The project director Diana Rocker will conduct the project with the performance coordinator Jade E. Griffith concerning Choreograph of all numbers within the event, she will also cover hair and make up for the production. After the production is complete and ready to be performed. We will also have completed the audio production of the compilation album "Reaching Your Full Potential" which will be handled by Ramona Delgado. We will secure merchandise to be sold at the theatrical event. Once this whole process is complete we will conduct a tour to be conducted in select cities and states. 3 showcases per city starting with NYC. 20% of all proceeds will be given to the youth to use towards a college education, vocation, or expenses pertaining to obtaining the same or a suitable business endeavor.

 

The Impact

I want to stress the fact that our contributors are helping to provide the youth in our local urban communities an opportunity to change their lives. More than a fair amount of the youth in our communities lack direction and prove to be irresponsible and unfocused about what career path they should take to become a resposnsible  successful adult. Most do not know basic financial concepts such as the importance of saving, how to open a checking or savings account for themselves at a financial institution. On more than one occassion I have witnessed the fact that they don't understand credit or it's neccessity in establishing a foundation for yourself as a young adult to obtain  an appartment, an automobile, in the future a home or financing for a business etc. As we conduct this project we will mentor the youth on these core principals and the importance of education. Ultimately this foundation will give the youth the tools they need to become responsible successful adults. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Get envolved! Tell your friends and family to get involved. Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Help us get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

To make this campaign successful, that’s all there is to it.
